review_text: R.I.P. Ms. Harper Lee, Feb. 19, 2016. Thank you for writing one of the great American novels.

Whoa. Its different from the way I remember the movie. The movie works as a movie, but the book sure works well as a book. The movie builds to a dramatic ending, but the book keeps you on the edge throughout, and has charming moments to boot. I can't get enough of the lawyer as hero! Well worth the read.

I love this book. It highlight something so simple that it misses us in everyday life. 
 It shows the human contradicting nature. 
 I don't think I hate to recap the values in it. It's been told many times. 
 A good book to read, a wonderful perspective to see from. 
 And in all, the story is alive. You cannot not live with it. 
 I guess if I have to say what I like, I wouldn't be able to say it. 
 Many times I feel that I can argue with the contents but in the end, it shoots right back at me. 
 They are not all right, nor am I all wrong. 
 But there's only reality and a wide view in which one cannot state his like or dislikes. 
 I have to stay and think for a while to come up for a better review. 
 But for now, this is it.

To Kill A Mockingbird was actually quite interesting. I'm not a big fan of classics, thinking them outdated and hard to read but this novel was satisfying. It was a bit slow at the start, and then there was this sequence of seemingly random events through the novel, which confused me. But then I started to realize they were all symbolic events and they really drove the point forwards- of the inequality of the American South and the African Americans. I also really like the attitude of the Finches, especially that of Atticus Finch who has some pretty remarkable quotes in there.

I can't believe I made it through high school without reading this one. I've always meant to read it but never had, but the audiobook version I listened to on my way home to visit family was excellent. The voice of Scout was well-chosen and all those country sayings had a lot of flavor when read aloud. The story is one that many better than I have critiqued, so I will say that it made me feel lots of feelings and feel glad that I don't live in that time. Though there are people of the future who will feel that way about our present and be glad they didn't live now for the very same reasons. Our prejudice may not be as blatant now, but it still exists and influences everyday life. What I found most awful was the fact that every single person in Scout's story seemed to have a prejudice against someone. The worst said it loudly and proudly, some said it while trying to help the less fortunate and patronizingly, some thought they weren't prejudiced (like Scout and Jim), but they had all those notions about Boo Radley. I think Atticus is the best person in the story, but even he had some prejudices against womenfolk and how they shouldn't be on a jury since they'd interrupt all the time. Everyone in town had someone to look down on. 
 Scout's teacher getting mad at her for reading incorrectly made me mad and then it was so ridiculous I had to giggle. I guess similar educational decisions throughout history have been just as silly. Hopefully they haven't been harmful, but I loved what Scout said about school and it is a good reminder to teachers that no matter what, we should make sure that this isn't what our kids are thinking! As I inched sluggishly along the treadmill of the Maycomb County school system, I could not help receiving the impression that I was being cheated out of something. Out of what, I knew not. Yet I did not believe that twelve years of unrelieved boredom was exactly what the state had in mind for me. 
 It was adorable that when Scout felt neglected by her 'future husband', Dill, she said she beat him up twice but it did no good. he he he. 
 Sometimes the Bible in the hand of one man is worse than a whiskey bottle in the hand of your father. 
 There are just some kind of men who are so busy worrying about the next world they've never learned to live in this one. 
 The one thing that doesn't abide by majority rule is a person's conscience. 
 The scene in front of the door of the jail was horrifying and the fact that an innocent girl's questions and conversation was the only thing that saved everyone from violence was awful. The mob mentality described was spot on. 
 All the little man on the witness stand had that made him any better than his nearest neighbors was that if scrubbed with lye soap and very hot water, his skin was white. 
 We're so rarely called on to be Christians, but when we are, we've got men like Atticus to go for us. 
 I thought Dill's idea about becoming a clown since he thought he couldn't do anything about the people being crappy so he might as well laugh at them. 
 The absolute hypocrisy of the people being upset about the persecution of the Jews in Europe while they stepped all over the black people here at home was maddening. I want to go back in time and ask how the hell they reconciled that in their brains. 
 The discussion of why some families were better than others between the kids was funny and insightful. They couldn't figure out why some families were older than others if they all had ancestors anyway. Aunt Alexandra's insistence that their family was old and better than others was confusing to them. They conclude that all the families are alike, but then wonder why they all hate each other if that is true. Then Jim sums it up by saying he understands why Boo Radley stayed inside his house all the time. (To stay away from the awful humans all around him). 
 I thought the description of the society of ladies was spot-on. The ladies all had an air of quiet and respect but sat there making scathing comments couched in innocent conversation that was just as biting as the out-right insults that the men used. Scout preferred the forthrightness of the men since it got out there and then the subsequent fight would settle things. 
 In the secret courts of men's hearts, Atticus had no case. Tom was a dead man the minute Mayella Ewell opened her mouth and screamed.
Still as wonderful as I remember.

The setting is a small southern town, the time is the Great Depression, just before WW II. Jem and Scout are growing up without their mother, but surrounded by caring neighbors. When their father Atticus is assigned to defend a black man accused of raping a white woman, their lives are changed forever. Harper Lee is a gifted storyteller. Her sentences are so beautifully written and so layered. Her sense of humor is acute and Scout's voice is especially precocious and charming. I can't imagine getting tired of this book, ever. Every time I read it, I get something new out of it. Reading it with my son was a great experience. He often wanted to stop and discuss issues that came up in the book, and it added a lot to the experience. He did make fun of me a little when I cried at the end. It always gets me when Atticus says thank you to Boo Radley. Every time.

Thoroughly enjoyed reading this book. I especially loved the second half; the court case was so interesting and brilliantly written. I would love to study this book and really analyse it as it covers so many important topics, ranging from racism, social class divides and injustice within society in southern America in the 1960's. The story is told both from a child's perspective (Scout) which gives an innocence and naivety to situations, but also from Scout reflecting on the events as an adult. The characters are extremely endearing and likeable and the acts of bravery they displayed were heart warming. A wonderful coming of age classic!

Because of The Big Read, I both read this and listened to it this spring. For a book that I have read several times and now listened to - it never gets old. How Harper Lee managed to write this book at all; let alone write it as a first novel is beyond my comprehension.

Great book, true classic, every time you read it you get a little more out of it, or see something in a different light. If you haven't read it you really should, it belongs on everyone's bucket list.
Read during high school

If someone were to ask me what this book was about, I wouldn't be able to tell them with one answer. The book holds many meanings. The meaning I emerged with is this: be patient and do not judge without knowing first. What I loved about this book is Atticus' defending a black man, but the story doesn't revolve around that fact. . .even though it is the major event that caused all the chaos. Reading the book from a child's point of view made just that much more interesting. The ending was perfect. . ."He would be there all night, and he would be there when Jem waked up in the morning." I can't think of anything else that would be more suitable then that sentence for a closure. 
 I'd recommend this book in a heartbeat.

Set book for English O'Level. I remember the class astonishment when the teacher admitted that he'd read it through without realising that Scout was a girl! 
 Although the prejudices and injustices seem antedeluvian now it is worth bearing in mind that, when the book (and superb film) came out in the early 1960s, James Stewart (the great fair minded movie hero himself),apparently turned down the role of Atticus because he felt the part represented too liberal a viewpoint.

This is one of my alltime favorite books. It's right up there with the Harry Potter series! When I first heard that we were reading it in English, I kind of groaned. You know, "Oh, no, not another one of those boring old books." 
 This book is not boring. It is awesome. The characters are all very well developed and likable, the theme rings true, and the narrative voice is simply beautiful to read. I gobbled it right up and couldn't stop reading, even though I probably wasn't supposed to read ahead in class. 
 The only problem I can see with it is that it's not very strong on plot. There are two plots that aren't really connected until the end. Though the story is very engaging, not all the parts are entirely connected to each other. But I don't necessarily think the book would have been better if it was more plot focused. It was just right for the kind of book it is.
Excellent book. Scout's youthful, innocent and untainted narration made this book enjoyable and even humorous at times.
I hope the sequel won't be a disappointment

Reading this as an adult lends a new perspective and the book resonated even more deeply with me. Beautifully written, moving, and evocative. As a younger person, this book didn't make it to my "top 5" list, but now, as a re-read these years (decades?) later, it does.

Oh, boo! Radley. (Get it?) Anyway, To Kill A Mockingbird is one of the most dreaded books to read in high school (not to mention Lord of the Flies, which I will never reviewed because I already read it a long time ago. I don't review books I read a long time ago unless people ask me politely). Most students wouldn't even read the first page of the book, for the fear of reading a dull and obnoxious books. (Like Treasure Island [I fell asleep on that one]). After 50 years plus after the date of publishing, I'm confused why To Kill A Mockingbird would be on the list of required reading. (And hey, lazy high school kids? I might slip some answers you're looking for in your direction.) 
 Even though the main character is Scout Finch, we are focused on Atticus Finch, who is Scout's somewhat distant father. Scout's mother died when she was younger, therefore only briefly mentioned by Scout. Cal, the Finch's housekeeper, fills in the role. Scout is used to the racial slurs and bad words and the gossip that surrounds the town. Although Scout is used to the areas and words of Maycomb, she's quite ignorant in the ways of the Great Depression. (I suspect she knows nothing about it.) 
 The term "Mockingbird" is first mentioned by Atticus Finch to mentions something along the line that to kill mockingbird is a sin. However, it was Miss. Maurie who actually explained the meaning of the mockingbird in full terms. (I believe that's somewhere in part one.) To kill a mockingbird is to destroy the goodness and beauty of _____. Obviously, the mockingbird is a symbol of a person, but whom is the question? There's several candidates for the role. The major players in line are Tom Robinson and Boo Radley. Tom, because he did nothing but help a white women do her chores out of the sorry and goodness from his heart. (Robinson died in the end). And Boo, who gave the children (Jem and Scout) gifts and protected them when they needed him. Atticus Finch also is an excellent candidate for the symbol, but his evidence isn't as big as Robinson's or Radley's. (Don't forget about his last name, Finch, which is a bird. Perhaps another hint-hint from the author?) 
 As time goes on, we see major changes in Jem, Scout, and Dill. Jem and Scout matures the most in the book. Jem, with his old memories of his lost mother, is somewhat softer and more empathic about other people than Scout. He's able to understand other people, which makes him more mature in ways that are different from Scout. Dill is the innocent child, the one with penchants for tall tales and ridiculous stories. (Remember, his story of running from home?) Dill is the outsider of the trio. He's not a native to Maycomb so he doesn't understand the POV of someone who comes from Maycomb. (Evidence: Jem tries to explain to Dill about the personalities and characteristics of Maycomb citizens in the beginning of To Kill A Mockingbird.) 
 Then there's Scout, who has the biggest change of all. Remember Walter Cunningham in the beginning of the novel? Remember Scout's distaste and protests about Walter's table manners because she doesn't understand why Walter does that? (Walter, by the way, pours syrup all over his food because syrup is a luxury in his poor family. He's unused to fine food.) By the end of the book, she able to understand Boo's personality and mind. (Boo, by the way, is the most mysterious character pretty much all of Maycomb.) 
 Maycomb is a Southern town located in US. Obviously the Civil War made a huge effect on the people and and their children and their children's children. Racism, prejudice, and the no-censorship on any cussing words like "whore lady" are part of Maycom, but is not the biggest part of the novel, other than prejudice, which had a huge effect on the Tom Robinson v. Ewells case. 
 I know I went through this book in great detail, but I can't figure out why people like this book so much. 50 years is a long time running, but I don't get why people like To Kill a Mockingbird. Maybe because it's the same problem as Scout Finch, the inability to walk in other people's shoes. I don't know why people like To Kill A Mockingbird. To me, this book is a boring waste of time and in depth reading. 
 Rating: One out of Five

So somehow I got through all my school years without ever having read this book. And while I've seen snippets of the movie, I never knew how it ended. Basically, it's a good book and I see why it's so popular to assign to school age kids. There were parts through the middle that were a bit dull for me and just seemed like filler but towards the end it picks up and the trial is pretty interesting. The ending was a bit too easy of a resolution for me, but it might work better for younger readers.
My favorite book of all time.
Damn this book is good. I can see why Harper Lee only wrote one book.

Upon first reading this, I, like so many others, fell in love. It's a lovely story about a girl and her perfect life and marvelous father and it has ridiculousness like a giant ham costume. It is also the story that everyone wants to believe, that had I lived in a time of racial oppression I wouldn't have gone along with the casual and cruel racism of my class and color, I would have taken a principled stand. 
 Sure, that's what I'd like to believe. There are so many stories of wonderful white folks saving the oppressed peoples of the world. But mostly, people didn't. Those whites who didn't attend lynchings as if they were family outings enjoyed their privileged and mostly didn't fight the system on principle, or religion, or any other basis. My parents didn't use racial slurs, but they never entertained a person of color in their home until I had all my female classmates over for a party in sixth grade. 
 It's a lovely story, but it's just another fantasy covering over the ugly truth of casual, unthinking prejudice, and I'm old enough to know that all the injustice wasn't left in the past of the story.

Five Stars. Again. This is my fourth time reading this book and my first time listening to it in audio. Sissy Spacek also gets five stars for her narration of this timeless classic. It was absolutely phenomenal. 
 Now onto Go Set A Watchman - of which I am hearing disturbingly mixed reviews. . .
This is my favorite book of all time! I re-read it every few years and get something new from it every time. Love it, love it, love it!!!

After all these years, this is still my favourite book. I even studied it for GCSE and still loved it afterwards which I'm sure says something! By having the serious issue of racial prejudice discussed through the protagonist re-telling this part of her childhood gives a different take on the issue.

There is not much you can say about a book like this. 
 I haven't read it in school as I'm not American, but i get why it is sort of mandatory for a student in the states. It teaches not only about the sad history but still holds valuable things to learn no matter which time you live in.
Yep, everything everybody has ever said about this was true. It didn't make me cry though.

When I first read the book I expected that there would be judges, court and lawyers from the very beginning given its reputation. But no, the story is being told through the point of view of a little girl. Ahh, what can I say about this book other than perfect! This Audiobook version is just awesome, really the best.
that was nice
This is an everyone-must-read-once-in-their-lives type of book. We had to read it for our English Lit classes in high school, and I'm so glad we did.

4.5 stars 
 Through the mind of our six year old protagonist 'To Kill A Mockingbird' is the story of a little town called Maycomb, relaying the prejudice and injustice that prevails. Sewn in this tale is the eccentrics of the town people and the endearing relations Scout has with them. Thought-provoking as well as heart-tugging, it is the classic everyone deems it to be 
 It is the book that is on everyone's favourite bookshelf, the book they rave about, the book they exclaim when I say I haven't read it and it is also my mother's favourite book. So thus it is with a load of expectation that I started the book, a load much heavier than the text of the book. 
 Had the book been exactly what I had been expecting I would have probably been disappointed. But it suprised me with the chapters solely devoted to the lives and mayhem the kids cause over summer and their school experiences. This brought me closer to the characters. 
 My mother was probably watching me like a hawk while reading it, and every time she asked me how I like it so far? I would say it's nice and ask when the whole court scene is gonna happen. She would say a long time after. So it is when I stopped waiting for some eye-opener that I began to enjoy this simple story. 
 The court scene was everything it was built up for. And once I stopped flinching every-time I read the N word, I throughly enjoyed it. 
 I fell in love with all the characters, they seemed so very real. 
 The 0.5 stars reduction is not the fault of the book, it is the brunt of the expectations load still looming over.
It's easy to see why people keep reading this book.

Decided to re-read this after seeing a documentary on Harper Lee. I hadn't read it since high school and really had forgotten a lot of the details. Nice to go back and remember, especially the great characters of Scout, Atticus and Boo Radley. 
 "Atticus, he was real nice." ... 
 "Most people are when you really see them."

Some people really love this book and while i love the innocent character of Scout, i really did not enjoy the book. The story was very slow for me and when the court scene came and i finally began to read the novel with interest, i soon found it to be over in a matter of pages. If anything the "Court Scene",a much later chapter in the novel, is the only gripping, intriguing and suspenseful scene. Its a classic so its worth a read but, not one of my favorite books.
Loved this book. I took my time with it and looked forward to the time with these characters every day! Loved Scout as a narrator and want Atticus as a father!
This is one of the best books I have ever read.

One of the books well-meaning adults expect schoolchildren to read. I thought it went nowhere when I saw the movie made of it. I thought the book less enlightening. The rumour is that Truman Capote actually wrote this. I have never read any of his attributed work, so I can't say what that implies...It's okay, sentence by sentence, it's not a bad read, but it just doesn't deliver a denouement that really thrills.

Perhaps one of the few cases of a movie being superior to the book. It's a little disjointedly episodic but the characters are endearing. I really enjoy the perspective of the adult retelling her childhood. And the messages might be obvious but they are still good ones.
I was supposed to love Scout maybe, and definitely Jem, but I fell in love with Atticus instead.

This book isn't too bad! It was my literature text for my second year of high school, and possibly the only literature text that I like. Harper Lee is just so amazingly funny. The way she puts herself in a young girl's shoes and the way she portrays the emotions of that same girl so vividly is so captivating. The only reason why I don't like it is because I scored terribly for my essay on the text. 
 Anyhow, this book has really deep themes, causing me to pause and reflect on my (rather short) life. It's extremely inspiring and I recommend it to everyone. (Sorry, I know this review is pretty much on-the-surface, but it's quite hard to give a review on a literature text which you've studied for half a year. It's just that you don't know what to write.)

I don't think there's anything I can say about this novel that hasn't already been said, so this will be short and sweet. I didn't read this in high school like so many others, but I'm glad I didn't. I think I appreciated this much more at 22 than I would have at 16. TKAM is an amazing and important novel and is one that everyone should at least attempt to read one in their life.

This is probably the first book that I read for school and enjoyed, even a little bit. The thing that sticks with me since then is the idea of narrating a story about a heavy topic from the point of view of a child. I really like how that was done.
I first read this book in high school. Growing up in the rural south, i felt i shared something integral with Scout-- the task of learning to overcome racism. This book is beautiful and peaceful.
A great read.. I really enjoyed this book because although it was written so long ago, everyone can relate to how the world just isn't fair sometimes. This one is definitely on my MUST-HAVE list.
28/5/16: I am so mad at myself for not being able to focus on the story. I have exams approaching FAST and they're damn important. I WILL pick it up again. I am at bare 5% into the book.

There's nothing really new for me to say about this book. It's one of the American classics and it's mandatory reading in high-school. There's 70000 written reviews about this book on Goodreads alone. Another review would just be a drop in the bucket, so most of all I'm going to put down my thoughts for my own future self to refer to. 
 "To Kill a Mockingbird" wasn't something I'd read in my school (I'm not in the US), but heard mentioned time and again, it being regarded as one of the greatest novels of all time and all that. In my effort to beat my 2017 reading challenge, I took on this book at long last. 
 I honestly didn't know much about the actual story and genre of TKaM and was pleasantly surprised to find out it's all set in Depression Era USA. I'd previously read and loved Gone with the Wind, and also East of Eden. There's something inherently interesting to me about this time period and place. 
 In TKaM, you follow two years of childhood life of little Jean-Louise "Scout" Finch, who lives with her 4 year older brother Jeremy and dad Atticus who is a lawyer. I didn't know where the story would lead for the entire first half, as it had such a slice-of-life kind of flow. Scout talks about one minor event after the other. Stuff like how she, her brother and close friend would reenact stories from books or get into trouble with her teacher on the first day of school. 
 Throughout that first half, there's a building up of the mystery of a certain "Boo" Radley, a neighbor who stayed in his house and was never seen. The mystery and small-town-creepiness feeling was very strong and you'd get really into the head of a small child. You remember when you were a kid and the littlest things could take on huge significance in your impressionable mind? That's exactly how I felt reading TKaM and that's a testament to the strength of Harper Lees writing. Even though the mystery was probably nothing much in actuality, it evoked a constant sense of dread while reading. I half-expected TKaM to be the typical (or original?) story of a peaceful small town hiding a sinister secret under its idyllic veneer. 
 There's also something about viewing the world from the POV of an intelligent child that's always interesting, something I found when reading Ender's Game for example. It's a great tool for elegantly exposing the idiocy of most adults without being preachy. 
 I was pleasantly surprised when in the second half it turns out that TKaM was actually more about the ugliness that stares society square in the face all the time - racism and adult hypocrisy. It is here that the character of Atticus Finch really shines. Atticus is a great parent, one who not only preaches a good message (always be kind to others, etc) but who actively practices it. He places his trust in his children and doesn't patronize them. That's very much in contrast to parents you see in life all the time who think they're being kind and loving when they're actually soft and weak about guiding their children, but I digress. 
 Atticus becomes more and more impressive a character who just drops truth-bombs and deep wisdom on his kids that are truly important to think about for the readers, not just the children. I realized that the point of the story wasn't the Radley mystery, the courtroom drama or the final incident, but the conduct and philosophy of Atticus Finch throughout the story. He is not unfailing, if you wondered about that, but just a man who tries his best all of the time considering the circumstances and that's more than you can say of 90% of people in real life. TKaM then is a book about inspiring people to think more and be more courageous, and that's why it is such an important novel, a timeless classic chock-full of lessons for people everywhere. 
 I'll just include a wonderful little paragraph: 
 "Lemme tell you somethin' now, Billy," a third said, "you know the court appointed him to defend this nigger." 
 "Yeah, but Atticus aims to defend him. That's what I don't like about it." 
 This was news, news that put a different light on things: Atticus had to, whether he wanted to or not. I thought it odd that he hadn't said anything to us about it--we could have used it many times in defending him and ourselves. He had to, that's why he was doing it, equaled fewer fights and less fussing. But did that explain the town's attitude? The court appointed Atticus to defend him. Atticus aimed to defend him. That's what they didn't like about it. It was confusing.
Read this for my grade 10 English class. I connected to it immediately and its impact will always be with me for the rest of my life.
Even named my cat "Boo" :)

8/30/15 I gained an incredible amount of depth and nuance from re-reading this book as a minority member of American society with African-American friends and neighbors and co-workers, with firsthand experience now of their culture and struggles, as opposed to my first encounter with To Kill A Mockingbird when I was a 13 year-old member of an Asian majority. Back then I thought this was an amazing book about injustice and prejudice and how to handle oneself with grace: now the pain that underpins the novel is no longer an abstract. To Kill A Mockingbird is an impassioned plea for social justice, self-reflection and kindness, and I'm almost afraid to read Go Set A Watchman now (tho I'm sure my Ingress bookclub will help carry me through!)

what a beautiful story. I can't believe it's taken me so long to read this one. I'm so glad I picked it up. 
 A story of love and friendship and growing up. What an incredible father. And a true story of racism and prejudice. Incredibly written. 
 It's the kind of book that changes you.
Read it as a class text in year 8, and frankly didn't like it all that much. It's not a bad book, and it had a deep message (plus the characters were sketched out really well). Just not my thing.

I knew eventually i would need to read this books, so i did early, and i fell in love. What a wonderful story that I couldn't put down. It's a book that either you hate or love and i'm absolutely #2 You have to dig deep to find the stories true meaning and I will always have a special place in my heart for this book, even if it's not normally a book i would read, nor like. I thoroughly enjoyed it.

So I read this book in high school, as most people do. 
 And I really did love it. It was one of the few books that I studied in school and still liked by the end of the term, although having to study it took some of the enjoyment out of it, for me. 
 Scout is a wonderful narrator. And Atticus Finch is such a wonderful character name, and god damn I wish I had thought of it. I think I'll be jealous of that (in the best way) for the rest of my life. 
 This book, though. It's a very humble little book, that did many great things. I would love to reread this book because I know there are a lot of subtleties in it, and I'd love to experience those again and maybe pick up on something new. This book builds very quietly, but it's a fantastic, very neat little piece of literature and it should never go out of print. 
 If you haven't read it because you didn't get to it in school and you've been putting it off for whatever reason - now is your chance because there's a sequel coming out, and that's awesome as well. I am excited for that! 
 ... EDIT: I just reread the book, and, like a lot of other people rereading it, I encountered so much I had forgotten and fell in love with it all over again. I cried a lot more than I thought I would and found it an absolutely worthwhile reread. It's so cool to be rereading this book along with a bunch of other likeminded people who are all also keen to check out the sequel. 
 It was nice to be back in Maycomb County, I love Harper Lee's writing, and I can't wait to read Go Set a Watchman. 
 YET ANOTHER EDIT: 
 After seeing some reviews of this book, and of the sequel (or prequel?) Go Set a Watchman, I've begun to rethink my relationship with it. 
 I see now, that Harper Lee, while addressing racism in a wonderful way through the perspectives of children, does, to a degree, silence the struggle, the strength and the resistance black people had in that time in towns like Maycomb County. This story, like a lot of others, falls prey to a lot of racist micro-aggressions that we all fall prey to, to this day. 
 The characters are well-written, and it's a powerful story, but I feel like this book would be a lot more powerful if we heard parts of the story from Tom Robinson's or Cal's perspective. Atticus Finch himself admits that he is not a radical man and while positioned as a good lawyer, isn't necessarily a good person, willing to change the structure of the town. 
 (There's more on him over here that I greatly agree with. http://academicfeminist.tumblr.com/po...) 
 Scout and Jem Finch are uncomfortable with racism and so perhaps they will be the first to change the way society works in Maycomb County. This is a well-written story, as I said, and I am grateful that Lee wrote it, with all the challenges she must've faced writing it, and getting it published. 
 That said, I cannot, in my heart, hold this book up on a pedestal as the be all and end all of atypical books that combat racism. I need to read more Alice Walker, more Toni Morrison, more James Baldwin, Chimamanda Ngozi Adichie, Maya Angelou, Roxane Gay, Octavia E. Butler, Zora Neale Hurtson, Angela Davis, Gloria Naylor, Jacqueline Woodson, Richard Wright, Langston Hughes and so, so, so many more authors who spoke directly to the black experience and to marginalised people everywhere, looking for hope. 
 I think this is a good book, but, much like Nabokov's Lolita, I think the message got a little lost in translation. 
 And I will read the second book. It just might be a while. I hope I have articulated my point well enough to not be hurtful to anyone (especially Lee herself), and if you have any recommendations for me, please let me know.
I only recently read this book and loved it! Still timely.

I loved this book! Scout and Jem are great main characters and you see them grow and mature as they get older. Atticus Finch is a great person and you really learn a lot about the time period. The story is interesting and enticing. There are funny moments and sad ones. Overall this book was amazing and I truly think that this book is the best book of American Literature.

How did I miss reading this one in my youth? Unfortunately relevant today as it was back then.

I don't remember when I first read this. High school I think, 9th grade probably. Far enough back that I think I missed some of the humor, and all of the spunk in Scout's character. Reading it now brings back memories of summer days, where time was seemingly endless in its plodding, and the humid heat necessitated escape via swimming pools and lemonade. The south of my childhood was considerably less fraught with issues than in those years between 1930-1960, but it's obvious remnants of the civil rights issues are (frustratingly, heartbreakingly) present and relevant today. 
 Harper Lee captures so much about small town rural America in those years. The flaws and social issues, not just between races, but gender inequality, the reality of poverty and education shortcomings as well. This fits with stories my dad told me from his youth on a rural Georgia farm- where racism was simply a part of every day life, where crosses burned on the hill across from his house some nights, and people looked the other way. Where high schools were segregated and alcoholism lived side by side with church on Sundays. 
 This is a story that's aged gracefully in the 50(-ish) years since its been written. Maybe at some point within the next 50 years we'll be lucky enough to consider its issues obsolete and a memoir to a time long forgotten. One can always dream.
Hard to read but got more and more gripping towards the end.

This book has it all, from funny, to meaningful; morose at times and joyful at others. One thing is, its not a light read. While reading this book I found myself, keeping it down for a while and thinking about something that Scout, Jem or Atticus would have said; which in itself is an achievement for usually I can't wait to get to the end. 
 One line in particular has stuck with me is a Atticus telling his son, Jem 'You never really understand a person until you consider things from his point of view... Until you climb into their skin and walk around in it.' 
 The book has a deceptively simple narrative. It is story told by a 9 year old girl about life with her father(a Lawyer) and her brother, Jim. The kids, grow up, trying to understand people and their various quirks. 
 Although the main theme is racism, apathy and hypocrisy, it comes across as much more than that. It is a story of a father trying to raise his children without any kind of prejudice; a story that shows not everyone is good, but that doesn't mean we have to hate them. We just need to understand them a little better. 
 Atticus has become one of my favourite character now. His wisdom and odd ways makes him so endearing and I just had to let him adopt me as his daughter. He becomes the epitome of empathy and bravery. He is also a man, who would not be browbeaten and stands up against almost everyone in town for what he believes is an injustice. He shows braveness is a measure of character than about how many fights you pick. 
 Overall, I'd give the author a big whooping FIVE for her characters, prose, plot and especially for her not so happy ending.
Studying it in class killed it for me. I don't think I was ready for it as a fifteen year old, and analyzing a book is just like dissecting an animal. It's dead after you're done.

My review in August '10...The last time I read this book I gave it two stars. Today it gets four five. 
 When I first (?) read this book ten years ago I didn't care for it. (Yes, I do know that the idea is heresy.) It's not a YA book and I was reading it to be taught to poor and non-readers in ninth grade. (I wasn't teaching the class; I have taught Kindred by Octavia Butler on racism instead, among others.) 
 Oh, I like the movie, but the book meanders around to spend chapters on Miss Maudie, Miss Stephanie, Mrs. Dubose, people who are entirely tangential to the primary plot. I would have preferred this as a short story or novella, instead of a novel. I've requested the play from the library, if it's a more straightforward telling of the story and I assume it is, I'll direct it next year. 
 Instead of Atticus Finch's children's POV, I would have preferred this book was told from Tom Robinson's children. But fifty years ago that book wouldn't have changed society as this one did. This book laid the way for the Civil Rights Act, probably helped to integrate schools as much as Brown, and has made our society more fair and equal. I'm leading a discussion of the book next week at the library, in part, as a response to my Village's ex-mayor and still Supervisor's racist words. And, like those men, many of the people in this novel use the n-word casually and that also makes this a difficult read. My thoughts are not terribly coherent yet on this book, and for that I apologize. 
 My thoughts on the book in April '11... 
 I saw things in this fourth or fifth reading I'd forgotten or overlooked. Reading it as a supplement to the play, while directing the play is a huge help. It's a Cunningham family member who is on the jury and keeps it out so long. I am again glad that in the play Atticus doesn't call Mrs. Dubose the bravest person he's ever known. But knowing that Mr. Underwood had his shotgun out during the mob scene makes Atticus seem more prepared.

When you know the story of a novel and you still enjoy reading the book so much that it keeps you awake after midnight, it's a sure sign that the novel is an entertaining read. 
 I liked that the book used the little girl's point of view, and also liked that it avoided sentimentalism and used a realistic and detached tone. 
 I listened to the audio-book, narrated masterfully by Sissy Spacek.

Atticus Finch, Scout and Jem are expertly portrayed by Lee, encompassing integrity, compassion, curiosity and the balance between innocence and knowing. 
 This is my favourite book of all time. 
 Atticus makes me want to be a better father. Jem makes me revisit my childhood with a smile, and Scout encourages me to look at my own children with hope.

I will say this right up front: I am incapable of reviewing this book for several reasons, but especially these two: 1. It is that good. 2. Thousands of others have reviewed it before me -- including analyses, quotes, descriptions and opinions. All of which are saying exactly what I should say. So, instead I will share one thought and I will review the narrator of the audio book I listened to, Sissy Spacek. 
 I loved this book. I read it a few years ago when my older son was reading it in 9th grade. And I listened to it again last week. It is a deeply moving and often troubling story. It is full of thought and heart. It is a coming of age story of a girl in the deep South who is surrounded by the vile world of prejudice, but who is raised by an open-minded and open-hearted father. The messages and themes of this book are many... all of them important. It is a book that will linger in your thoughts. It is a book that will touch your heart. And it is a book that everyone should read. Once. More than once is even better! 
 This quote shares the message that I may like best. "I have always believed, and I still believe, that whatever good or bad fortune may come our way we can always give it meaning and transform it into something of value." 
 Sissy Spacek brought this book to life. Her narration was so perfect that it made the book even better than it already was. Nobody else should ever read this book as they will not do it the same justice. Superb!

Straight up, this is a classic even among classics, and so I'm giving myself permission right up front for this review not to be important or add anything to the conversation at all. I don't actually think I'm capable of saying anything that hasn't already been said by people who said it better than I ever could. I feel like the only way this book can be reviewed now is either by looking at it through the context of today's societal lens, or by relating it to the reader's personal experience. I'm going to take the latter route, and even then, I'm going to keep it brief because words are wind and carry no meaning. 
 Well, that last part I'm sort of being facetious about (I am a writer writing things, this, for example), but I feel it's true in this case. Too much stuff to pack into one review. 
 I have now read this book three times: 
 Once in the eighth grade. We read it out loud in class. I remember knowing it was an important book at the time. I also remembering not really understanding why it was important. Everything in it seemed pretty obvious to me. My general reaction was along the lines of 'Hey this is a thing, moving on now.' 
 Once ten years ago. I was gobsmacked at my earlier self's reaction. This was a really good book! This was one of my earliest memories of re-experiencing literature as an adult, and one of the main reasons I'm bent on re-reading classics I read as a teenager when I was too young to appreciate them. 
 And now, when I am convinced this is one of the finest books ever written. It's simple and straightforward, yet it packs a mean punch. And at its core are things that have (sadly) only gotten more relevant with time. 
 My biggest takeaway this time is that the book is also more complex than I remembered. It's not A BOOK ABOUT RACE, although that is part of it. It's more like the racism is a symptom of a larger problem: a lack of empathy, a loss of innocence, where innocence is the ability to see past socially constructed boundaries, and human compassion is the exception not the rule. That's why Scout is the narrator, and Jem is the key to the story. At the beginning of the novel, Jem is like Scout, thinking "folks is just folks," and by the end he's sad and bitter, and trying to work out in his head how it is that if folks are just folks, how the world can be the way it is. And how he has to learn to become like his father Atticus, a man who sees how people behave in groups, how they adhere so rigidly to how things are instead of how they should be, and who still believes that most people are nice "when you finally see them." All of these are sentiments I was completely unable to appreciate as a still-innocent, completely idealistic pre-teen. And even on my second read, I didn't have enought life experience to really get it. 
 This is going to be one of those books, like Lord of the Rings, that I bust out every ten years and marvel anew how good it is, and fall in love with the more I read it. I'm cautiously excited for Go Set a Watchman this summer, despite the controversy. Even if it turns out to be a dud, though, we'll always have Mockingbird.

I first discovered this classic read when I was a high school student, when one of my professors had it as recommended reading for one of our courses. So I had kept a copy of this book for years. (I never put my hands on the pages of this book again not until recently after watching the "Perks of being a Wallflower" movie where this has been a favorite book of the main character. :D) After looking through it again, I can honestly say that "To Kill a Mockingbird" is one of the best books of all time. 
 Since then, this book has always been one of my favorite novels. The story brings up issues of racism through the eyes of a child, and that was something I had never read before. Sure, I always find Tom Robinson's trial riveting, and the mystery of Boo Radley constantly intrigues me - and that will never change. And whenever I recall the story, I can't help but admire Atticus Finch as a father. He never has a bad word to say about anyone and leads by example. It's easy to talk a good game, but his actions show that he is a compassionate, caring and conscientious person. He also has a fantastic relationship with his children, Scout and Jem, and treats them with respect. 
 The conclusion? Well, there is so much to admire and enjoy in this book. I can say that this novel that will always be close to my heart.

An absolutely amazing book. 
 The description of serious matters as rape and racism through the eyes of a child can easily seem hackneyed, but somehow, it didn't. Rather, the vividness of these, juxtaposed with the early childhood innocence, created a magical feeling. This compelled me to rate this as nothing less than a classic. 
 The suspense between hope and broken promises, the clash between Scout's innocence and Ewell's unscrupulousness pushes the plot forward - there was barely a boring moment - all without invoking the adrenaline induced excitement. 
 Recommended to anyone, of any taste and any age.
A classic I enjoyed in high school and I enjoyed it just as much this time around.

The first half of the book introduces us to a number of interesting characters and provides us with a detailed setting of Maycomb. About halfway the journey the book gets to its core and brings about its message gradually. 
 To Kill a Mockingbird is a tender coming-of-age story that is told in the eyes of a boyish girl. Revolving around Tom Robinson's case, it is also about racial discrimination and justice. There are so many lessons to be learned from this classic considered one of The Great American Novels.

Read this one aloud with Isabel. It is on the list for the middle school Battle of the Books. I haven't read it in quite a while and found it hard to read out loud. It was interesting how many of the ideas are similar, but also how I can see so many characters caught in their time period.
A wonderful classic that everyone should read once in their lives!

I thought this was going to be a reread. When we decided to pick To Kill a Mockingbird for my book club, I thought "Good, I haven't read it in ages!". But when I started reading it, I quickly realised that I actually never had before. I might have watched the film, and I have certainly read many a discussion about it, but this was my first proper read of the book, and it was an interesting experience. 
 I read it in May, long before Go Set A Watchman came out, and intended to post a review before then. I made my usual disjointed notes as soon as I finished it, but then I hit a really busy patch in the last few months and all blogging went out the window. It would be pretty much impossible to write a review now that's not coloured by what I've heard about Watchman, so what I'll do is to simply copy those few notes (with some minor edits for grammar and readability -they really were disjointed!) below and be done with it: 
 - I didn't expect the humour. There were scenes that had me laughing out loud, like Scout's first teacher and the ladies' tea party. 
 - The characters, even many of the secondary ones, are so well-realised that I could see the events in this book being written from several points of view. The story would then be about something else, though. Which might not be a bad thing... 
 - From all I knew about it, I expected the book to be about Tom Robinson's case and the trial. It wasn't. It was about Scout and Jem growing up and understanding the world they're living in. Tom Robinson's story was unimportant, other than as an example of injustice. The whole point of it was to be the catalyst for Scout and Jem's coming of age. Very uncomfortable about that. Feels like when the whole point of a disabled character is to change the life of the able-bodied protagonist, that sort of thing. 
 - This reminded me of Lean In, in that it seems to be all about learning to live in a fundamentally unfair, imperfect system and how to manipulate it to get a little bit of justice. I lost a lot of respect for Atticus for seeing enough value in the system to want to continue living in it, to think it was worth the effort. Probably immature of me. I wanted him to want to change the system. I wanted him to recognise that a system that works as his society did has no value. I wanted him to want to say "fuck the system" and want to tear it down and burn it to pieces. Because that society? That's what should have happened to it. And someone who would be part of a lynch mob is not "basically a good man", just with some blind spots. I found that attitude really troubling. 
 MY GRADE: It feels like sacrilege, but although I recognise how good a writer Lee was and I enjoyed the story while I was reading it, too much about it bothered me. It was a B for me.

I think I'll always appreciate To Kill a Mockingbird. It has a large number of life lessons worthy of real life application. I've read it twice and if I were to read it again, I think it would only get better. Thank you Harper Lee!

You know the story; I know the story. So spoilers be damned! 
 For a long time now, To Kill a Mockingbird has been one of the most glaring omissions of my reading life. Everybody but me seems to have read it and loved it. So I'm glad I've finally checked it off. 
 For the first twenty or thirty pages, I was quite impressed. The prose was warm and lively; the characters, well-realized and likable. The episodic quality of the plot did bore me a little, but the opening scenes were, for the most part, charming. 
 But the more I read, the less I enjoyed. Until the Tom Robinson trial, nothing propelled me forward. The characters are simple enough to understand in two pages, and nothing exciting happens in their young lives. So when people finally started giving Jem and Scout trouble about the Tom Robinson case, I was pleased. Finally, some direction. 
 This, however, is when the book went from charming to nauseating for me. I fear that my criticism will not be pleasing to many; but if there's one place in the world to express your honest opinions about a book, it's a Goodreads review. 
 It comes down to this: To Kill a Mockingbird is a boring book. And I don't say that because "nothing cool happens," but because the book doesn't make the reader think. Rather, it lulls the reader's intellect to sleep; its appeal is to the heart only--and even then, to the most childish feelings of the heart. 
 Consider the moral universe of To Kill a Mockingbird. It is a world populated by good folks and bad folks. There are no in-between folks. In other words, there are no people. 
 Take Atticus Finch--the hero. The only fictional hero that can rival good ol' Atticus for lack of emotional complexity is Superman. Sure, he's a memorable character; but so are Santa Clause and Bugs Bunny. The reader never understands why Atticus is so righteous, or where he gets his inner strength. Atticus is so upstanding it's impossible even to admire him. I admire Martin Luther King, Jr. because I know that the man must have suffered many crippling moments of doubt and desperation. But Atticus always keeps his cool, always knows what to do, always wants to do the right thing. He's as interesting as a bowl of plain oatmeal. 
 Tom Robinson is even worse. He's the stereotype of the kind-hearted, innocent "Negro" who don't want no trouble from no White Folks. He could have been plucked right from the pages of Uncle Tom's Cabin (a book I disliked even more than this one). He couldn't be more two-dimensional if he was a stick figure; he doesn't even reach the status of caricature. That Harper Lee chose to make the book's one tragic figure such a stock character is beyond me. What reader is heartbroken by his death? (This is not to mention that the way Harper Lee kills him off is clumsy and contrived.) 
 I think the main reason this books fails is that it attempts to tackle grown-up issues from the perspective of a naive child. As a result, the solution it offers to the problems of the world--which, in Lee's opinion, could be summed up as "why people got to be so mean to each other?"--is sickly-sweet sentimentality. In fact, the solution to the questions of racism, oppression, rape, deceit, murder, and all of the other evils of the world, is exactly what a child would give: "Why can't everyone just be more like my paw?"
I am so glad that I read it again. I am in love with this book!

August 1, 2013 - third read - Like meeting up with an old friend. 
 May 27, 2011 - I first read this in 8th grade. Nearly 20 years (and numerous books) later, time has messed with my memory enough to make this second read through feel like the first. I remember really liking it back then. This time though, I'm IN LOVE.
Third time around (after reading in high school and while on a camping trip six or seven years ago). This time for the library book group.

This is an exceptional piece of literature that anyone and everyone can enjoy. I love it just as much now, or maybe even more so, as I did when I read it for the first time in middle school. This book is about the town of Maycomb, Alabama, where a father, Atticus Finch, a local attorney, is assigned by the local court to represent a black man who has allegedly raped a white woman. The narrator, Scout Finch, explains the hardships they had to deal with during this situation. As this novel is set during the Civil Rights Movement, I think this would be an excellent choice to teach because it is also a history lesson as well as a classic tale of sadness, happiness, equality, immaturity and maturity, and injustice and redemption. In addition to that, we get to see a true hero in this novel, Atticus. Throughout their story, we see them struggle and yet continuously do what is right, regardless of how the other people in the town take it. 
 I look forward to the day when I am able to teach this to middle grades students. This will be a great book to introduce theme, symbolism, and motifs as literary devices. I think the themes especially are important lessons to learn from this story. I found that a great activity to do to help kids really connect to the story in their own way is to create a soundtrack involving songs and lyrics that are fitting to the story, characters, tone of a particular section of the book, etc. Also, to keep them engaged in the story, maybe we could do an activity where they choose a character from the story and write diary entries as if they are that character, also while collecting artifacts that the characters would keep and presenting their findings and diary entries. This novel provides excellent characterization which kids would find relatable and interesting. I believe in teaching this book, we will have very productive classes where the kids enjoy coming to class to discuss this novel. Hopefully they will enjoy this novel as much as I have. I see that this novel will greatly resonate with middle school readers. This book definitely has my recommendation and it will be one that I definitely teach one day.
It really was that amazing, one of the best books I've ever read in my life. I would give it ten stars if I could. And I'd probably sell my soul to be able to write like that.

I understand the historical significance of this book, but honestly I never liked it. Perhaps it was the child's point of view, or maybe the fact that it was a school assignment. I dunno. Just not my idea of a great book.

To Kill a Mockingbird is beautifully written and full of entertaining anecdotes and great lessons about the importance of acceptance and politeness. 
 What objections I have are not with the book itself, but with the Finch family as the Moral standard to which America should aspire. The Finches are good people, certainly by the standard of the time and place in which they lived, but they have clear (and likely intentional) moral flaws. They are unapologetically classist, and they are certainly racist. They are of course well intentioned, and their attitudes are certainly preferable to those of the sneering villains and gossiping housewives of the novel, but they are racist nonetheless, in more subtle ways that remind me of the struggles with racism that have dominated the news all too often in our own time. 
 It was fascinating reading this after reading reactions to Atticus' depiction in Go Set a Watchman. I have not read that book (which was apparently an earlier draft of this one), but I don't think Atticus growing more overtly racist in his old is inconsistent with the Atticus of TKaM. 
 Those objections aside, I was pleased with To Kill a Mockingbird as entertainment, and as a revealing depiction of growing up as a young girl in south in the 1930's.

So Goodreads tells me I added this to my to-read list in September 2008 but really, I've wanted to read this since I left high school. WHY DIDN'T I READ THIS SOONER? 
 I really loved this book, and its perfect narrator who made this story a bit magical in her own way. Scout draws you into her world, making you see things through a child's eyes and consequently making it impossible for me to put the book down.

I started this book last year but due to other distractions - school, exams, lack of attention at that time - I let my reading fall to the wayside. My reading of it was spaced out so I couldn't follow the story properly. I abandoned it until I could read it completely and enjoy it. 
 This book is astounding. Not only is it thought provoking and complex, it is also real and so simple. 
 One of my favourite themes in media is the innocence of children and their views - how it comes to our notice that society then shapes our prejudices and ill thought of inequality; children do not care in their naivete and innocent outlook. This book plays strongly on this theme. Its narrator, Scout, is a six-year-old at the beginning of this novel and is not even ten by its end, though she and her brother grow up, and some of that innocence is lost. 
 Throughout the story, the development (or should I say the destruction?) of the children's innocence is played out brilliantly by its believability. With all the fun, happy-go-lucky moments we read about there are also many melancholy moments that appear in the book as the children, and therefore we as readers, come to realisations and acceptances. One stand out point for me was Jem's realisation over Boo Radley wanting to stay indoors - 'it's because he wants to stay inside'. It comes to the cost of accepting what society itself is like. All this time Jem had thought Boo was kept inside because why wouldn't he want to be around people? But Jem accepts, after the trial of Tom Robinson, that it is because of people and how corruptive society can be. Jem's faith in humanity and justice is shaken. As he says himself, 'Why can't they get along with each other?' Many times throughout the book Scout talks of how Jem began to act older. As Jem is pretending to be grown up, it made the utter belief that Atticus would win the court case hurt all that more - because really he is still a child, still an innocent, still not aware how corrupt society really is. 
 Perhaps the scene where Scout cools off the mob at the jail by talking coolly, with innocent, out-of-place questions, is the most memorable for me. Here Scout, in her innocence, her youth, she reminds these men of humanity in their least humane moment, It also reminded me as I read the book that people who act out rashly and do horrible things are sometimes not evil or truly bad, but are capable of humane deeds and can be those normal, everyday folk who would usually be too polite to cause a fuss. 
 How much I recommend it: Anyone who enjoys the themes mentioned will adore this book and will love its message. If Boo Radley doesn't stay in your mind days after reading, if the final scene doesn't replay itself in your head, doesn't mean something to you... then I doubt you read the book. 
 A book like this makes you feel so deeply, ponder on its quotes, its references and the stories of its characters. It was a beautiful, emotional read that will stay with me for a very long time. Possibly forever, till my memory begins to fail me. It's a book that reminds you not to hate society or humans despite its faults, despite how it kills innocence and those who cause no harm. It teaches you to not do so, with its most famous line, 
 'Shoot all the bluejays you want, if you can hit 'em, but remember it's a sin to kill a mockingbird.'

"Well, most folks seem to think they're right and you're wrong..." 
 It took me a long time to read To Kill A Mockingbird, I tried years ago and gave up only because of a dislike of the font in my copy of it. I got over that now, or I forced myself to, and I'm glad I did. I found the book utterly charming. Painted from a child's perspective it puts a lot of focus on life from a 'simpler' world that one recognizes well (eavesdropping and sibling fights included)while the dramatic race-plot is for a long time nothing but a dark shadow that doesn't take center stage until the end. 
 The picture that Lee paints is not only beautiful and amusing but in the end also thought provoking. I think what you can get out of TKAM is little bit dependent on what you're searching for and how you view Scout and the time she lives in. All in all I think it's a book well worth reading but it almost feels as though it should be mandatory to partake in a book discussion about it when one does. 
 "They're certainly entitled to think that, they're entitled to full respect for their opinions," said Atticus, "but before I can live with other folks I've got to live with myself. The one thing that doesn't abide by majority rule is a persons conscience."

A must read, especially for young adults. I'm rating it 4 stars instead of 5 stars this time around not because I appreciate it any less but because I hadn't read Carson McCullers' The Heart is a Lonely Hunter nor any of Flannery O'Connor's short stories before I first read it.

I've read this book before but not in years, and there are a couple things that amazed me this go around. 
 The first Atticus determination to treat people with deep respect. Even people with whom he vehemently disagrees. Even people who viciously insult him or yell nasty things at his children. Even people about whom everyone else whispers and tells stories. 
 The second is how again and again Atticus reminds Scout that these people (the people he disagrees with, the people in different social standings) are "our friends." 
 It was a bit of a shock to the senses as I've become quick to outrage at other people's opinions and find myself thinking very unkindly (or just unfriending) people with whom I disagree on any sort of social network. And it's left me a lot to think about. What would an Atticus Finch say to today's gun politics? To racial issues? Women's issues? An increasingly globalized world? I don't know, but I'd like whatever I say about these matters to be said with his sense of humility and steadiness. 
 If you haven't read this book, or if it's been a while, do yourself a tremendous favor and read it.
Great story addressing family issues, especially with single parents, as well as racism/prejudice within a community

Somehow I managed to make it through the first thirty one years of my life without reading this book. I finally got around to reading it, and I can see why it is a classic. I loved it! 
 I don't have much to say about this book that hasn't already been said more eloquently by hundreds of other reviewers. So I will just say this: If you are like me and have managed to avoid this book your whole life, get yourself a copy and read it already!

This book was an assigned reading in my 9th grade Pre-Ap class. We started reading this in the fall and, despite being in a Pre-Ap classroom, all of the students seemed to read achingly slow. The teacher would make us take turns reading aloud--or he would read aloud himslef. Reading aloud, period, annoys me. For the majority of the time in class when the class was taking turns "popcorning" I would just read silently at my own pace. Whenever I was called to read I'd simply remark that I was ahead of that passage and my teacher would skip me. My irritation grew enough that during winter break I checked out my own copy of the book and read it on my own time. 
 I loved the book, and thought it wove an interesting and thought provoking stories. It was character driven and because of that the book seemed very realistic. It's hard to believe that Atticus Finch is simply a man woven out of author's words, printer's ink, and plain parchment. I would highly recommend this to everyone. Its a book that reminds us all that sometimes good doesn't always win and it presents us with the concept of "reasonable doubt". In fact, I heard many law students at my university are required to read this novel at one point or another. Great book, great read.

This is for me the perfect novel. It is a great story beautifully written with respected and memorable characters to dearly love and admire, to laugh at and with, to be surprised by and to learn from. The narrator, Jean Louise (Scout) Finch is a bright, precocious child who embraces life with open arms and innocently abandons the typical stereotype of a "proper Southern young lady". Maycomb, Alabama is typically framed as a small town in the Deep South in the 1930s fraught with all of the typical baggage and hypocrisy that comes with that setting. Published in 1960, this novel had to help in some manner to awaken a beginning sense of change, however small, from long held customs and practices, from assumptions and deeply ingrained prejudices. Yes, racism continues and is alive decades later in many forms and likely always will be, but the clearly cut boundaries of the pre-60s South which could in no way be crossed and the widely held assumptions of inequality throughout the nation founded on equality were clearly addressed head-on in this book. All who have loved it for 55 years and have read and reread and shared it with their children and grandchildren are better for having come to know Atticus Finch, an all time favorite character for me. We can only wish that there were more men and women with the convictions and "quiet heroism" of an Atticus Finch in our communities.

I absolutely understand why this is considered a classic. The father, Atticus Finch, reminds me so much of my own father in his sense of fairness and right vs. wrong. And I loved the POV of Scout. I'm so moved by this book!

I absolutely loved this book. It was a class assignment to read this and I obviously thought I'd hate it. To my surprise I could relate to this book a lot. Who knew a 16 year old could relate to a small town white girl in the 1930's. There isn't much to say about this book except that it is amazing and unfortunately the Tom Robinson plot remains relevant.
Outstanding narration by Sissy Spacek. Great story. I'd read it as a teen and had forgotten all the details. So glad to have tried the audiobook!

I read it 11 years ago, right on the cusp of high school. I remember I liked it but i'm sure I didn't understand it well enough since it hadn't really made an impression on me, or a desire to re-read it.
I enjoyed this book, but I think its significance is exaggerated. Maybe it had a bigger impact when it was first published.
Amazing. So engaging and beautifully paced to pull the reader along. I can't believe I've waited this long to read it. I love being in Scout's head so much. I just left it and I miss it already.

 I'm pretty sure in a previous blog I said that school has destroyed a million books for me, one of the key ones being To Kill A Mockingbird. In school, they'd analyse every little detail, force you to power read through books just to meticulously examine every turn of phrase of motif and ARRRGH. School ruined so many books for me, and I suppose it's time I read them off my own back, and in the case of this I'm really glad I did. 
 This is one of my best friend's favourite books. It's such a good book (not that anyone needing telling) and it reminds me why I disliked school's approach to English. It's another reason I didn't take the subject at University. I couldn't handle more books being destroyed in this way. I liked being able to read this book without a teacher moaning that I wasn't reading fast enough, or being told to explain some minute turn of phrase or imagery. Ironically, I read it all in less than a day. I'm pretty sure my English teacher would have been overjoyed if I took to it so well back in school. So the lesson today is: I should re-read any books school destroyed because chances are they're actually great.

Told from the perspective of young Scout, the story focuses on the key events of her childhood. Along with her older brother Jem and their friend Dill, they try to find out about mysterious reclusive neighbor Boo Radley. Raised by their widower father, Atticus, they also remember the summer of his most important case, defending a wrongfully accused African-American of raping a white girl. 
 Interspersed with these larger stories are other random vignettes from childhood, including summertime and school tales and a surprising account of their father shooting a rabid dog in the street at the request of the sheriff. Through it all, the deep-rooted fairness and tolerance that Atticus displays in his unorthodox approach to parenting, especially in that era, consistently shines through.

So here's my former dirty secret. I haven't read this book before. It wasn't required reading in any of my classes, ever. 
 But it is no longer my dirty secret because I've read it now. 
 So what to say about the book? 
 There is a reason that despite its Mockingbird is still popular today. Part of it has to do with Scout and Jem. The two children are children. They are not stupid, but they are not super duper smarty pants either. They don't understand everything, and this is particularly true of Scout who tells the reader things that the reader grasps quicker than she does. Lee doesn't use them as bludgeon you to death avatars. 
 And because she doesn't do that the book works brilliantly. And Scout, well, Scout is the right kind of girl. 
 But it isn't about that, at least not entirely, and it's not entirely about race (and quite, frankly whoever thinks this book is racist needs to be smacked until Sunday) because the book is about perceptions and truth. 
 And it doesn't get more timeless than that.

One word. Beautiful. 
 Read it. Read it again.
That boy might go to the chair, but he's not going till the truth's told. And you know what the truth is.

I first read this at twelve. In those days, it was on no reading list--I suspect the subject matter was considered inappropriate. I checked it out from the library. And indeed, I couldn't figure out what the trial was about, except I got the gist: the black man was being unfairly accused just because of his color. 
 I identified hard with Scout. I cried at the end without knowing why I was crying--I was too ignorant to sense Scout's end of innocence. But the book stayed with me, of course, as the good ones do. 
 In later years I read it with both my kids, and it was interesting to read it as an adult, as well as see the story through a girl's eyes then a boy's. The story took on so many layers; we talked a lot about it, about the early sixties and the civil unrest, what it was like when kids from inner city L.A. were bussed to the overcrowded schools. 
 I never believed Truman Capote wrote it--I never saw the compassion in his writing that Lee exhibits here--though his lapidary eye for prose might have been employed in helping her edit. I dunno, that's a guess.

 5***** and a 
 Is this the quintessential American Novel? Will it stand the test of time as Mark Twain's The Adventures of Huckleberry Finn has done? Time will tell. 
 I do know this, however. This is a singularly powerful novel that had a great impact on me when I first read it at age 13 (shortly after it was first published), and has never failed to move and inspire me as I've re-read it over the years (at least 20 times by now). It has touched generations of readers in the 50-something years since it was first released, and remains high on many "must be read" lists. 
 There are many reasons for this. It's a well-paced novel, a fast read with elements of suspense, family drama, humor and moral lessons. Scout is a wonderful narrator, both as a child and as an adult looking back on her childhood; and the fact that Lee was able to seamlessly move between these two viewpoints is a testament to her skill as a writer. 
 Many people feel this is a book about racism. I don't think that is the core theme of the book, though it is the central plot device Lee uses. I think the major theme of the novel is personal integrity and courage - doing what you know is right when all about you seemingly disagree and even when it may be dangerous to do so, being true to your own moral compass, and instilling those values in your children by example not just words. 
 In this respect Atticus Finch shines as the protagonist of this work. He is a man of strong moral fiber, a man who is "the same in his house as he is on the public street," a man "who was born to do our unpleasant jobs for us." He embodies the lessons he tries to impart to his children: that courage is not a man with a gun in his hands but rather, "It's when you know you're licked before you begin but you begin anyway and you see it through no matter what." 
 The novel aims a spotlight on a particular time and place in America's history. Lee writes with clarity and colors this world for the reader with descriptions that put us squarely in Maycomb, Alabama circa 1935: Somehow it was hotter then: a black dog suffered on a summer's day; bony mules hitched to Hoover carts flicked flies in the sweltering shade of the live oaks on the square. Men's stiff collars wilted by nine in the morning. Ladies bathed before noon, after their three-o'clock naps, and by nightfall were like soft teacakes with frostings of sweat and sweet talcum." 
 The minor characters, especially the women, are as richly drawn as the major players. I was struck by what a wide range of personalities, strengths, weaknesses and ethics Lee was able to express using characters such as Calpurnia, Aunt Alexandra, Helen Robinson, Mrs Merriweather, Lula, Miss Maudie, Mrs Dubose, Miss Caroline and Mayella Ewell. Some of them appear for only a page or two, but they come alive on the page and remain in the reader's memories. 
 The audio book is performed by Academy-Award-winning actress Sissy Spacek. She does an admirable job, though her accent is wrong. She is a Texan, and the Southern Alabama accent is softer than her twang. Still, by the second disc I had stopped noticing this, and allowed myself to be carried into the story by her expert reading. 
 ******* 
 NOTE: The above is a fresh re-write in July 2015; compiled from notes I've taken over several re-reads: May 1998, July 2004, 14Aug2010, 22Oct2011, 07July 2013, 13July 2015

Strangely enough, this is the first time I've read this book. Unlike many teenagers, this was not a required text for my English Literature class at school. You know what? I feel mighty ripped off. The English class read this book, but apparently the Literature class (which I was only in because it 'balanced' my ratio of Humanities to Science) was too cool for this book. (We read Patrick White, which does not compare and completely turned me off his works). 
 Oh how wrong. This is a fantastic, captivating, interesting and dramatic piece of LITERATURE. Take that high school! 
 The premise is simple - Scout (real name Jean Louise) and Jem (Jeremy) are the children of one of the most underrated heroes of literature, Atticus Finch. Atticus is a local lawyer in Maycomb, called on to represent a black man charged with raping a white woman. The book captures the essence of 1930s Alabama in a way that so few books do - right down to manners, social conventions and racism. The book simmers with undertones - how the different races act towards each other, how the different classes act, how 'different' people are treated (such as Boo Radley, who appears to have a mental illness) and how it doesn't make sense to children such as Scout and Jem. 
 Scout is the first person narrator. It is told with her looking back at the events that unfolded starting with the summer before she started school and culminating several years later. With the wisdom of age, Scout adopts a more mature tone and thought process than for example, Jack from Room. But it also allows us to see the racism and prejudice going on through her innocent eyes. 
 Scout is a tomboy, who prefers overalls to dresses and solves fights with fisticuffs. Despite her getting in a lot of trouble for her ways, it is her strength of character and willingness to fight - not just in the schoolyard, but against adult bullies - that makes her likeable and effective. Atticus is a true hero in his own way - he quietly fights for what is right (his courtroom scenes are subtle, yet powerful) and lets his children have just enough freedom for them to develop as individuals. 
 What makes this book work? A lot of things - the characters are endearing and/or memorable, even the minor ones (Miss Maudie, who the children turn to for advice and cookies, is delightful in her straight-talking ways), the slow build of tension that reaches a crescendo with the court case and that even though dramatic events unfold, there's a lot of real life in there. Not everything goes to plan, not everything happens the way it should 
 This is a book you can read over and over, taking pleasure in different things each time. Don't write it off as something to study, this book should be celebrated for the masterpiece it is.

I'm not going to do a lengthy review because this book is a classic and people will get out their pitchforks. 
 It's a good book but as a 18 year old, I don't really get into it. I don't know if its the fact it's 50 years old and that I don't get into stuff like that.
