Another school-required reading that I loved.

As a teenager, I was forced to read many books in high school. There had been really nothing I had liked. Most of them, I had to force myself to read for tests or find those delightful cliffnote books you could get just to trudge through them. This book was different. This book with it's characters, storyline of injustice and prejudism captivated me. I had actually enjoyed a book I was forced to read by the teachers. A rare fete upon itself. 
 With the last of the year only days away and fresh snow on the ground, I decided to revisit my favorite novel once more. I had not picked it up since my time in high school. It was like reconnecting with old friends again and listening to a story being told once more around a table with hot chocolate in mugs and a grandmother who had lived during this time and had been part of the world. 
 I am not sure what made me like this book. I think it was the fact that here was a man accused of a crime that he did not do. No matter how the law says "innocent until proven guilty". he was still guilty because of the color of his skin. this was a time still of segregation and people of color were still a long ways from gaining any rights of an American citizen. 
 If a teacher hands you this book to read, take a moment and enter into this world. Listen to what all the characters have to say and observe a decade where people who were different from others struggled for their rights.
One of few "American classics" I really get something out of.

Last month I made an important resolution; I decided I was reading to much crap and was going to try to read one classic book each month. The great American classic and Pulitzer Prize winner - To kill a Mockingbird by Harper Lee was the chosen one for the month of August. 
 A lot as been said about the importance of this book for American society and its symbolism, so for the obvious reasons I'm not going to dwell about that. It's an amazing book one that everyone should read and one that I should have read a long time ago. 
 I made the mistake of watching the 1962 movie adaptation before I finished the book so I was pretty much spoiled about the ending. I found the book and movie to be very different. The movie omits a lot of aspects of the book, lots of little stories and sub-plots, and focuses more on Atticus Finch; portrayed by the amazing actor Gregory Peck, who ended winning an Oscar for it, and less on the children. 
 I also decided I wanted to know more about the book and especially about the reclusive author after finding out this was her only novel apart from a few short essays. I ended watching and definitely recommend the 2010 documentary Hey Boo: Harper Lee and To Kill a Mockingbird.

I actually loved this book. Since I live in the homeland of Julius Caesar and pizza (or known better as Italy :] ), we don't read this book for literature class, unfortunately (they don't know what they're missing). But, my mom's friend got me this masterpiece a few years ago, andunfortunately I did not read it that time. This was a few years ago... 
 And so finally, this year, I gathered all my attention to this book during the christmas season, and let me say, I loved it. 
 It has a shade of happiness and nostalgia, filled with themes of racism and prejudice. 
 Harper Lee had an original and ingenious idea to describe every single thing through the eyes of a kid; Scout's feelings and ideas, the peer pressure from his brother during his teenage years, and finally, [spoiler alert] meeting the "monster" or Boo Radley. 
 Everyone should read this masterpiece at least once in their lifetime.

When I was young, the first time I read this (a tween, I believe), I didn't like it. Admittedly, hundreds of years later (it feels like), I couldn't even remember what the book was about. 
 And so, I reread it. 
 It's strange how things change as you age. I now consider this one of my favorite books - ever.

It's a sin to kill a mocking bird. ie, Mocking birds only brings happiness with their songs. They pause no threats.Mockingbirds here is the innocent people like Arthur Radley, Tom Robinson, Scout, Dill and Jem.

It was OK, I suppose, but definitely not really something I'd like to read again, and I can't say I'd recommend this book to anyone with a short attention span. It is an old book, after all, so I suppose that's part of the reason It didn't interest me as much. The language was certainly different and "old-school", and only the last three or four chapters grabbed my attention. This book reminds me of listening to my grandparents when they tell me about growing up. It's very folksy and anecdotal. I loved every minute of it. I don't think that there's one Great American Novel. There is, perhaps, a canon of great American novels (like The Great Gatsby, and Tom Sawyer), and this belongs in that American canon. This novel is very American. What happened happened, and we can't change it, but we can learn from it, and we can choose how we move forward. I can't wait for my kids to be old enough to read this book.

 It will be news to basically no one that To Kill a Mockingbird is an amazing novel. I'm just learning that now, though, as this wasn't offered as part of my high school curriculum, and that's a shame. It would be a great book to read in your early teens. Not only would it have led to some interesting discussion around race issues, but Atticus Finch would be such a great role model to have in one's life growing up, even if just in fiction. 
 Until I feared I would lose it, I never loved to read. One does not love breathing. 
 This is the story of six-year-old Jean Louise Finch who prefers to go by the name of Scout. She lives in the fictional town of Maycomb, Alabama with her brother Jem and widowed father Atticus. The first half of the book is composed of scenes from her childhood as she and her brother attend school, puzzle over their reclusive neighbour Boo Radley, and enjoy the long summers. It really felt like a Tom Sawyer or Huckleberry Finn story at parts, in a great way - pure innocent childhood adventures. 
 The second half of the book has more of a central plot in which Atticus Finch, a lawyer by trade, has been tasked with defending a local black man accused of molesting a white girl. At the time, a black man accused of such a thing was essentially guilty before the trial had even begun, and to defend him with any sort of earnestness was to subject yourself to a lot of anger from the community. Atticus Finch believes the man to be innocent, however, and he's truthful and kind to the core, so he fights what most people consider a futile fight. Over the course of the trial, and during its aftermath, the seemingly inconsequential events from the first half of the book all tie together nicely as the children start to grow up. 
 As you grow older, you'll see white men cheat black men every day of your life, but let me tell you something and don't you forget it--whenever a white man does that to a black man, no matter who he is, how rich he is, or how fine a family he comes from, that white man is trash. 
 I really loved everything about this and every character in it. The narrator Scout is fantastic, but everyone else in the book is so vivid on the page as well. Atticus Finch is one of my new favourite fictional characters, I think. In a way he almost comes across as somewhat one-dimensional. He's established as the wise and calm father from the beginning and stays that way throughout the novel, but I thought it was really interesting how the children's views of him changed. His depth and character arc comes out through the eyes of Scout and Jem. They see him at the beginning of the novel as a completely different person than they do at the end. I love how they come to realize how principled a man he is as the novel progresses, how some of his decisions they had assumed were made from fear were actually made with patience and humility, and how you could see his attitude quietly affect them in ways that would change the adults they eventually become. 
 I'm not sure I'll read Go Set a Watchman. Everything seems off about the publication of that, and I think I'd rather not overshadow this story with an apparently mediocre prequel. Obviously I've just read To Kill a Mockingbird for the first time, so I don't have any sacred nostalgia tied to it, but even so I'm happy with it as it is. I have no idea if Harper Lee is being taken advantage of by her publisher, but I hate the idea of an author's work being published without their permission, especially if it may in any way tarnish his or her existing work. 
 Harper Lee is going to publish a sequel after 55 years... 
 and you people think I write slow.-- George RR Martin (@GeorgeRRMartin_) February 3, 2015

For the Celebrity Death Match Review Tournament, Hamlet (4) versus To Kill a Mockingbird (20) 
 Ladies and gentlemen of the jury, I would like to start by saying how sorry I am to be here today. I considered the deceased a friend. I tried to convince him to act fairly and rationally, in accordance with the best principles of the Danish Constitution. It was easy to understand why he was upset, but, in all honesty, I could not accept that his evidence amounted to proof. The "ghost" he claimed he saw on two occasions - well, we have just heard Mr. Horatio's testimony, and I freely admit that, as he says, there are more things in Heaven and Earth than are dreamed of in his philosophy. All the same, no court would have considered it admissible. The incident of the play was, I agree, far more compelling. Several witnesses - Miss Poloniusdatter was very eloquent - have provided us with their accounts. They coincide well with the one Mr. Hamlet gave me. I went absolutely as far as I could to help him. I told him I thought it warranted further investigation, and I promised in writing - I will show you the letter in a moment - that I would take steps to appoint a Special Prosecutor, as specified in Article 312, paragraphs iv) and v). I honestly don't think many lawyers would have done that. I was taking a serious professional risk, but I believed it was the right thing to do. I'm sorry? Did you say timeframe? I was just coming to that. I said I would progress the case as fast as I could. I thought I would be able to get the Special Prosecutor appointed within as little as eight months, and if things went well we would have convened a Grand Jury by April 1602. We could have been looking at a trial by early 1603. Yes, that is correct, I do remember him talking about the law's delay. He's not the first person I've heard say that. And I'm sorry, I didn't know what a fardel was. I still don't. Maybe someone could tell me? 
 Your honor, I have tried to answer all your questions to the best of my ability. If I had been able to stop Mr. Hamlet from killing himself, I would have done so. Please don't clap. I don't deserve your applause. I wish I could have done better. What do you mean, I've won? This isn't a contest. No one has won here, least of all me.

 It was beautiful, it made me think, it gave me insight of how things were in America at that time. I'm not American, but I'm aware of racism(in America and outside of it, because let's face it, it's an international issue), I think it's important to write this sort of books and read them too. Because they make us more aware of things that happen daily, of things that we're sometimes ignorant of because we're not a part of them. Harper Lee wrote about these issues and many more, her book is a lesson and I loved to be taught through every page about something new. 
 "People generally see what they look for, and hear what they listen for."

I last read To Kill a Mockingbird in 2000 when it was required reading for my ninth-grade English class (just as it is for most kids at that age). Throughout my time in high school, I typically regarded any assigned book with a bit of annoyance and plenty of hesitation. "How could this book possibly be any good if I'm being forced to read it?" I applied those same feelings to this book at that time, and begrudgingly slogged my way through it. (I did finish it, however, unlike almost every other book our teachers handed us, such as Grapes of Wrath and My Antonia.) 
 When I decided to read the book again this year, I initially couldn't remember much about it, except for a few of the major plot points. I knew the narrator was a young Southern girl named Scout whose father, Atticus, was defending a black man in a controversial case and that they had a reclusive neighbor called Boo Radley, but that was about it. As I starting making progress, however, the narratives were instantly familiar, and yet so much more eloquent and poignant than I remembered. The characterization is strong, and Scout's observations are just as important today as they were when the novel was released. I really don't know what else to say that hasn't been said a thousand times before, but I will tell you that I enjoyed it a lot this second time. There is a reason this book is a classic, and if you somehow haven't read it, there's no better time to pick up a copy.

When I was a kid I read this book and disliked it. I thought I would give it a chance as an adult and I'm glad I did. I appreciate it more now. I wouldn't say that it really entertained me, some parts were very slow. But I will say that it taught me something. I learned a lot of history and I really liked the Finch family. They were good people. Who doesn't want to grow up and be a good person like Atticus Finch?

This book really holds up over time. 
 How can one not fall in a little love with Atticus, the single father who models compassion and empathy foremost, but also rewards curiosity and never dumbs down his vocabulary for his kids. And with Scout, who, over the years and through her own lens, learns these lessons well enough to teach the master. 
 The story itself is in turn heartbreaking, infuriating, and ultimately satsifying. But what took me into their world was the very rich characters, growing and learning throughout. I feel like I just spent some time visiting a warm family in the rural south in the 1930s. 
 For the audiobook, Sissy Spacek's reading is terrific.

If the total output of your entire career should include only one thing, make it something special. 
 Not only was To Kill a Mockingbird Harper Lee's only novel, at one point she nearly destroyed it. That would have been a terrible loss, for - coming from an insular, white-New England upbringing - this book was a game changer for me and my young outlook on life and race relations. Having read it as a youth, it's coming-of-age or loss-of-innocence theme spoke to me while the idea of equal rights for all held by the "liberal" Southern Atticus Finch seemed heroic and opened my eyes to the closeted bigotry around me. I know I'm not alone in my reaction and the effects it had upon me. 
 Perhaps Lee didn't write another novel, because she took to heart the maxim "write what you know" and this was the one and only novel within her. It seems a shame such a good writer should have produced and be judged by only one book, but at least she made that one book something special.
Books like this build the Stereotype that "classics" equal to "boredom".

4/5 stars 
 I read this book as an assigned reading book. When I was finished, I had to write a reaction piece as a part of the assignment. I revisited my piece--which I wrote about a year ago--and thought that it can also be my review of the book. I did, however, edited some parts after reading what I wrote. 
 Warning: some spoilers might be ahead! 
 To Kill A Mockingbird is not only a book about "a simple love story," as the author regarded, but a brilliant piece that touches on many aspects of life. It includes messages such as the loss of innocence, perspective, courage, the coexistence of good and evil, prejudice and the different social classes that's apparent throughout human actuality. The transition from innocence to a more mature view of the world is carried out by both Scout, the narrator, and her brother Jem. 
 Jem gets his first real taste of racism while watching and hearing Judge Taylor asking Tom questions; it makes him rethink about the traits that humans have. Scout is able to really understand what Atticus means when he tells her to put herself in the shoes of others; she manage to do so when she sees the world through Arthur's point of view. 
 The purpose of the book isn't for the killing of mockingbirds. It's a symbolism that relates to generally all of the themes shown in this book. "Shoot all the bluejays you want...but remember it's a sin to kill a mockingbird." Tom Robinson and Arthur Radley are both examples of mockingbirds. They don't do anything to others, and yet they get hurt and polluted by society and reality. 
 Harper Lee used Atticus as the main voice for the recognition of virtues which plays a big part to identifying the messages that she incorporated into the novel. 
 ***

Read this as part of Buddy Read with Reading Is Fun Group. 
 "Mockingbirds don't do one thing but make music for us to enjoy. They don't eat up people's gardens, don't nest in corncribs, they don't do one thing but sing their hearts out for us. That's why it's a sin to kill a mockingbird." 
 This is considered a classic but it is soo very different from the other classics that I have read. I don't know why, but always because of the title of this book I thought this will be a difficult book to read and kept on pushing off reading this. How I repent not reading this earlier!! 
 Firstly I had no idea that this whole book is from a child's perspective. The book's basic premise does deal with a very serious topic . But the way it has been written somehow makes it easier to read (I did not have the heavy feeling that is associated with most of the classics). 
 The start of the book reminded me of all the children's book I have ever read- the world is innocent all around and life is all about fun and games. But as the story moves forward and the main protagonist (Scout) becomes aware of all the evil's that surround her, we too experience this awakening with her. I really think this was a very unique way of making the reader realize how the innocence of this child is shattered and there is a stage of awareness of the rights and wrong (We all have been through that). 
 The author has also beautifully iterated to the reader that it is easier for the children to differentiate between right and wrong than adults who are prejudiced by their own narrow view of how the world should be. 
 If you haven't already read this, I highly recommend reading this book. I am very interested in seeing the screen adaptation of this story.
Excellent story!
A brilliant, thought-provoking classic. Loved it.

I just finished this book, and I can see why it is considered a literary 
 masterpiece 
 ! This is a book on the inequality of blacks and whites, and the only thing I dislike about this book is a rather slow pick-up (which is usually what most teenagers will think) and the frequent use of the 'n' word. One point I noticed that I thought was quite magnificent was the demonstration of the flawed education system of the time. Just because Scout could read, she was punished. Also she was not allowed to follow a more advanced and fast paced education. This is an amazing book that I would recommend to anyone over the age of 12 or 13 for difficulty and content.

73. TO KILL A MOCKINGBIRD, BY HARPER LEE 
 Actually, this one was recommended (rather non-voluntarily) to me by a creep on the internet who took offense at me wanting to spend a year reading books written by women. Unfortunately, I didn't take note of his user name and don't know how to get in touch with him again to thank him... As malicious as his comment might have been, this is indeed a very good book. It was further recommended by Michelle, so he doesn't get all the points for this. 
 English is not my first language, so I didn't read this in school. My required reading was very different. I'm not absolutely sure I would have enjoyed it if I had read it as a child, but I tend to believe so. The prose is delicious, the characters are captivating, the story is adventurous. 
 I'm sure, this being such a famous and important book, that there are many reviews for it, and they must have discussed its elements quite thoroughly. That being the case, I'll just save my words and simply say that I've enjoyed it and very much recommend it. 
 Up next: The Secret Life of Bees, by Sue Monk Kidd

This book is one of the greatest story I've read. I started reading To Kill a Mockingbird in my english class during my high school years. This great tale started off very interesting from the characters personalities and the time & setting. I have to admit that it was an excellent source of literary knowledge of older times. 
 Here is the story plot is about a young girl named Scout, her older brother Jem, and their loving father Atticus, living in a small town in Alabama during the 1930s. At the beginning of the book it's mostly centered about Scout, Jem, and Dill,(Jem and Scouts summer friend), trying to get the mysterious Boo Radly to come out of his house. As well as some of their adventures together from school, play relatives/neighbors life happenings. Now during the later portion the novel it's more about their father Atticus defending an innocent blackman on trial, for a crime he didn't commit, and how it affects his family and everyone in their small southern town. That's where the story really spins for you. The emotional rollor coaster that the story takes you to the highs & low of the courts and people outcome. It is an all together beautiul bittersweet coming of age tale of growing up, innocences, and acceptence of life's circumstances. 
 I rate this novel with 10 stars & 2 thumbs up. The movie was wonderful too. Even though it was not exactly like the book. They had to make the film shorter. But Gregory Peck delivers a marvalous performance as Atticus Finch and the children too. =)~

Like many American schoolchildren, not unlike Jean Louise Finch herself, probably, I read To Kill A Mockingbird in middle school -- although "read" might be a loose term: I listened to the book on tape while my teacher sat glumly at her computer and refused to answer any of our questions. In some respects, I was like Scout when she complains to Atticus that her teacher isn't letting her read and write at home. I was already reading more interesting things than what any teacher forced me to read in class, and that year my teacher's complete lack of interest in TKAM made me disconnect even more. That too often classes in English classes in school; you tune out and hate the book forever. I thought TKAM was an okay book back then, but I had a tainted memory of it in my head and didn't understand why everyone loved it. Specifically, why they loved Atticus Finch. 
 I can't count how many times I've seen Atticus lauded as a hero, for reasons I didn't understand until yesterday, when I started reading TKAM again. And then it was like a mockingbird crashed directly into my face. 
 Justice has a funny way of working itself into tales of heroism and bravery, into those stories where everyone gets what they deserve and it ends on a happy note. And there really isn't a more stereotypical place for it than within a courtroom, where Atticus Finch feels it's his duty to defend one of the least-respected members of society in the sluggish little town of Maycomb, Alabama. It's a lot like Twelve Angry Men, when you believe Henry Fonda is crusading for the true and just cause of exonerating a kid who doesn't deserve the treatment he's getting. 
 But the thing that's great about TKAM is how skillfully Harper Lee builds up a standard story arc and then demolishes it. The last third of the book -- although I did remember bits and pieces from my first read-through -- was shocking to me, but in an angry, inspirational way. I had a sickening feeling the racial and class disparity in Maycomb wouldn't be magically saved in the trial, no matter the verdict, and the final climactic scene on Halloween night left me feeling a mix of melancholy and awe. 
 Harper Lee writes a superb story, one that practically compelled me to read the book in two big chunks; I was never bored. Scout (and Jem, too) is a fun narrator, who combines the sense of childhood ignorance the entire town depends on with the yearning for justice that her father instills in her. And that makes the book a more interesting read because Scout is not actively involved in everything that goes on; rather, she's an unwitting bystander to some of the town's biggest upheavals. She's a precocious girl, sure, but Lee wrote it purposefully so she wouldn't full comprehend all she was seeing or hearing. The reader still relies on Atticus to explain everything to us, except in the places where the "grown-up" talk goes above Scout's head. 
 I don't often wonder about characters beyond the end of a novel. But I fear the events of the novel, had they actually happened exactly the way Scout interprets them, would have turned her off of hope for any kind of tolerance and anti-discrimination in her hometown. She is asked in the book what she wants to be when she grows up -- a lawyer, like her father, or something else? -- but she replies that she's never really thought about it. Lee's novel makes you want to believe Scout and Jem have been changed for the better, but Atticus' remark that things are just the way they are and won't always chance despite a great character's best intentions. 
 That's Atticus in a nutshell. The events of one fateful summer hung on him heavily, on the entire family, and impacted them for a period of a couple of years. He taught his own children, and multiple generations of eager readers, the true lessons of kindness, tolerance and decency, even in the face of something over which you have no power. Karma doesn't always come back around to fight with you instead of against you, but as Atticus taught, sometimes you just have to do something because otherwise you couldn't go around living with yourself.

Didn't know this was a child's book. I thought it was OK and I liked some descriptions and settings but the story itself didn't go to interesting places, even when the potential was there. All the good characters are too perfect and read like modern western liberal bloggers. They even have a dig at Hitler.

It is rare that a truly important social question gets expression in a book of fantastic literary sensitivity. To Kill a Mockingbird is the story of a coming-of-age girl that witnesses the wrongful treatment of a Negro accused of rape in the 1930s' South. The first part of the book draws in detail the white society as seen by Louise (Scout), the motherless girl under ten of Lawyer Atticus Finch. In this part, Harper Lee gives full account of her wonderful writing skill, including memorable formulations such as "People in their right minds never take pride in their talents", "With him, life was routine, without him, life was unbearable", and "She was never bored, and given the slightest chance she would exercise her royal prerogative: she would arrange, advise, caution, and warn." In the second part we get in touch with the heart-breaking (and still socially-relevant) story of Tom Robinson, the Negro accused to have raped a girl. When Atticus Finch becomes his defender-in-court, Scout (and we through her eyes) becomes the at first amazed and at last ashamed witness to the social divide between Whites and Negroes. The story evolves rapidly to a tormenting and still actual conclusion. A must-read for everyone, and especially for the Western society.

One of my absolute favourites. I can understand some of the criticisms that have been levelled at it as regards the perceived "white-saviour" theme, but I think it mostly averts that problem, for what my opinion's worth (note: not much). On another note, reading this as a tomboyish kid, I just felt like Scout understood where I was coming from. Also, the moment near the end with Boo Radley still makes me tear up a bit, possibly even more than the outcome of the "main" storyline (I cry at everything, though).

Bingo - a banned book. I think I last read this in 2001 or 2002 (for our bookclub's annual "classic" re-read), but it didn't leave a lasting impression on me then and I cannot imagine why. The setting is close to where my dad grew up. We still have family there but I haven't visited since the 1990's... on this reading I can see Maycomb as it must've been 80 years ago and it makes me sad, but hopeful. And then sad again because much of what existed in 1935 still exists... beyond the deep South. This is an amazing story and the writing is ... perfect. 
 Sadly, it makes me think that Go Set a Watchman is going to be a disappointment. I can't imagine that, if it were any good at all, it wouldn't have been published after To Kill a Mockingbird. I hope I'm wrong!

"You never really understand a person until you consider things from his point of view... Until you climb inside of his skin and walk around in it." 
 Finally, after 23 years, I read this classic and wow, people weren't kidding: this book is something special. This novel isn't only a great children's book, but also a wonderful coming-of-age story of Jem and Scout, and a serious (adult) book about racism, honour, and different forms of courage. 
 This books reads like a play: you first start by setting the scene (Maycomb, a small Southern town in Alabama) and by growing familiar with the characters: the siblings Scout and Jem and their father Atticus. This slow start doesn't appeal to everyone, but due to Harper Lee's story telling I was never bored. The narrator of this story is young tomboy Jean Louise (Scout), and her observations of Maycomb and people's behavior are simple, honest, and visually very rich. I had no problem picturing Scout, Jem and Dill's childish efforts to draw Boo Radley out of his house, or Calpurnia taking the kids to a colored church. 
 But when, after 128 pages, the court case begins and the plot really becomes intriguing, you immediately feel a rise in tension and excitement. Here Jem and Atticus become the main characters instead of Scout because they are more aware of the risks and importance of the case, although Scout's moment with the mob was heartwrenchingly beautiful in it's innocence. 
 The last part of the book was less tense but never dull: it was important to show the aftermath and the effects of the case on different class - and races - of people to convey the impact of Atticus' actions. Because back in 1935 and even now, in our current political situation, standing up for what's right while the majority is against you, is an incredible brave and difficult thing to do. 
 "Courage is not a man with a gun in his hand. It's knowing you're licked before you begin but you begin anyway and you see it through no matter what. You rarely win, but sometimes you do." 
 One thing especially about this story that stood out to me, are the interesting gender roles in this book. We have Atticus who isn't only presented as an amazing father but also as a great male character, because he's patient, courteous, clever...but not traditionally masculine. In contrast with Bob Ewell, the main antagonist, Atticus isn't physically strong, doesn't use strong language, and hates violence (example: he keeps his shooting skills a secret from his children). 
 His sister, aunt Alexandra, is a very traditional female figure who wants Scout to behave more 'lady like', and because Scout doesn't like her (at first), we as readers dislike her too. Acting as her opposites are Calpurnia and Miss Maudie, who neither show traditional feminine characteristics like politeness and charm, but both are presented as good and right. 
 And what do the other (minor) characters teach us? Like Mrs. Dubose, that nasty old lady, who is described by Atticus as 'the bravest person he ever knew'? And what about Mayella Ewell? Lee leaves her role in the open, letting us decide if she's either an antagonist or a victim. 
 "To Kill A Mockingbird" is a well-loved book for many good reasons, but I was very surprised by its diverse male and female characters, who make this story even richer that it already is. 
 So this was an absolute beautiful read, told by two precious children and an inspiring father, who teaches us about justice, prejudice, and empathy. A book I'll definitely read to my children in the future, and a novel I can recommend to anyone.

I wish I had read this sooner. There are numerous books, movies, even comic books about racism, but I have not seen anything as poignant and beautiful as "To Kill a Mockingbird". 
 Atticus Finch is the ultimate hero: detached yet loving, smart yet humble. The portrayal of southern Alabama in the 30s (which I believe to be as much of a character in the novel as Atticus is) is fabulous. Scout, who sometimes leads the narration from the perspective of a 7 year old girl an sometimes a grown woman reflecting on her youth, is instantly lovable. And despite some of the language the young scout uses seeming a little bit too adult for her, she's utterly believable. 
 I loved this book and you should definitely read it.
Re-reading this, and you know what? It just keeps getting better.

Awesome book! I can't believe I waited this long in my life to read this classic. I already knew the general plot of the book, but it still exceeded expectations! The author gives you a lot to think about and presents it in a very entertaining (and suspenseful at times) way.

I did it! I finally read To Kill a Mockingbird. I'm not going to lie and say there weren't times I could take it or leave it. If I had no knowledge of what happens in this book, I would have thought the entire story consisted of a tomboy's antics in small town Alabama. 
 BUT once the book starts to get to build towards the trial, and the themes of racial inequality and the question of individual integrity, I was hooked. For an older book, the writing is readable and avoids flowery descriptions, instead keeping an engaging pace throughout. I mean I actually liked The Scarlet Letter, but for goodness sake that book spends the first chapter describing a door. It's a commitment. 
 Despite being decades old, so much of the racism described in the book is still alive and well today, making it simultaneously timely and timeless. An accessible classic that provides a lot of food for thought regarding one's personal code of conduct and sense of morality.

This is a stupendous book. It is arguably most famous for the racial themes in it and those are definitely a key part of this book. However, what I found most interesting was how that and other things related to parenting in this book. 
 The entire book is from a child's perspective and focuses on key moments in her upbringing. It is really a interesting and well done story about introducing a child to the harsher realities of the world. The message about prejudice is important and I think is actually done a greater service by being more of a backdrop for scouts' upbringing. You get a different view of not just prejudice but also how people may act differently than they say.
Ten years later I finally get around to this book. How was it? Fucking great that's what. Everyone knows what it's about so I am not going to go into it. However I will for the sequel.

 I'm genuinely sad that the words stopped. :( I feel like it's too early to say goodbye to these characters at this point in their lives, but I'm really glad that I got to spend some time with them! Let's just see how things will go in the sequel. :)

I've now read To Kill a Mockingbird a couple of times, and when I finished this last time I looked over the reviews other people had written on Goodreads. I've seen two kinds of responses. The vast majority are extremely positive raves about the book. These reviews tend to focus on how admirable Atticus is as a character, the worthy theme of the book (more or less, everyone is equal), and enjoyment over seeing through the eyes of the main character. The other, much smaller, camp is much more negative, going so far as to call it painful and not worth reading at all. I find myself very much in the middle of these groups (which I'm sure will endear me to nobody). 
 To Kill a Mockingbird is a story told through the eyes of Scout, a young girl growing up in the South. She, her brother, Jem, and their friend, Dill, hang out and try to draw out the neighborhood recluse, Boo Radley. Scout's father, Atticus, is a lawyer, and he happens to take on a very controversial case. A young Black man is accused of raping a young White girl, and Atticus is tasked with defending the man. The town is mostly very much against Atticus in this case - the very idea of taking a Black person's word over a White person's is abhorrent to them. Scout tries to make sense of the world and her community in the face of injustice and racism throughout the book, which culminates in a harrowing series of events that leave Scout and Jem in peril. 
 Overall, To Kill a Mockingbird is enjoyable. It moves along at a solid pace, and it keeps your attention with amusing side stories. It's a well-told story. But I felt that, in many ways, it was a bit clumsy. In particular, I find the way the theme is presented to be pretty ham fisted. It's just so in-your-face about the injustice in the South before the Civil Rights era, without any trace of subtlety. It's so blatant that I don't think it's very effective at changing anyone's mind or showing someone anything new. Very few people are honest with themselves when it comes to prejudice. It's just so difficult to judge ourselves objectively and harshly, particularly when it comes to race. I think that when a lot of people read this book, they feel self-righteous and angry, but they don't feel anything that would cause them to change or view to the world differently. This is what I expect of great books with worthy themes, and To Kill a Mockingbird does not live up to that. 
 So I don't really understand the adoration for it - it's ok, but it's really not that great. I also don't really understand the hate - it's not great, but it's really not that bad. I certainly don't think it's a must-read, but I think a lot of people would enjoy reading To Kill a Mockingbird as a piece of very slightly socially conscious fluff.
By far one of my top favorite adult books ever! Heart-wrenching and wonderful and pure and.... all sorts of other fabulous adjectives!

I know this makes me a freak of nature or something, but this is one of those books that I don't understand why so many people love it. I'm not saying it's bad, but it's only okay. Perhaps I'd like it better if I reread it (I haven't read it since high school), but I never really liked Scout and I always thought the most interesting aspects of the book had more to do with the trial and her father than her, but because she's the main character and we follow her POV, we get more about her wandering around being a kid than the trial.
Certainly one of the great American novels, quite possibly my favorite.

Somehow, I am very overwhelmed after finishing this book. I am both sad and happy and can't really form my thoughts into words. 
 This book was so much better than I expected it to be. I thought it was one of those "classics" that were once revolutionary but not very relevant anymore. But it's written fantastically, with such a understanding for humans and so much little wonderful details. And as sad as it is to admit, all the issues this book talks about are still current. 
 I decided not to read the "sequel", since I don't want it to spoil this book, as I've seen some reviewers say. But I'm very glad I decided to read it.

It's always been a gaping hole in my literary education. My English teachers in high school all leaned toward British authors, and my college professors all tended towards male American authors. It's actually pretty embarrassing that I've never read this literary classic. I decided to rectify it on the heels of the news of Lee's "sequel" novel being published this year. 
 I can't really review this book as much as I can say that I loved it. It was subtle yet powerful, and it's the kind of book you can read over and over again. I'm sorry I never got to experience it as a young girl, but I'm glad I get the chance now. 
 I'm counting this as the "Book you should have read in high school" for the 2015 Modern Mrs Darcy Reading Challenge.

Not having read this book since high school, I decided to reread it so that I could read the "new" Harper Lee book. 
 It was definitely better than I remembered. One thing that made it more personal for me, is that my husband is from Alabama. As a Californian, this part of the setting did not stick in my mind when I was in high school, since all southern states were pretty interchangeable in my mind. Now I've been to one of them, and it's that one! 
 As I read the first few chapters, I was surprised by how well I remembered it. I could tell right away that the writing style was one that I would enjoy. 
 What I didn't remember well was the very end. 
 I'm glad that I took the time to read this book again, outside of school. I look forward to reading Go Set a Watchman.

I put off reading this book because I thought it was just an overrated piece of literature. However, my brother urged me to read it after he studied it for his English Literature GCSE (my class did Lord of the Flies instead) and I was surprised not only at how good the story was, but how good the writing was. I was worried that, because the book was reasonably old and set in the American South, that I might not understand it; however, Harper Lee has (had?) a gift for writing and the story never once had the feeling of stuffiness you might associate with other modern classics.

This is a very amazing book (now I know why it's considered one of American literature's masterpieces). The second half was so intense and it kept me on my feet, and I can finally announce that I'm officially cured from my reader's block!

I did not care for this book. I always feel -- often rightfully so -- that I'm being horribly judged every time I admit that. I once had somebody say to me, "No offense, but... do you maybe think you just didn't get the entire meaning of the book?" 
 Haha, that's cute. To answer your question, no, I don't think I missed the meaning. How could I miss it when Harper Lee all but comes out and beats you to death with it? There's the good people, there's the bad people, and the children can easily see how every single person in their lives fits into one of these boxes because they have the sweetness and innocence of childhood, blah blah blah. 
 Other people feel differently about this, but my personal feeling is that if a book is going to be overtly didactic it should at least have a message that's unique and thought-provoking. If it doesn't, then it's like listening to the kind of story that you would tell a kindergarten class where we all learn that it's important to SHARE :o. That's why I don't care for this book. (It's also why Mitch Albom is among my all-time least favourite authors, but that's an issue for another review...) 
 Another problem I have with this book is that it seems to several short stories weakly bundled together, rather than a whole cohesive story. Apparently that was one of the criticisms the publishers had of the rough draft, which is why Harper Lee added the whole Boo Riley thread -- to add some sort of continuity to the story. 
 I've sometimes felt that I should really try to like this book more because other people seem to love it so much. Ultimately, though, I've decided that I don't care. To me, this book is a bunch of (not particularly interesting) episodes haphazardly strung together, with a few hackneyed, pseudo-philosophical platitudes thrown in here and there for good measure.

When I was in third grade I realised people considered a certain kinds of books "Real books". If you read them, you were well-read and intelligent, if you didn't read you were busy. If you read something else, you were shallow and delusional. 
 I considered this problem and came up with a reasonable solution. I went around and read all of these classics in a year or so. Some of them I enjoyed, some of them I didn't. More importantly though they served their purpose, I'd read any mandatory reading we had till the end of high school and anytime someone heard I liked books and asked me if I had read Jane Austin or Jane Eyre, or another kind of Jane, I could say yes and leave it at that. 
 It was a good plan and it served me well, It left me free to read anything I wanted until I came to my character enough to realise I didn't care what people thought about what I read. That year of studying classics still serves me well when I'm having a literally argument, put forward a great example from a fantasy and face either blank looks or snickers, then I can go around and say something from a classic, something they'd either feel obliged to accept or be too ashamed to confess they haven't read. 
 However I'd never read To kill a mockingbird until this day. The reason is simple, it's not considered a classic in my country, it's not even famous. It wasn't until I was deep into my English reading that I first heard its name. I got the book out of a different ( and yet similar ) kind of attitude to my classic reading in third grade, because I felt an obligation to read it, this time to myself as a reader. Yet it sat in my shelves for ages and I never picked it up, with so many books I was extremely exited to read coming out every day it was hard to make time to read something out of obligation. 
 So despite being left unread, when I was preparing to move to another country it wasn't one of the (Sadly small) number of books I could bring with me. 
 Imagine how I felt when I got here, signed up for a writing class and realised this was the mandatory reading! I wasn't sure if I should laugh or bang my head against the walls. 
 It was like this that after years I finally read To Kill a Mockingbird. 
 Maybe you're wondering why I'm wasting your time telling this long fetched story that has nothing to do with reviewing the book. 
 It's because I don't plan on reviewing it. I liked the book well enough. I liked the characters a whole lot, the parts about women's part in the society that irked me at times weren't anywhere as bad as Little Women, I liked what it was saying, I tried to learn from the crisp clear writing and more than anything I enjoyed how alive the narrative was. 
 But I don't want to review it because no one cares. If I didn't like it and I could come up with a hundred good reasons no one would care either. This is a classic and it has its set place and no review of it really matters. 
 So this isn't a review of the book, it's a review of classic worshipping frame of my mind. I don't know what it's liked in other countries. But I do know in mine it's the biggest reason people don't read. I'm sure there are some people who can start reading with reading war and peace and only read books that teaches them something, but for every one of them there has been 30 others who's learned forever to look at reading as boring because their true genre was fantasy or adventure and they'd been snobbed into classics. However even worse than this are the people who have learned to automatically assume any books their teachers ask them to read is boring and never even give it a chance. 
 So I guess this is what I'm saying, about To Kill a Mocking bird or any other book of its kind. You don't have to read them to be intelligent or well-read. You don't have to read them to be a bookworm. In fact, there is no single reason for you to read them other than wanting to, because that's the only way you'll really enjoy them anyway.

On the occasion of the publication of Lee's new book, I finally opened my copy of To kill a mockingbird that has sit on my bookshelf for a few years. 
 It wasn't a disappointment. I like reading it, I like Scout's voice. Her story telling skill is superb and never bored me for a minute. 
 Yet, I wasn't totally satisfied. The novel, after all, was written in the 60s by a white woman on racial issues, no matter how luckily that child was to be raised by a wonderful father (well, Lee's new book caused huge uproar about Atticus. I'm curious, I'll obtain the new novel soon). Given that context, the novel was a great achievement. It reminds me somewhat of uncle Tom's cabin, though a bit better. But today, if the text is used for educational purposes, many things should be cleared, carefully studied and explained, or else it could even backfire.

This is going straight to my favorite book list! Filled with astounding personalities and stories, it gave me an almost nostalgic, rustic feeling of being a child and starting to learn about life and it's many faults and lessons.

Review to follow. Old favorite. 
 10/10
This book is a true classic. No matter how many times I read it, I can't get enough.

"Before I can live with other folks I've got to live with myself. The one thing that doesn't abide by majority rule is a person's conscience." 
 -- Harper Lee, To Kill a Mockingbird

I read this book this summer mainly because, as a bookworm who had never been assigned it in school, I pretty much felt obligated to read it at some point. Why not now? I had been putting it off for a while, being apprehensive of reading it, for unknown reasons. I really didn't like it in the beginning, it was a chore to read, I felt like the plot was going absolutely nowhere. It definitely picked up a little more than halfway through, near the courtroom scene. I was planning on giving it two stars, but I'll give it three because I did enjoy the end, and I was pretty biased against liking it when I started, which may have affected my enjoyment of the book.

A lot better than I thought it would be! 
 Favourite character: Atticus. He's just so intelligent and wise, and the scene where he took down the dog with one shot was just too cool. That was probably not the point of the story, but oh, well. I thought it was seriously awesome that he had a hidden ninja history. 
 Scout was a funny protagonist. I like the way she sees a lot of things and the way she recounts a story. She's a tough little cookie, and I would start laughing every time she spoke about beating other boys up. I like that she didn't listen to her aunt, who told her to wear dresses. 
 Also: ham costume. That cracked me up. 
 I really liked the ending and the circular plot. (view spoiler)[As soon as I read that Scout heard the sound of something of Jem's breaking, I was like, IT'S HIS ARM. THIS IS FROM THE START OF THE BOOK. It was really good. 
 Other good things include the courtroom scene; it was really intense! I loved how Atticus acted and how smart he was. Whenever Mayella messed up or Atticus made a good point, I would be like, OHHHHH YES. YOU SHOW 'EM WHO'S BOSS. (hide spoiler)] 
 Honestly, this novel, out of everything I've ever had to read for English, is probably my favourite. Cheers.

"You never really understand a person until you consider things from his point of view... Until you climb inside of his skin and walk around in it." 
 -- Harper Lee, To Kill a Mockingbird 
 "Until I feared I would lose it, I never loved to read. One does not love breathing." 
 -- Harper Lee, To Kill a Mockingbird 
 "I wanted you to see what real courage is, instead of getting the idea that courage is a man with a gun in his hand. It's when you know you're licked before you begin, but you begin anyway and see it through no matter what. 
 - Atticus Finch" 
 -- Harper Lee, To Kill a Mockingbird 
 To Kill a Mockingbird by Harper Lee was a captivating and beautiful book. Although I had to read this for school, I sure enjoyed it. Harper Lee had covered many themes that were weaved into the plot, making it a intersting and delightful read. I really enjoyed the deep writing, plot, and characters. They all contributed in a way to making the book and its messages vivid. A historical fiction classic, this book is one of my favorites. 
 "People generally see what they look for, and hear what they listen for." 
 -- Harper Lee, To Kill a Mockingbird 
 "I think there's just one kind of folks. Folks." 
 -- Harper Lee, To Kill a Mockingbird 
 "They're certainly entitled to think that, and they're entitled to full respect for their opinions... but before I can live with other folks I've got to live with myself. The one thing that doesn't abide by majority rule is a person's conscience." 
 -- Harper Lee, To Kill a Mockingbird 
 I loved the characters- it's as simple as that. They all are different but deeply developed and loveable. From spunky Scout to pensive Jem and even-handed Atticus. I just adored them all from their greatest to not so heroic moments. Each of them taught me something and I feel they are as real as can be- I mean how can you not? I really loved all their adventures in finding themselves and understanding the world. 
 Back then in their time, I can only imagine the difficulties of human ignorance, but some people today aren't far off. Modern times and past times don't really have a difference when it comes down to human moral nature. But despite it all, the characters stayed strong and true to the end. Atticus was a favorite, he was such a caring and gentle parent, but also an understanding and logic adult. His unique way of raising Scout and Jem was what made the family one of a kind with their values and considerate perception. 
 I also had to cherish Dill, Mrs. Maudie, Aunt Alexandra, Judge Taylor, Cal, Mr. Tate and of course Mr. Arthur Radley. Or Boo Radley as I like to say with the kids. But in all, I have to say I despised Bob Ewell and his freakin' family along with the rest of the hypocrite town of Maycomb. Like at times, I just wanted to imagine actually spitting and kicking those people. Good Lord, I might just do that with the next racist person I see. People really disgust me at times, they are just wholly revolting. When will the human race stop spliting itself up and grow up?! Somethings in this world will probably never change yet, not for a long while I suppose. 
 "Sometimes the Bible in the hand of one man is worse than a whisky bottle in the hand of (another)... There are just some kind of men who - who're so busy worrying about the next world they've never learned to live in this one, and you can look down the street and see the results." 
 -- Harper Lee, To Kill a Mockingbird 
 "It was times like these when I thought my father, who hated guns and had never been to any wars, was the bravest man who ever lived." 
 -- Harper Lee, To Kill a Mockingbird 
 "As you grow older, you'll see white men cheat black men every day of your life, but let me tell you something and don't you forget it - whenever a white man does that to a black man, no matter who he is, how rich he is, or how fine a family he comes from, he is trash." 
 -- Harper Lee, To Kill a Mockingbird 
 In conclusion, To Kill a Mockingbird was a great classic. I was throughly delighted and have learned much from this book. I adored the characters and I just loved how the story unwrapped. It was like growing up with Scout and Jem over the years, witnessing the understanding and innocence. This book is another written proof of what human ignorance and its consequences and effects on the world looks like. Harper Lee has an amazing way of writing through the eyes of a child along with the words of an adult mixed in. Her characters, plot and story were just sooo good. I really was glad that I finally got around to it (even though school had to really push me into it)- and I recommend this great read. Really touching and straight at its purpose. 
 "People in their right minds never take pride in their talents." 
 -- Harper Lee, To Kill a Mockingbird 
 "Mockingbirds don't do one thing but make music for us to enjoy. They don't eat up people's gardens, don't nest in corncribs, they don't do one thing but sing their hearts out for us. That's why it's a sin to kill a mockingbird." 
 -- Harper Lee, To Kill a Mockingbird 
 "Atticus, he was real nice." 
 "Most people are, Scout, when you finally see them." 
 -- Harper Lee, To Kill a Mockingbird

This is one of those titles that I have always meant to read but have never got around to, but I am glad that I now have. I can appreciate now all the subtle references to it in popular culture that I have missed until now. Will probably reread at some point in the future.

This is a book that deserves to be read over and over again. Each time, I appreciate the humor, honesty, pain, and sense of justice in the midst of so much prejudice that much more. This time I paired my reading with watching the movie, which I had never seen before, and it makes me so excited for the release of Go Set a Watchman!

5 lovely, simple, thought-provoking stars!! 
 To kill a Mockingbird by Harper Lee is a supreme classic. It"s an austere yet elegant book written from the POV of a little girl, Jean Louise Finch a.k.a. Scout. who narrates about the ridiculous attitude of adult men and women towards class and racism, prevalent in the 1930s world, as perceived by her childlike mind. 
 In the first part, the county's lawyer, Atticus Finch tells his children this- 
 "Shoot all the bluejays you want, if you can hit 'em, but remember it's a sin to kill a mockingbird." 
 At first I was flummoxed by what exactly Atticus had meant. But as the story progressed, the mist cleared off as easily as it came. The title as well as the quote is literally insignificant, but does bear considerable meaning to the very context of the book. Mockingbirds here probably imply innocence and ingenuousness. 
 "Mockingbirds don't do one thing but make music for us to enjoy. They don't eat up people's gardens, don't nes in corncribs, they don't do one thing but ing their hearts out for us. That's why it's a sin to kill a mockingbird." 
 The two kids, Jem and Scout through a span of a few years of their childhood take a plunge from a view that people were possibly good, and that they meant no evil, to bringing themselves to think that evil, injustice and hypocrisy are just as evident in every sphere of life. No, the book doesn't work on a pessimistic and negative vision entirely. It unfolds with unblemished dexterity to elucidate that most often people around us are a mix of both decent and vice. The perfect example here would be the Sheriff, Heck Tate, among many others. In the court case against Tom Robinson, he sided against Tom who was innocent, but when Mr. Bob Ewell tried to inflict harm onto Jem and Scout, and died in the process, despite Atticus's many objections, Mr. Tate stood unflinching on his stand that Mr. Ewell fell on his own knife and it wasn't the result of any juvenile slaying by Jem; here, he did what was lawful and right. 
 The best part of the book, for me, would be the court proceedings concerning Tom Robinson's case. Atticus's unprejudiced and vehement stance in defending Tom Robinson, a Negro who was falsely accused with the rape of a white girl shows his firm belief in moral values, devoid of any bigotry on account of colour, class or religion. To him, he was a man claiming his dignity from the tentacles of the selfish white lot. Everything in the case was in favour of Atticus. Everything but that jury, which was also a fragment of the cruel chauvinistic society, which placed Race above Innocence. The death of Tom Robinson is another example that justifies the title; he was a mockingbird slaughtered by the mean, hypocritical ways of the townsfolk. 
 Another interesting element in this book was Boo Radley. Harper Lee explores the voyage of the two kids, Jem and Scout in trying to unveil the mystery of the Radley place. Boo Radley's image gradually transforms from being a childhood rumour to a more grown-up outlook of being a lonely child of an atrocious father, who shut himself out from the world outside. Jem later even rationalizes this behaviour of his by saying that maybe he knew of the meanness in this world much more than they did. 
 "Scout, I think I'm beginning to understand why Boo Radley's stayed shut up in the house all this time... Its because he wants to stay inside." 
 Atticus Finch is a timeless character, totally down-to-earth, compassionate, humane. He is a remarkable father and he perseveres to pass on his moral values to his children. From being an impartial father when it comes to listening to the woes of his children, to being a person striving to seek goodness in every person of the world, he was the epitome of benevolence. 
 For instance, his take on Mrs. Dubose's character, no matter how cranky she had been to the kids- all attempted to implant that essence of goodness into his kids. 
 "I wanted you to see something about her- I wanted you to see what real courage is, instead of getting the idea that courage is a man with a gun in his hand. It's when you are licked before you begin but you begin anyway and you see it through no matter what. You rarely win, but sometimes you do. Mrs. Dubose won, all ninety-eight pounds of her. According to her, she died beholden to nothing and nobody. She was the bravest person I ever knew." 
 The language was splendid. Scout's POV was the best thing undoubtedly in this book, and it just kept me hanging till the end. I know the start might be dragging for some, but now that I'm done with the book, I think it was only because Lee attempted to get us accounted with the kids and with the very quintessence of childhood incorruptibility. 
 I don't know where I was all these years that I hadn't read this book, but now that I had, I'm so glad I did. Its a literary classic, and it ought to be celebrated. 
 A 5 starry-read for me.

Atticus, an upright defense attorney represents a young black man accused of rape. Living in the Macomb, GA during the 30s gave the accused two strikes before he took the stand, and his fear made him seem even guiltier. I was so disappointed in the town and their rush to false justice. I felt like Dill, sick. And when Scout questioned Jem about the teacher's opinion of Hitler's injustice, I thought how smart she was to make the connection. If Jews in another country shouldn't be persecuted, why are "niggers" treated so badly at home? 
 The use of the "n" word certainly played a part in causing some to ban this book. Others may have had offense to the subject of the trial. Still this book is chosen for high school study in many schools. The lessons of prejudice and democracy need to be taught. And we should listen to mockingbirds; their songs will remind us that there is still good in the world. Bad things may happen, evil continue to live, but like Atticus we should love all and seek to live in the light.

I seem to be one of the only people in our generation to have made it through grade school without having to read this, so when our book club decided to do it, I went in with fresh eyes. Kind of a "Tree Grows in Brooklyn" from a different time and place (high praise coming from me), but I can only 4.5 stars because I had to endure the "n" word on almost every page.

This was a very enjoyable read. A fun coming of age tale mixed with a look at race relations in our history. 
 I was forced to read this in school many years ago and I hated it. I liked the movie but had to force my way through the book. I can't remember why I didn't like it then, but my opinion has changed completely. 
 Scout was a fun character to read. She didn't change a lot throughout the book and sometimes it seemed she was older than her age, but for the most part it worked. It was good to see Jem grow and mature and Scout's reactions to this. 
 I can imagine the outrage this book caused when it was written. I wish it would have been a lesson, but unfortunately we as a society still have a lot of the same prejudices today. They may not all be as blatantly obvious as they were back then, but they exist nonetheless.

This "Review" was originally written for the Celebrity Death Match Review Tournament 
 The bout begins. 
 The opponents: Huckleberry Finn vs. Scout Finch. 
 Due to Huckleberry Finn's considerable advantage in size and experience, Scout is given the choice of venue and rules. She chooses the streets of Maycomb, Alabama and the rules of the Third Grade Playground. 
 The round starts with a surprise as Scout rushes headlong into Huck. No one expected such a direct assault from the tiny Scout. But inches before crashing into Huck she swerves, comes behind him, and gives him a monster wedgie. Huck's yelp is two octaves higher than usual. It takes him a few seconds to recover but he grabs Scout's head and proceeds to give her a few dozen noogies. As he looks around for an ink well to dip her hair into, Scout wiggles out of his hold and sticks her tongue out at him. 
 Huck continues to attack her but she easily evades every attempt. While Huck has the strength advantage, it is clear Scout is quicker. She has reverted to a "Rope-A-Dope" strategy, hoping to wear out Huck to the point of exhaustion. She begins to taunt him. 
 "Hey Huck. You from the Show-Me State? You ain't shown me much!" 
 Scout's "Rope-a-Dope" is clearly working. But in the midst of a clever "Your daddy's so drunk" routine, she is shoved from behind. Tom Sawyer has entered the street and pushed her down. Scout goes to the referee to demand a penalty for illegal interference. 
 The referee shows her section 98056.01(4) of the Third Grade Playground Rulebook that states interference by a player's homie is acceptable. 
 Scout is thrown off, expecting another attack by Tom. All of a sudden she puts her two fingers in her mouth and whistles. Out of a nearby house comes Boo Radley. He grabs Tom under the right arm, Huck under the left arm, and smashes their heads together. They go out cold. 
 The referee raises Scout's arm in victory: To Kill a Mockingbird by two knock-outs!

I was in Stockholm, hosted by a librarian. I asked her, "which book should I pick, if I had only one chance to read one?" "the compulsory book in your elementary, er, I forgot.. the American piece" 
 "to kill a mockingbird?" I responded. 
 "that one. yes." 
 So I read it, anyway, it has been 7 years I planned to read the book and I've had already a copy. 
 Soon after I finished the book, I found one thing about this book: it left me with an ugly feeling that I can't describe. You can't expect drama from this book, it is not what it is about. This book is simply invite you to be a part of an ordinary society that time and then elaborate with what's happening there. 
 I think this book is well-written and couldn't be better.
I loved this book. I didn't want to put it down.

I hadn't read To Kill a Mockingbird since it was assigned reading in a high school class, and now I am angry at all the rereads I missed out on in the intervening years. How did 15-year old me not recognize what a masterpiece this was?! Teenagers. 
 Obviously this book is without peers. The language, characters, pacing, plotting, EVERYTHING is beautiful. And the messages of institutionalized hate and racism... at this time, seems particularly relevant. 
 I will certainly not let another 19 years pass without revisiting this book.

I got to 178 and had to put it down. 
 It's an absolute bore. I have read many but this tops the list of boring books. It just seems to drag on and on, and none of these reviews do any justice to it. If you're looking for an interesting book where you grip onto the characters like a lifeline, this book isn't for you. If you like books that seem to drag on, and never end, but in a positive light, this book is definitely not for you. The characters seem to have absolutely no personality and it's difficult keeping up with everyone's goddamn back story. 
 The characters seem just brutally emotionless. 
 I like the plot. It seemed at least somewhat interesting. If this had been written by someone else, this may have been a better book. I have never said that about a book before, but for this book, this is true. 
 Note - English Teachers; if you want your students to have a fiery hate for you that cannot be extinguished, this is the book you want to give your students. But if you want to have less death threats and the look of loathing in your students eyes every time you walk into a room, I'd strongly suggest never bring this book into your class room.

I first read this book in school (middle school, high school?), and I remember thinking it was good at the time. But sometimes it's hard to love something you read when you are required to read it. That is why I try to revisit some of the books I remember liking in school, but wondering at the time why it was assigned and why it was such a big deal. 
 I'm so glad that I re-read this story. It's a great book, and I read it this go around at a time when I really needed to see the goodness in people. Reading this as an adult, I see why its required reading in school; it has a great message. Especially these days, when bullying has become so prominent in schools. There is evil in the world, but we don't have to succumb to it. There are still good people out there, and you can be one of them. 
 This is one of those books that I would recommend to anyone without hesitation, and hope that it has as profound an effect on them as it did on me. Books like this are why I love reading.

Harper Lee's one and only published novel. And now that I've read it I must say that I wish it was not her only published novel. 
 Lee is a magnificent writer and she accomplished to convey in small and short sentences Scout's feelings. It's a book about racism and about the misconception of people who choose or can't help be different and never fit in with the rest of the world. Reading this made me see the world differently and I realized that what we see is not always the entire truth and we sometimes have to be thorough and search deep enough in order to uncover the intact and rather harsh truth. 
 It's not a matter of what we believe is right but rather a matter of how differently each one of us perceive the world and the people living in it. 
 "You never really understand a person until you consider things from his point of view... Until you climb inside of his skin and walk around in it."

All I can say is that you must... 
 If you are to ever decide to visit Alabama, please remember that this is not how our culture is at the present. 
 FYI people, this book just makes me furious! I get so upset by the issue of race. I admit that this is beautifully written, but the events that take place in this book upsets me so much that I can't give it a higher rating than what I have. It has taken me a very long time to finish this read. I think coffee is now required. 
 Cheers!

To Kill a Mockingbird is a powerful book, it brings to light the great social injustice in America. I think the fact that it was written from a child's point of view makes it even more impressive. Since a child asks and says things we all wonder but tend to be (as adults) too afraid to ask. 
 A good example of this is how Scout mentions the hypocrisy of Miss Gates: 
 'Jem, how can you(Miss Gates) hate Hitler so bad but then turn around and be ugly about folks right at home - ?' 
 The person I felt the most sorry for at the end of this novel is Mrs.Robinson, all left alone with no husband, multiple children, no money and having nasty Mr. Ewell chase you; and then just to realize how many real life Mrs.Robinson's there must have been. 
 Overall a great piece of writing and a good introduction to American literature.
This is a timeless and thought evoking book about segregation and justice. It's one of my favorite books that I read with my school.

I don't know how to write a review on a book this spectacular. 
 I can say these things: 
 This book is responsible for my being excused from class because i cried so hard while reading it 
 This book made me appreciate the things I take for granted, such as friendships. 
 This book made me think more than any other I have ever read.

4.5 Stars. I thoroughly (though a little grudgingly at first) enjoyed this novel and concluded by the end that, in my opinion at least, it deserves its high place in literature. I anticipated something rather more depressing, but was pleasantly surprised; the racism was terrible, but Scout's narration lightened the atmosphere and Tom Robinson's case was not without positive ramifications. I also anticipated it being entirely about race-prejudice, but it was more about prejudice and people in general, and the ending delivered that theme with a punch. While it didn't make me cry, it did wrench my gut. 
 The loss of .5 stars was mostly for personal quibbles, especially the fact that I often found Atticus an irritatingly lenient and occasionally unobservant parent. It was also difficult to adjust to the children calling him by his first name. Still, they were respectful, and I did appreciate that.

As a chronic reader, I always wonder why do we read so much? One story after another. And then another. Never satisfied about anything. Always wondering about that new book we bought. Brooding over the books read before. Unfulfilled corner in our room stuffed with books; both read and unread. It's like, we are always hoping for something better in the new book than the last. 
 I can easily say that that is not the case now. After a long time my perpetually hungry soul- that always feeds on the books I read- is downright sated now. I could go for days without having to wonder what to read next. I can bask in this story; a novelty I hadn't had the pleasure of. 
 There are some books/movies that divide your life in two parts; one before you've read it and the one after. Some call them "classics". I always thought it was too bland of a term for something so life-changing. They ought to be called Crossroads(or something). Those who haven't read it travel a whole other path than those who have. This is one of those books. 
 What can I say about the story that hasn't been said already? How can I explain how Harper Lee manifested this gem of a human being- Atticus Finch? If I look at it objectively, I think only a person with Daddy-issues can write a book like this. But then, she just might be a bloody good writer. I could sit here for hours together dissecting every character and explaining to you every line, character and their significance. But, how do I describe this feeling that is too... intangible for words? 
 I believe, that is the power of books.

This may be my second favorite book of all times. 
 Will re-read this many many many times, whenever I can. 
 Beautifully written.

I think that this is a book that deserves its all-time classics rating.

 One of the most major theme is about the racist issue (black/white equality).
