 The spoiler below is the reason for 5 star rating, and that the good story flow and character built-up credits much to it. 
 (view spoiler)[IMO, my favourite part of the book is the court scene, about tom's trial. I was hoping that Atticus could be change the racist mindset but "Guilty" formed the majority vote. The feeling of desolation and despair of Atticus could be felt, at the moment. (hide spoiler)]
Great classic, even though I had to read it in HS. Definitely worth a re-read.

A sweet story, with bittersweet undertones. I can see why people hold it up as a classic. There's a lot of charm, as it's told through the point of view of a perceptive child. Scout has internalized the casual racism and sexism of her culture, but even a 9-year-old can see when things are wrong or unjust. 
 I really enjoyed the language and flow of this book. It pulled me along in a nice way, and I'm glad I read it. But speaking as a reader who prefers high stakes and lots of action, this was a real change of pace. It's sort of like the movie "A Christmas Story." It's a vignette of childhood. An interesting childhood, in a culture that no longer really exists, but still a laid-back and meandering type of tale. 
 To me, some of the dialogue sounded too scripted, like 1950s-1960s movies. Especially towards the end, as Scout draws some conclusions, she sounds a little too graciously adult. I have trouble believing that a 9-year-old would regularly say things like, "Won't you sit down, Mrs. Merryweather?" even in the 1930s. 
 Anyway, aside from that, this book gave me a warm, fuzzy feeling. It's nice to see that some things haven't changed about us humans, no matter what culture we're in. And it's nice to see how things have changed for the better.

In a nutshell: A story of the loss of childhood innocence set in the south in the 1930s focusing on societal issues of rape, the status quo, and racial inequality. 
 I read this book in high school. But, as a person of 15, I couldn't truly appreciate the story until I had more life experience. In high school I thought the book was boring and I just didn't see what the "big deal" about it was. Re-reading it nearly 10 years later, I now understand and believe it is one of the best books ever written. 
 "'Mockingbirds don't do one thing but make music for us to enjoy. They don't eat up people's gardens, don't nest in corncribs, they don't do one thing but sing their hearts out for us. That's why it's a sin to kill a mockingbird.'" (page 119) 
 Jean Louise Finch (Scout) is a typical little girl living in the small fictional town of Maycomb in Alabama. She enjoys a childhood of overalls and roughing it with her older brother, Jem, and her young love, Dill, when he comes to stay with a neighbour in the summer. When she isn't thinking up ways to get a peek at Boo Radley, a mysterious figure that hides in his house, she is getting life lessons from her neighbour Miss Maudie, her family's cook, Calipurnia, or her father and role model, Atticus. But Scout's childlike innocence is lost as she learns cruel life lessons about the differences between rich and poor, good and evil, and right and wrong. In addition to the regular growing pains every person goes through as they mature, Scout learns about old stereotypes and cruelties that exist following the civil war in the south. Atticus is a lawyer and takes on a case to defend Tom Robinson, a black man that stands accused of raping a young white woman. Scout learns of the injustices and inequalities that exist and is shocked and confused at what she experiences as her father is tormented for defending a black man. This is a coming of age story told in the most tragic fashion but is a classic through and through. 
 Before I started to re-read this book, I knew I would feel a lot differently about it now than I did in high school, but I wasn't sure to what extent. And I can honestly say I appreciate the book so much more now as an adult. It's a story that I think everyone should read. When I was in grade 10, I could not appreciate this book nearly as much as I do now. Forgive my teenage ignorance, but I just didn't get the point. I didn't understand. But I do now. 
 In it's own way, the book is tragically beautiful. When I was younger, I thought the story was merely about racial inequality, but I now realize it is so much more than that. It is about children growing up in a society where racial prejudice exists and childlike innocence meets the cruelty of mankind. In a way, it teaches the lesson that ignorance is bliss. And once you gain more knowledge, life can be difficult to understand and you can be left wondering what kind of world we live in. 
 Because this is a classic, I don't want to bother talking about the writing style or the character development (even though the book passes both of my main categories with flying colours) and I want to delve more into the story because I am amazed at how much I love this book after reading it for a second time! 
 When you're in high school, you learn about symbolism and how important it is to classic literature. The green light in The Great Gatsby. The concept of "big brother" in 1984. Simon in The Lord of The Flies. But in my mind, you can't truly appreciate symbolism until you are older. At the end of the day, you can take what your teacher explicitly tells you is symbolic about a novel. You can write an essay about what THEY tell you is symbolic about the novel. But when you are older and you re-read a symbolic novel, you can take your own symbolism from it. And that's what I did this time. 
 I was always perplexed about what Boo Radley was supposed to represent. Why should we care about some creepy, mysterious creature who Scout and Jem are terrified and curious of? They are curious about Boo, but terrified at the same time. I can say that Boo represents maturity. Boo remains a curiosity to the children until the end of the story. Once they "come to terms" with Boo (I don't want to give anything away in case people haven't read this... but I'm sure most people have read this book.), they are arguably a lot more mature and in a sense have come of age by the end of the novel after what happens. In my mind, that is what Boo represents. 
 Next is the perplexing symbol, the mockingbird. Note the quote I use, as said by Miss Maudie to Scout. Most people have argued that the mockingbird represents Boo and Tom Robinson because they are both innocent and wouldn't hurt anything so it is a sin to kill them. In my mind, however, it represents childhood innocence. It is a sin to kill that childlike innocence. In this way, the world is corrupted because we destroy the innocence of children every day by imposing society's expectations, norms, etc onto children. Such is the case in the novel. It is sad that childlike innocence is being killed. For instance, Scout and Jem go to the jail to see Atticus, who is waiting outside the jail to protect Tom Robinson from citizens of the town that wish to do him harm. When a group of men come to harm Tom, they are about to hurt Atticus as well to get him out of the way before the children step in. Scout doesn't seem to know what is happening so she strikes up conversation with her neighbours as if they were visitors for tea. She doesn't understand why they are so angry but she carries on her witty banter. Eventually the small mob leaves, probably because they are taken aback by how innocent Scout is and they don't want to do anything wrong in the presence of the children. The children are also horrified at the cruelty of mankind when they witness Tom Robinson's trial. And those are just some of the examples by which the childrens' innocence is killed throughout the story. 
 So if you have never read this book, or have even not read it for several years, personally I advise you to read it again. It is a flawless story.
It's for Boo okay, I loved that whole aspect of the novel. Everything else, meh.

Confession time: I stopped after three chapters and it took me three months to pick it back up again. Now that I have I really love it. Recommending this to everyone whether they want to read it or not.

At first, I didn't want to read it, but as the story progressed I found that the novel was intriguing, and I wanted to find out what happened next and see what the characters would do. I tend to enjoy classics. I won't say I enjoy them all because there are a few that I wish I never read, but I love the messages that they send and what the books focus on. Classics are a way to look at the past without a history book. A reader can find out all kinds of things about a certain time period by just reading some novels written during that time. I love how To Kill a Mockingbird and other classics open a window into the past, and I will continue to read classics as should others.

In light of reading Go Set a Watchman, I am editing my star rating for this book, from four stars to three. The text of the review hasn't been changed. 
 I don't think there is any other book on Goodreads that has been reviewed by so many of my friends. Most of my friends just plugged in a star value instead of a review. Out of almost 25 ratings, there are only two reviews! Even I used to have a star rating for the book before I deleted it a few years ago, unsure if I'd even read the think. HAVE I ever read To Kill a Mockingbird? I was supposed to. Everyone was. But I don't think I actually did. As I read the book, everything I remembered was from the movie, which admittedly I watched a lot as a child. But anything that wasn't in the movie was completely new to me. 
 I (re?)read Mockingbird in preparation for the "new" Harper Lee novel in a couple of weeks. And I liked it. It has that classic Southern feel, complete with complicated Southern lineage (I learned that a "double cousin" is a real thing. I thought that was just a joke from True Blood), steamy Southern weather and problematic racism. But it goes a bit deeper into the racial dynamic of the time than I expected it to, with thoughts that are surprisingly modern for the time (except for the help, Calpurnia's view on "talking black.") Hell, the way things are going in the United States today, To Kill a Mockingbird still feels relevant. 
 It's an enjoyable read, even if it is a bit uneven. "Part One" is episodic in nature and feels like an entirely different book from "Part Two" which has a traditional plot structure. Part One is more enjoyable, mainly due to the presence of Dill (who is a much deeper and more interesting character than his role as "comic relief" in the movie; I felt for him when he realized his own mother doesn't really want him), and Part Two gets a little too didactic with its politics, but I guess that's how you win a Pulitzer Prize. The title and bird symbolism is heavy handed and doesn't really make any sense. Also, Atticus is so goddamn "good" he borders on naive and ridiculous at times. Atticus calls Mrs. Dubose "the bravest person [he] ever knew," which is an incorrect assessment of an evil, hateful old woman, and tells Scout, about Boo Radley, "Most people are [real nice] when you finally see them." Um, except for Bob Ewell, who just tried to kill two children. I understand he says "most people" but that's a weird note to end a book about injustice on. In fact, the whole Boo Radley portions, while entertaining in the beginning, are the weakest part of the book. He's absent for most of the stronger second half before sweeping in to save the day and disappear again with no explanation. 
 Anyway, despite my criticisms taking up the majority of space in this review, it isn't a negative one. The book has a strong voice and clever sense of humor (maybe it's Truman Capote's ha ha) I'm glad we have many more diverse voices to choose from today, but To Kill a Mockingbird is still relevant in its way.

I first read to Kill a Mockingbird when I was a freshman in high school (about 14 years old). It wasn't a required school reading, but simply something to pass the time during the seemingly long summer vacation. 
 As soon as I finished it, I picked it back up and re-read it. 
 This was the first novel I can think of that gave me an intense roller-coaster ride of emotion. The characters are realistic and relatable. There's mystery. There's suspense. There's heartbreak and anguish and parts that make me so mad I want to spit. But that's what a good book does to you. It makes you feel things and think about the world you live in. 
 The story is from the perspective of Scout Fitch, a tomboy living with her father Attics, and her brother Jem in the fictional town of Maycomb, Alabama. The two children befriend a boy named Dill, who comes to Maycomb each summer to stay with his Aunt. The book is a coming-of-age tale focusing on three children's misunderstanding of the world and people around them. They learn about prejudice, racism, but most importantly they learn not to judge others. 
 I found To Kill a Mockingbird to be an accessible book for readers about 13-14+ years old. There are many wonderful things to take away from this beautifully written and haunting story. I highly recommend it.

The following was a review I wrote April 1. I've since come to view it in a different light, and now believe it's one of the finest books ever written. 
 April 1 
 It's funny how things can change. I recall really liking this book the first time I read it back in about 8th grade. Maybe I should have just left well enough alone. It was a pleasant memory from my youth. Why spoil things by picking it up again as a more clear-sighted (some might say jaundiced)adult? I probably wouldn't view my favorite book from 4th grade, The Secret Weapon, the same way either. The intense drama of a glue-fingered benchwarmer called in at the end of the big game to catch the winning touchdown might seem shallow and contrived to the current me. 
 I realize I'm swimming against the tide here, but how many of you have reread this supposed masterpiece in your more mature years? With that perspective, I can't be the only one to see Scout as the rather obvious wish-fulfillment of Harper Lee. Reading since infancy, brave as any boy, inherently fair-minded, a noble spirit well beyond her years... C'mon, Harper; you've got to give her some flaws mere humans can relate to. Now Jem, in comparison, was a run-of-the-mill dullard. As written, he's not necessarily going to grow up to be the depraved male in a Lifetime movie, but it's clear that Ms. Lee doesn't much care for this kid with the penis. And Dill? How can we not think of him as the future Truman Capote, fat and affected? 
 My real problem with the book, though, now that my blinkers are off, is the pure perfection of Atticus. His progressivity knows no bounds. You're going to tell me that a lawyer is capable of empathy and integrity?!? And where is the complexity of context, you might ask. Wouldn't this son of the South, to be at all realistic, have wrestled a grudge match against himself, his Doppelcracker, if you will? Even modern-day hacks know to include that much conflict. 
 Clearly, Atticus is a balm to assuage white guilt for a nasty racial past, but I wonder if that by itself qualifies as clothes for the emperor. Ironically, people who are happy to applaud the courage Atticus displayed in standing against popular sentiment will likely castigate me for doing the same. 
 Whenever you take an extreme view (and I know I have; even defying Oprah, for chrissake), you have to wonder what that says about you more than it does about the work under review. Maybe had this been March 31 or April 2, I would have felt differently, but today I felt a strange need to rock the Goodreads boat. Did anyone fall out? Happy AFD!

 All I could say is that 'To Kill A Mockingbird' is a really book, not to mention, how honest the language of this book is. Its good to read something that really depicts how unfair the society becomes when racism is involved in cases just like Tom Robinson's case here in this book. 
 This book is either something you read as required in a subject at school or just happened to catch your attention on some ways. I am telling you that this book is very realistic and true to its readers. Maybe Harper Lee is some kind of a peace seeking person and that would be nice to know.

** spoiler alert ** 
 Finally read this eloquent & affecting masterpiece; I've no idea why I never read it as a child. I think it should required reading for children. 
 Scout is a delight and I love her spirit. Also I really identify with Jem's inability to understand how people he believes are good could make such an unjust & biased decision. I've felt that reaction - although thankfully not about anything of such importance - and it is indeed gut wrenching and fills you with such anger and disgust. Atticus and the other characters were wonderful as well.

The narrator, the school-aged girl called "Scout" in a small town in Alabama, feels confused at the drama engulfing her town one summer. Her father protects her innocence by giving her no more information than necessary (His name is Atticus, like the rhetor) and by showing her the parts of his actions that could be perceived as kind. Yet... 
 I am unsure that Go Set A Watchman is a re-telling of the Mockingbird story. Here's why: 
 1. Miss Maudie says that Atticus is doing what others not dare do when he tries to help Tom Robinson win his case. 2. Atticus thinks that Tom had a chance in appeal. 3. The black community stands up as Atticus leaves the courtroom. 4. Judge Tate seems to believe/know that Tom is innocent of rape. 5. Aunt Alexandra acts like she doesn'the understand her brother, but she has left her home on the Landing to support her brother and his family. These things could fit within the construction. Yet the people gathered at Helen Robinson's house gave way to Atticus in Mockingbird while in Watchman, the people gathered there were to some degree angry/frustrated/resentful. With her intuitive ways, she would have sensed any dark emotions or actions when she accompanied Atticus. 
 IMHO, this Mockingbird book is a different book from Watchman. Apparently theyou are related, but are they necessarily the same story with watchman telling more of the truth? As a writer, I know that some days I see the situation from one perspective and other stiles from another perspective. The books don'the have to match up, so I am choosing/deciding for myself that these are two different books. It is art. It is open to interpretation.
This a great story about right, wrong and growing up. Sometimes we need to walk in someone else's shoes to understand.

I did NOT expect to love this one. 
 Don't know why but this book didn't appeal to me much at first sight. My wife had it when we were on vacation, and I ran out of other stuff to read so I picked it up. 
 Unfortunately, my wife didn't like it that much. She had read summary that said the book was about the trial of a black man who had been wrongfully accused, and she was disappointed that the book took soooo long to get to the point. WRONG. 
 This book is not about a trail, it is a time capsule or a snippet of American life. To me, it accomplishes this beautifully. This book is not about it's plot; it's the atmosphere, the beautiful prose that brings rural life in Alabama of the 1930s to life. 
 This accomplishment is precisely why it's considered one of the Great American Novels. I think I'll check out a few more of those.

To Kill a Mockingbird will forever be a classic piece of American Literature. 
 It is a story of how life isn't always fair, told from the innocent perspective of a young girl. 
 I love this story! Much earlier this year I had to write an essay on the movie To Kill a Mockingbird. I'd never seen it before and had no interest in seeing it. Finally, the night before the paper was due, I sat down and watched it. It was so powerful. The acting was amazing and the story was so real. I quickly whipped out an essay about it, and my teacher loved it. I was the only one in my class who liked the movie. 
 The book was a billion times better (if that's possible). The narrative was so perfect. I felt like I was there in every moment. 
 The courtroom scenes were particularly intense, even though I knew the outcome. 
 I am forever grateful to my mom for forcing me to watch the movie and read the book!

The first couple of pages were boring. Maybe the first ten pages. Subject to modern editorial scrutiny, the first few pages wouldn't have passed for publication in my opinion. 
 But slowly, unnoticed, you find yourself inside the mind of Scout Finch. She sucks you into her innocent world, sometimes making you feel warm inside and sometimes icy cold. The world of a seven year old is wonderfully small but also enormously powerful in shaping them. 
 There is always something keeping you reading, the mysterious "Boo" Radley, the adventures with Dill, the big case later on. Most of these seem like snippets of any child's life but the takeaway is big in each. 
 I loved reading it.

This is my 3rd or 4th time reading To Kill a Mockingbird and I think I love it more and more with each read. This was Harper Lee's first and only novel and it garnered her a Pulitzer. The writing, story-telling and subtle nuances of characters absolutely reflects that award. This was a book club read and our discussion ranged from the power of language and literacy, to race relations, to socioeconomic biases, to gender issues, to the role of parents and community and the inherent nature of heroes (i.e. Atticus). It was a wonderful discussion and I was reminded, yet again, how much I adore the group of people in my book club, and how much I need this kind of intellectual interaction. Read this, if you don't love it I'm not sure if we can be friends.

The 1st time I read this, I was in grade 8. It left a permanent, positive impression on my views of literature & it's roles in society. I've always just considered it one of those milestone books, that's my mistake. 
 When teaching difficult literature, the teacher should approach it in a mature, educated & responsible way. The racial themes should be addressed in a sensitive & age appropriate way. I firmly believe every country, province/state, city & community has their own racial tensions. After so many generations & centuries, it's still a widespread global problem. Books like this are fantastic for introducing these difficult topics to today's children in an accessible, challenging way. 
 If we stop reading these milestone books, how can we develop empathy or introduce meaningful conversations about racism that still plagues our society? Well written novels such as this one, are a great way to explore racial themes in a deep & meaningful way. 
 Book banning & censorship is something I'm firmly against except in very rare, exceptional occasions. This book includes themes that are commonly brought up in social discussions or heated debates at a dinner table. 
 In short, I wouldn't support banning this book or removing it from educational schools.

Okay, I have to admit it. Yes, I am reviewing this book because I got a copy of Go Set a Watchman. Is that a bad thing? Not really. The fact that Watchman came out only insures that I review this book now, and not a month, or a year from now. Yet, because of the tremendous amount of hype surrounding the new book, I couldn't help but hear some things about it, despite my best intentions. I usually try to go into a book could, only going into other reviews when I can't seem to decide what to make of the novel I just read. In the case of To Kill a Mockingbird then, my viewpoint on this novel hasn't really changed, despite some of the controversial things that occur in Watchman. 
 As with my Hunger Games review, I don't think that my review of this novel is absolutely necessary. With this novel, that statement holds even more weight. This story has become so interwoven into the American culture over the past 50 years that I'm surprised a beer cooler that says "I *heart* 'Merica", with the heart dressed up to look like the American flag no less, doesn't come with every purchase. This novel does teach about the racism of the south during the 1930's, but it also teaches about empathy, and has more moral lessons than you can shake a stick at, which is perhaps the best portion of the novel. 
 These many moral lessons come to the novel because of Scout, the main character. Because she is the main character, there are many more moral platitudes that she is told by her father Atticus. Because she is a child, she is still learning about things like empathy and how to work with others in different social settings. Her brother Jem is also an awesome character. This is really a coming of age story for him, more so for Scout. He goes from a boy at the beginning if the story who reenacts plays with his little sister, to a man who understands the racism of his hometown, and how black people are treated unfairly. 
 One advantage that I like is that many different lessons that are taught by Atticus, are not simply there for the reading audience, they are actually exhibited in the novel, later on. For example, in one scene, Atticus explains to Scout about empathy, with his now famous words about how you can't know what someone is going through until you get into their skin and walk around in it. What I like is this plays back on the novel later on, when Mr. Ewell spits on him after the trial. Atticus allows this to happen because, from Ewell's point of view, Atticus destroyed any reputation he had left. This empathy shows that Atticus knows how to not only talk the talk, but also walk the walk. 
 I have heard some critics say that Atticus is a character who does not seem real, and who is more comparable to a shining knight whom we all should look up to. I think this is both correct, and incorrect. Yes, he is put into a positive light, but I believe that this is only because of the fact that Scout, the main character is a woman writing about her time as a child. When one is a child, everything seemed to be nicer and better, especially in hindsight. Scout may be showing us the side of Atticus that she wants us to see, and that she saw herself. Atticus may have not wanted to let others see his worry and self doubt about his job and the Tom Robinson case. Regardless, this character was one whom I really enjoyed, and is someone who I want to read about next in Watchman. 
 I think that this novel is an excellent story about life in a small southern town, told from the viewpoint of a child. Despite the language, which some may find difficult to get into, I thought it was humorous and very entertaining. The only time I was confused by the text was when the text mentioned southern slang for certain items. I still think that it was very well written, especially the phonetic spelling of the language. It made for a very good read, and it is one I won't soon forget. I give it a five out of five.

I'm sure there are those out there who don't like this book, but I'd be hard-pressed to understand why; I love everything about it. The music of the language. The characters. The portrait of Southern, small-town life and a moment of transition from one time into the next. The themes. Scout's relationships with her brother and her father. 
 Most of the time I don't reread my favorite books: they mark a moment in my life when they touched me and remain as ghostly reminders into my present. But I think this is the sort of book that grows as its readers grow, and I look forward to discovering what it has to offer my future self.

She is so naive and also smart and funny, and will definitely make you lough. She is the narrator, and Lee really succeeded to give the perspective of a young child. This is really a super must-read! (just have patience to go through the first chapter and later you can't stop). 
 And it is worth to cite Scout here for all of us who love and breath reading: 
 "Until I feared I would lose it, I never loved to read. One does not love breathing."
It's in my top five books of all-time.
I cannot believe that I let an awful English teacher from 8th grade make me hate this book for years. It wasn't the book's fault at all.

Classic though it may be, I have to say that this was very "basic" to me. 
 I know I read this years ago in high school, but I literally have no memory of it, or my feeling toward it then. Unlike The Scarlet Letter which I read around the same time and loved ( though I'm sure I was the only one in the class who did. 
 To start with, I didn't like the character's. Scout really annoyed me most of the time. And I found Atticus to be an extremely weak character. Does he have principles, yes, but he let's others raise and discipline his children, including his housekeeper and sister. 
 I also didn't care for how black and white the trial was.

"Don't judge a book by it's cover." The underlying message of To Kill a Mockingbird is simple, straightforward and frequently employed throughout Harper Lee's classic novel. It's a good message, and for those who might find it banal and overused, it's one that we as a society have still clearly not learned in the last 55 years. There isn't much complexity in this book, but Lee executes everything to perfection, from her portrayal of curious, open-minded Scout to meticulous, wise and just Atticus to the hypocrisies and prejudices of their fellow Maycomb County residents. It's an easy read, but it seems every page contains one shining truism. And yet for all the obvious arguments in favor of giving every person the benefit of the doubt and granting equality for all, there is some question as to whether Lee sees those rights extending to woman. The clash of tomboy Scout with her Aunt Alexandra and the supposed civilized ladies is a recurrent theme throughout. But then Lee writes of the qualifications for rape "Apparently you had to kick and holler, you had to be overpowered and stomped on, preferable knocked stone cold." This is Scout's rendition of how her brother describes rape, so there is the strong possibility of irony here, but this definition hardly encompasses the nuances of sexual violence rightly understood by contemporary law, where a victim may not offer physical resistance, yet still feel violated. Later, Atticus tells Scout "There's nothing more sickening to me than a low-grade white man who'll take advantage of a Negro's ignorance," followed two paragraphs later by "Miss Maudie can't sit on a jury because she's a woman." The juxtaposition should be obvious to a modern reader, which raises questions about Lee's intent in these scenes. Is she merely stating the legal standing of the times, ignorant of their implications for the rights of woman? Or does Lee's social critique extend to gender equality, woven into the backdrop of a novel overtly promoting racial equality? I'm inclined to believe the latter. Whatever Lee's intentions, this reading makes To Kill a Mockingbird a far more complex book, forcing the reader to consider Tom Robinson's rape trial more carefully and chipping away at Atticus' moral sainthood. In either case, To Kill A Mockingbird deserves to be read for its deft and powerful betrayal of the pitfalls of prejudice.

Actual rating-3.5 It was an interesting book with some interesting themes and a few exciting scenes, but not enough to wow me or outweigh the boring sections. I read this for school and had been meaning to read this for a while; it being a classic and all. I can't say that I was as impressed as I felt I should have been, since both of the ninth grade English teachers(and my sixth grade teacher)at my school claim it as their favorite novel. 
 The characters were alright. The main protagonist, Scout, I found to be lacking. I was hoping to feel the youthfulness radiating out of her, creating a refreshing view on the subject. Although her age was a main element of the story, it just didn't create the feeling that it should have. I did, however, really enjoy the character of Atticus Finch. He was an interesting father and an even more interesting lawyer. And of course there was the mysterious figure, Boo Radley. 
 As for the plot of this story, there really was none until the second half of the book. Part one of the book was filled with various short stories about the children and their everyday life, which could have been interesting, but unfortunately were pretty boring. I have heard from my classmates, though, that they loved the book specifically for part two. I can agree that part two, especially the court scene, was pretty enjoyable. The topic of racism was strong, and I found myself constantly questioning the ways of southern life after the end of slavery, but before the end of prejudice. The ending of the story, though, which was supposed to reveal the entire point of the story(so I had heard), didn't hit as hard as it could/should have. 
 Overall, this book did explore an interesting view of the past, and the issues of racism, and prejudice. The title of the book also brought up some important symbolism. I will say that this book is not on the top of my list of favorite classics, mainly because I found it too simplistic. Maybe I didn't read it correctly. I'll probably try this book again in a few years.

Many years ago I saw and loved the film adaptation starring Gregory Peck, but I never got to reading the book until a couple of weeks ago. Peck's impeccable portrayal of Atticus Finch has always stuck in my head. As I was reading the book, many scenes of that film kept coming back, but I already forgot how the story ends. 
 The story still moves me deeply, as the themes of human compassion, parenting, friendship, racial prejudices and class discrimination are evocatively explored. The voice of the narrator as a nine-year-old girl makes the story all the more endearing. 
 These quotes of Atticus's impress me most: 
 "You never really understand a person until you consider things from his point of view, until you climb into his skin and walk around in it." 
 "They're certainly entitled to think that, and they're entitled to full respect for their opinions. But before I can live with other folks, I've got to live with myself. The one thing that doesn't abide by majority rule is a person's conscience." 
 Perhaps this passage is the most striking in the whole book for its piercing poignancy: 
 (view spoiler)["Atticus had used every tool available to free men to save Tom Robinson, but in the secret courts of men's hearts Atticus had no case. Tom was a dead man the minute Mayella Ewell opened her mouth and screamed." (hide spoiler)] 
 However, what really gets to me is the ending, which was disquieting enough to make me take away one star. Heck Tate's (the sheriff's) decision (view spoiler)[to falsify Bob Ewell's cause of death in order to protect Boo (Arthur) Radley from being charged (hide spoiler)] is obviously based on a flawed reasoning. But Atticus's (view spoiler)[ultimate acquiescence to it (hide spoiler)] seems to overturn (view spoiler)[the very principles of honesty that he has been fighting so hard to uphold, both as a lawyer and as a parent (hide spoiler)]. To me, this is a disappointing ending to an otherwise brilliant novel.

Hmmm, I'm not the biggest fan of this book to be quite honest. I did like it, it was nice, but it just didn't capture me. I took me long enough to read it,that I lost the connection with it. I found interesting the scenery and the relationships between people in this particular time and place. It was a light read though, so if you are looking for something lighter, you should grab "To kill a mockingbird".

I love it when karma bares its ugly teeth in the world of stories. Not so much in real life. I like it more when it's obvious that it really was characters' own fault, not the author's twiddling with the plot. 
 This is one of those books that is famous enough that a review from someone like me will disappear into the dust, so I'll leave the real reviewing to the real reviewers. 
 I have to admit, most of the book's attraction for me after the midway point was the character of Atticus-he is almost the polar opposite of my own dad, who contradicts me and then laughs at me when I explain the danger of Beijing flooding due to global warming. And while Atticus's strong sense of justice has its ups and downs for his children, I'd be happy nevertheless, focussing on the assets. 
 I fell asleep during the first few chapters. Especially when I read the first page, and it seemed so, how do I say this, American. Football. Southern towns. And while I have nothing against Americans, it gets aggravating when pretty much every single book you read takes place in a setting unfamiliar to you. 
 So I fell asleep partly because of that, and partly because the atmosphere is sleepy and quiet and the first half of the book basically chronicles the 'adventures' of a small-town girl half my age with a bookish father. 
 I kept going, because, well, I had to. Somewhere along the road someone decided that the study of this particular book had to be implanted in every. Ninth-grade. English. Course. Then things got more interesting: I soaked in every single word of the trial of Tom Robinson-will not go into details for fear of spoilers-and what proceeded it was absolutely unexpected, (or maybe not so much, considering how utterly realistic Harper Lee gets), which makes it expected for me. In well-written books, I must expect the unexpected. 
 What happened after that only intensifies the ethical struggle when the town is split into two sides: those who believe in equal rights and those who take on the infamous attitude of the south. What is obvious to us these days never reached the thoughts of most of the jury, the Maycomb residents. 
 One qualm, I think, is the role of Dill in this story. His character seemed to have no greater purpose in the plot than sparking Scout's curiosity and acting as a friend to her and Jem. He was an interesting character and I would've liked to see him adopt a greater role. 
 The writing itself is amazing-Lee has a major talent for narrating. 
 Also the slightly abrubt ending seems to rest uneasily with the other reviewers on this site. I'm wondering if Harper Lee simply wanted to end it there, or if it was because she couldn't think of a way to wrap it up. Probably the former. 
 A/N: Other people have mentioned their non-appreciation of this book when they were in high school, apparantly because they were in high school. I suddenly realize there must be something very, very, wrong with me...

I picked this book at first because its considered a master piece of american literature, so I was curious... 
 Even though it seems that the story is written for children it's very much deeper that that. Considering the era when it was written, now I totallly understand why it's considered an American Classic. 
 To Kill a Mockingbird shows some facts from human nature, such as racism and discrimination through the eyes of a little girl. And after reading it I was marveled of how simple is life if you keep seenig things as a child. 
 For me, this is one new favorite

To Kill a Mockingbird by Harper Lee is a feel-good book for me. A read "again and again" book for me. 
 Set in Alabama in the 1930's, the story is told by "Scout" Finch, the young daughter of lawyer Atticus Finch. To say that it is the story of racist America in the 1930's would be an understatement. Yes, Atticus is defending a black man accused of raping a 19 year old white girl, but it is more than just about racism. It is about coming of age for Scout and her brother Jem. It is about "family" and "neighbours", and having a father who teaches his children right from wrong. 
 This book is a classic !

Such an amazing book. it took me so long to read because I wanted to really understand the book and since the writing style was different for me, I took what would seem like forever. But I finished it! And I'm so glad I did.

I learned a lot with this book, I don't want to tell you anything about it because in my opinion you have to figure it out by reading it. 
 This is the perfect example that books can help you change your mind.

I am pretty sure I read this in high school. It wasn't mandatory reading like I think it is here. Either way, I didn't remember it at all so it was like reading for the first time. It took me a bit to get into and I can understand how people might get bored and give up, but I'm glad I didn't. I wasn't expecting to love it, but I did. I don't know what else to say about it that hasn't already been said (a bazillion times) so I'll just say SO GOOD, so good, so good.

This book surprised me a lot. I didn't really know what it was about when I got it for christmas, only that it was famous. Now that I've read it I still can't say what it is about, beacause it's so much stuff. But I can say I really liked reading To Kill a Mockingbird. There is something naive and sweet about a story about people (not only child) told in the POV of an eight-year-old, it changed things and made for a great book.

I wrote 2 reviews today so I don't really want to deal with this one too right now. Shortly, this book is many things and after the last few ones I've read this week, it felt kinda like taking a break, thanks to it's lack of symbolism. To Kill A Mockingbird is a very enjoyable read. Too bad there aren't any other books by Harper Lee!

This book (and the Gregory Peck movie) go in the category of "things I somehow missed in high school". I knew the rough storyline and was familiar with the characters, but that's about it. 
 Really enjoyed my time reading this tale. Especially well crafted was how the story of the trial bumped along at the edge of Scout's narrative for the first third of the book. Truly a timeless classic.

I didn't realise it was such an iconic book, Pulitzer prize, 30 million copies sold etc... I was intrigued by the text on the back cover. Which said the book is about a rape case where a black man is charged. 
 The story started to fold out nicely, the kids were cute and real - but where is the case? I was growing very impatient! And then the whole thing was done in 20 pages or so. Huhh? 
 I only realised at the end of the book that the back cover description was ALL WRONG and it ruined my reading experience of this book. I'm so sad I could scream! 
 The book is about the kids and their secretive neighbour. I don't know who wrote the back text I despise so much, but he deserves to be sacked!

Rating: 3.5/5

Our book club had chosen this for tonight's selection. Most of those present had read and loved it in the past, and did not feel like discussing it tonight. I kept meaning to read it before book club, but put it off in favor of e-books I'd been postponing. 
 Anyway, I did not read it before book club. My daughters and others keep saying I should read this someday. I plan to do so. Someday. 
 In the meantime, I've several paranormal romances in the pile.

A classic, but I'd be lying if I said it spoke to me personally. It gets two stars for two vivid scenes that stuck with me: Weaning the old woman off of her drug addiction, and Scout's showdown with the vigilantes.
A book I had to read in high school. Nothing about in which I found interesting or redeeming in the least. I hated the characters and the storyline and the book just dragged on.
Obviously, this is a very important book. Very thought provoking, very realistic. The words painted the pictures in my mind so easily.

I've read this book about 3 times. I've also seen the movie, and of course, I prefer the book. Although, the movie isn't far off the book as a lot of movies tend to be. I love the way it is told. It's probably my favorite out of all the classics.
I read this in high school, and like most books I was forced to read, I felt "meh" about it. I think I should give it another chance now that I'm older.

I'd say I'd give this a solid 3.5 (damn you Goodreads, for not having half stars). 
 I really appreciate the story and the ideas of the book, however the ending felt a bit too abrupt for my tastes and in some areas the book seemed to meander a bit. Since almost everyone has read this book at one point or another that's all I'm really going to say, just wanted to give my reasons for the 3.5 :P
I think this is my favorite book ever written. It has pain and triumph, characters and plot, great dialogue and clear prose. There is a reason this is an all-time classic.

I reread this book this year and I loved it so much more than reading it as an adolescent. Harper Lee, you are an amazing author. This book has so much to praise. 
 First of all, the narrator of Scout is amazing. This kind of story would likely be much easier to tell from an adult's perspective as adults (sometimes) have a better understanding of the workings of the world. What makes this book unique is that Scout often sees and hears things that she can't make sense of, so you have to. And this is done in such a way as to not spell everything out for the reader either. 
 And obviously, the content of this book is incredible. What I love about this story is that it wasn't an unrealistic happily ever after. But it did end on a somewhat positive note. This book does not leave you with a sigh of relief from a perfectly resolved ending, but it leaves you with a sadness with just a hint of hope. Those are some of my favorite endings.

I would give this book 10 stars if I could. A friend of mine in my book group just recently posted a review of this--the audio book version read by Sissy Spacek. I thought she had a brilliant idea, to reread this pending the release of the long-awaited (and probably not very good, or it would have been published many decades ago!) sequel, so I followed in her footsteps. I had just read a particularly pathetic novel (The Orphan Train, reviewed elsewhere, and pathetic despite the big splash it has enjoyed), and this one, which I had not read for a number of years, shone all the brighter in comparison. This is a book. This is a book that everyone should read--everyone! And I have to agree with my friend that it could not be better read than Ms. Spacek did it. I am not a particular fan of hers, but I will never think of Scout again without hearing her speak in that perfect accent. Not only was the southern drawl ideal, but Ms. Spacek obviously understands and appreciates every word of the novel. A real joy.

How did she even write this? How did she come up with this idea? 
 Brilliant.

To Kill a Mockingbird is a book that can change your perspective on life and how you live it. Atticus Finch is a noble character who lives in an unjust world, and you see this injustice through an intersting perspective: the eyes of his daughter, Scout. An engaging read, but it made me want to get up and throw something against the wall: I can't stand the unfairness of life...

I'VE FINISHED IT !!!!! Because I didn't need several months to read it. Nope. Not at all. 
 Anyway. I won't write a real review because there are literally thousands of them out there, and because mine wouldn't change your life. Which is why I'm going to do this for ME. Just so I can remember what I thought about it. 
 I liked the fact that it was written form a child's POV. (And successfully, too.) Thing is, the younger we are, the more we see things with an innocent's eye.I liked that throughout the book, Scout never judged anyone and simply gave the facts, which allows the reader to make up his own mind. 
 I liked how Harper Lee showed us how much a child can change in only a few years. 
 I liked that HP wasn't afraid to write about taboo subjects, and I liked that she did it with enough finesse not to offense anyone. 
 To me, To kill a mockingbird is about acceptance, prejudice, and life lessons. 
 The back of my book says Harper Lee always considered her book to be a simple love story. At first, I didn't understand how it could be a love story. When I actually thought about it, though, I understood it wasn't a love story between a girl and a boy, but rather a love story between a girl and all who surround her. -Her father, her brother, her neighbors, the old lady she hated, the guy she'd never even seen and the black people.

One of the books that wasn't on my high school reading lists, but after reading the book, what a masterpiece it is. Not only was the book extremely engaging to the point that I couldn't put it down, but it was a beautiful coming-of-age novel expertly-plotted with a really strong theme. Most people think about this book because of its reflections on racism, and rightly so since the book makes a powerful point with regards to character and the importance of standing up for unpopular truth. And yet it isn't just a book about racism. It's a book about human life. And a beautiful one at that. 
 Rating: 4.5-5 Stars (Excellent).

<<Overview>> 
 A timeless and relevant classic that should be read by everyone at least once in their lifetime. 
 Lively, memorable characters that jump off the page and get under your skin, forcing you to look inwards and analyze yourself and your opinions. 
 It's written in such an intoxicating mixture of colloquial speech and literary beauty that by the time you're done, you're drunk on southern slang and hazy Maycomb summers. 
 WARNING: May contain spoilers. 
 <<Plot & Concept>> 
 What can I say about this book that hasn't already been said? I came to it late in the game, never having it assigned in school, and being too obsessed with fantasy to pick it up on my own in those formative years. I can't say whether reading it then would have made an impact, but I can say it's made one now. In my 20's, during this tumultuous time in the media, there is a message here that is just so, so relevant. I feel everyone should either be reading or re-reading this right now. 
 It's a wonderful story that is both heartwarming and heartbreaking at the same time. It's all about not basing an opinion on someone before you know them, based solely on the color of their skin, or their wealth, or a rumor blown out of proportion. 
 <<Characters & Relationships>> 
 TO KILL A MOCKINGBIRD would be nothing without its characters. 
 Scout is an enchantingly sassy southern girl, with a brain and an opinion about everything. She's crass and full of contradictions, but she's smart and inquisitive and open to everything around her, just like we all are as kids, before the world gets to us. She's a bit of a fish out of water in her community, preferring to explore and roughhouse and wear overalls, than to wear her Sunday best and small talk with town society. She calls people out on the things they say, but she loves with a fierceness and a loyalty that surpasses all else. She's the genuine article, a classic character that will never age and always remain relevant in some form or fashion. 
 Oh, Atticus. It's because of Atticus Finch that we have Scout, and I can now finally see why so many people have idolized him for so long. As a father figure, he is perceptive in a way that most modern characters couldn't even begin to be (and real life fathers as well). He's the dad we all wished we'd had, but can still see glimmers of him in our own fathers. He's wise and kind, and challenges his children on an emotional and moral level, an area parents oftentimes seem to neglect. He treats them like tiny adults, as opposed to silly children, and it makes Scout and Jem who they are. He's incredibly brave for taking the stance he did in the era he exists in. Perhaps he has been put on a pedestal by readers, but who's to say he doesn't belong there? 
 <<Style>> 
 It's a shame Harper Lee didn't write more, but perhaps it makes TO KILL A MOCKINGBIRD all the more special that she didn't. It's written in such an intoxicating mixture of colloquial speech and literary beauty that by the time you're done, you're drunk on southern slang and hazy Maycomb summers. 
 The conversational tone makes the novel fly by, but also forces you to pause and read passages over and over again to absorb the beauty and meaning of the words. Being in Scout's brain is a fascinating place to be, and I found myself reluctant to leave it and move on to other books. 
 <<Quotes>> 
 All quotes are from the 2006 Harper Perennial Modern Classics paperback edition. 
 * "Ladies bathed before noon, after their three-o'clock naps, and by nightfall were like soft teacakes with frostings of sweat and sweet talcum." pg. 6 
 * "'...You want to grow up to be a lady, don't you?' 
 I said not particularly." pg. 90 
 * "'An' they chased him 'n' never could catch him 'cause they didn't know what he looked like, an' Atticus, when they finally saw him, why he hadn't done any of those things...Atticus, he was real nice...' 
 His hands were under my chin, pulling up the cover, tucking it around me. 
 'Most people are, Scout, when you finally see them.'" pgs. 322-323 
 And a million others. The whole book is one big, perfect quote. 
 <<Cover Love>> 
 There have been many covers over the years, and I love the classic cover of my paperback edition. The soft green, deep navy, and punchy, rusty orange are lovely to look at, and that wonderful stripey spine looks to pretty on a shelf. But I have have a fondness for these editions as well: 
 {Popsugar 2015 Reading Challenge: a book your mom loves}

I haven't read this book since high school when they made me but I still love it and think I always will. I wasn't one of those kids who had books in their house or whose dad spoke in lines of Shakespeare or whatever, so this is basically the first book I remember reading other than Goosebumps (which totally sucked by the way). It was that book that was like WHOA READING CAN BE COOL and so I was basically a reader as soon as I finished reading this book and went to a bookstore for the first time in my life and bought Intensity by Dean Koontz. To Kill A Mockingbird was recently voted the best novel of all time, which is a shame because it's not very good. It's incredibly simplistic, for one thing. Mrs. Dubose's story is like an afterschool special. And it's insufferably folksy and preachy. Atticus comes off as awkwardly as Lawrence Fishburne's character in Boyz in the Hood. 
 It's aged poorly because for a book about not being racist, it comes off pretty paternalistic these days. And there are mid-20th-century books that deal with race in ways that haven't aged poorly, like Native Son, Their Eyes Were Watching God and Invisible Man. 
 The mighty Flannery O'Connor says, "I think for a child's book it does all right. It's interesting that all the folks that are buying it don't know they're reading a child's book. Somebody ought to say what it is." Which she did, so I don't have to.

What a beautiful read. Scout is now one of my favorite literary characters, ever. I read this in high school but had very few memories of it. Such a moving experience. Beautiful characters, lessons and writing.
To Kill a Mockingbird (Harper Pernnial Moderns Classics) by Harper Lee (2006)

Brilliant! 
 This is one of those classics that I have been meaning to read, but never got around to. After Harper Lee's passing, I determined that I had put it off too long. 
 I can understand how many people could be put off by the book. The first third is slow to progress, but it sets the tone and the backstory for the remaining two thirds; 1930's Alabama as seen through the eyes of a child. Racial inequality, class differences, and gender inequality are just some of the ideas portrayed by Lee, with a lot of it based on her own upbringing. 
 Jean Louise, aka Scout, so desperately wants to grow up so that she can hopefully understand what is happening in the world around her. A black man is convicted of rape, even though the evidence clearly shows he did not do it. Some children come to school while others stay home and work on the farm. The world, as seen through Scout's eyes, seems unfair and confusing. That's the point. Sometimes it takes someone as innocent as a child to point out the follies in life. 
 I don't want to rehash the entire novel, as it has been done by thousands before me. I do however feel that this is one of the most important novels of the 20th century. People may not like the language or the subject matter, but it does show life in 1930's Alabama. In order to know where we are going, it's important to know where we've been, and this novel shows us how far we have come. It is also shows us that we still have a long way to go.

I finally read one of the most iconic novels of all time as known as To Kill a Mockingbird. This novel shows the point of view a white Southern girl living in the 1930s, Scout Finch. Scout lives with her sibling, Jem, and their solitary father, Atticus, in the languid Southern town of Maycomb. In To Kill a Mockingbird, we see three important years of Scout's life; we see childhood innocence transform to corrupted adulthood. 
 Lee explores significant themes such as the coexistence of good and evil, significance of moral education, existence of social inequality, and how appearances can be deceiving. Lee shows these themes in just one court case: a young white woman, Mayella Ewell, accuses a young black man, Tom Robinson, of rape. This is where the novel gets intense. Atticus is called on to defend the defendant, Tom Robinson, and soon Scout, Jem, and their friend Dill find themselves caught up in events outside their ability to grasp. 
 Read more at: http://fullofbooks.com/to-kill-a-mock...

After reading it in 7th grade review: 
 It's funny. Most times when I read classics like this book, Oliver Twist, War of the Worlds, Of Mice and Men, etc. etc. they always get 4 stars. I don't think that half of them even deserve that many, you know? I think I just give them 4 stars because it's a classic and all and you're SUPPOSE to like it. Not that this book is like that, because I actually liked this book. I guess because I just naturally like historical books like this. Good book. A classic classic. 
 After reading it with my class review: 
 Let me start off by saying I didn't read this book twice. I stopped reading with my class around the 29th chapter. Also, I still believe that this book is just one of those classics that everyone reads and is SUPPOSED to be good. This book I realized was just okay. When i read it in 7th grade it seemed so riveting and...mature. I think that was because of the court case and Mayella talked about the rape and stuff. But then I read that part again and realized I've read better court scenes before...I can't remember where but I have. And I just think that if Lee had made the court case longer or something and hadn't ended it the way she did this classic novel would've been right on my imaginary shelf(along with The Catcher in the Rye) titled "Classic novels I actually really liked".
I have now caught up with every high school freshman... but seriously, so so so good. And honest. And too sleepy for a real review.

I loved this book even more the second time around. I think it's especially relevant today, where our country is so divided. Whether or not Atticus was right, I thought it interesting when he told Scout to respect other people's opinions, regardless of how wrong they were. 
 This book just made me feel so nostalgic for my own childhood, and I teared up a few times. Loved the writing as well as the overarching message.

I meant to read this book years ago and never got around to it. Finally, I got it in the mail two days ago and finished it tonight. The themes were familar to me, but certainly because it has been copied since it was published so I kept an open mind about it. From the first sentences, the craftmanship of the writing made it obvious why this is such a classic. Simply beautiful. I also loved how the different angles- the children and Boo Radley, Atticus as a lawyer, Atticus as a father, and the Finches and the community of Maycomb relating or conflicting with each other, all stood on their own and almost could have developed into seperate, stand alone stories.

I had been looking forward to reading this one for so long, especially when "Go Set a Watchman" was released. 
 It's a good story with great characters. It's hard not to like Scout or Jem, or the awesome team they're together. 
 My favorite character is Atticus, though. I felt so proud for him to be just as he is, and I understand why his children respect him so much. He is all what a good lawyer should be: loyal, smart, confident, patient. He was so focus on always doing the right thing no matter the consequences, and that's awesome! 
 I was really shocked by how strong the racism was present at the time; I believe that's the reason behind all the success of this book: it perfectly showed the social reality of that period. 
 I did enjoy the book and learn a lot from it; however, the events went at a slow pace most of the time, so I lost interest at certain moments. For me, the trial was the best part in the entire book! It had my undivided attention from beginning to end. 
 This book is good, and I can see why it represents such an important legacy for literature and history and lawyers. 
 I did enjoy the book and learn a lot from it; however, the events went at a slow pace most of the time, so my interest went down at certain moments.
THIS WAS SO MUCH BETTER THE SECOND TIME AROUND!!!! I could truly understand everything, and analyze it better. This was such a spectacular book, EVERYONE NEEDS TO READ!!

Dang it, I had no dog'garn idea this was anything less than a good book. 
 The story is a good story. The movie is a good movie. The message can resonate within us all and help us teach our youth. But the book was not good enough to get me to finish it. 
 I thought this was supposed to be about a black guy who gets picked on by all the intolerant white folk. Except the book never actually seemed to get there and let us meet the guy. Instead, it's just a bunch of kids playing around the neighborhood. 
 And the father... such a representation of righteousness! Smart, always on the side of good, patient... 
 Stuff happens... and then some more stuff... kids will be kids. And then... yeah... I just couldn't read about anymore stuff before getting to the point. The writing didn't flow. 
 There are some good and memorable scenes, there's just too much stuff and it's not written strongly enough, even with some wit and humor, to come together.

OH MY GOODNESS GRACIOUS THIS BOOK IS SO GOOD. I read it for the second time and I got even more into the book than the first. Harper Lee builds her little town and its cast of characters up so well, it's like they're your own neighbors. The writing is amazing, and I loved Atticus even more. Atticus is a true hero. Scout and Jem are always near and dear to my heart, and Miss Maudie was as sassy and outspoken as she always was. (I aspire to be her) I finally figured out what Miss Maudie meant when she said "His food doesn't stick going down, does it?" and now that is one of my favorite lines of the book. Such a great classic; I'd recommend it to anyone.
This is my favorite book that was a required read so far. I loved Scout and Jem and Boo and Attucus and everyone (except Mr. Ewell of course)
One of the best forced school read books ever. So well written. Too bad Harper Lee never wrote another book. One day I want to read it again, just for fun this time.

Having grown up in Europe in a non-English speaking country, I was not aware of this book in high school when a lot of people (had to) read it. 
 But since most of my book friends declared it a must-read classic, I decided to catch up with everyone else. 
 The characters are brought to life wonderfully, and I loved how the main protagonist describes her world from a child's perspective without coming across as childish. I found it hard to put down, and read the most of this in one weekend. 
 I can certainly see why this is a brilliant book to read with hishschoolers.

First read on 3-10-14 
 Really there isn't anything I could say about this book that hasn't already been said besides this: PLEASE read this book! No matter if you live in the U.S., Japan, France, or on the moon. You absolutely need to read this book before you die. It is one of the best books I have ever read and reading it a second time, like I just did, made more points a lot clearer in the book. Please, just go buy/check out/borrow this book at the next chance you get. You will not be disappointed

so i missed some things from when i read it the first time. 
 but it turned out better than when i first read it so... yay?
that was really moving. more people should read this book.

I found this a very interesting and quite a beautiful book, it looks at social class, understanding of others and racial discrimination in the mid 1930's in Alabama as seen through the eyes of a child. 
 I can see why it is seen as a classic by so many. The story ambles along, or perhaps that is how I read it based on the narrative, and I ambled along with it. Knowing this is based on Harper Lee's own childhood I found the concepts in the book quite powerful, perhaps more so than I would had this fact not been told to me before I started reading. 
 There isn't much to say about the story itself without ruining it for someone, sometimes nothing much happens, sometimes a lot happens, but it's not really about the events as such, more so the understanding and change that happens within Scout who is too young to understand a lot of what she sees and hears at the time.

Just finished reading this with the 10th graders. Nice to know the jaded sophomores still have some innocence. They were totally shocked that Atticus didn't succeed in getting Tom acquitted - even though the last three reviews of the book I've read discussed his conviction as a foregone conclusion and focused on other ways Lee was able to build suspense. I loved this book when I was their age, and it's awesome that so many of them loved it too - even though it's way above their reading level, and even though some of them hate books in general.
Loved her(the author's) style of describing everything. This will be one the books which would have influence on me.

reread as an adult and utterly loved it. 
 ETA: Going to flesh out my thoughts a bit more now that I am at home and have a computer. As a teenager, I just couldn't get into this one. The only assigned HS book I loved was Brave New World, and 1984 to an extent, but I bought this as an adult and devoured it. My review went from a 3 to a 5 and I now see why it's a classic. Although the writing wasn't all there, and it felt like a Truman Capote book at times (ahem...), I loved it and will pass my copy along to a friend who is a newly minted American and needs to find out more about the country and our history.

To Kill a Mockingbird was another freshman year required read. I thought the classic novel was interesting, and I loved the characterization and the portrayal of the story's theme: discrimination--especially racial. 
 Atticus Finch was my favorite character: calm, collected, and intellectual. On the other hand, the narrator, Scout Finch, was not one of my favorites, probably because of her naivety (though what can I expect? she's six or so). 
 I felt that the story dragged on in some places, and at other parts I wasn't sure where the plot was headed. There were more than one instance where I felt To Kill a Mockingbird just rambled around for a chapter or two. The ending was a little rushed, in my opinion. 
 Looking past some of the minor problems I had with Lee's To Kill a Mockingbird, I was overall impressed and moved by her literary classic.
I read this in 9th grade, and have been meaning to read again.

It was a treat to reread To Kill A Mockingbird again this summer! I just love this book. I have no ability to be critical or impartial reviewing it--it has become part of me after I reading it at least three times. I've seen the movie about fifty times, so the characters have been forever given faces. Atticus and Scout and Bob and Mayella Ewell are perfectly cast. It's okay in this case, because the movie is so good. 
 I think the character I enjoyed the most this time was Jem. He observant and makes some interesting discoveries about the way of the world. Of course we are seeing him through the eyes of an adoring younger sister, too, so that helps. A sleeper character who doesn't get talked about a lot is Heck Tate. He's kind of my hero in a way that Atticus isn't at the end. Atticus is surprisingly slow on the uptake. 
 PS Apparently there is no saving this review. I need coffee.
So glad that I read this again, there was so much that I had forgotten about since reading in in 9th grade English. It is a little sad that 60 years later so much of this is still relevant.

This marks the third time I've read this novel. I first picked it up when I was a naive twelve year old, my first impression being, this is definitely not a story for children. Some of the situations described--the abuse Arthur "Boo" Radley suffered at the hands of his father and older brother and the dialogue of the rape trial--disturbed me. At the time, I had wondered why through all those years no one offered to help Arthur escape from his situation. There were all of those neighbors, not to mention a lawyer living next door, yet everyone turned a blind eye. It seemed so cruel and unjust I couldn't understand it. I also couldn't fathom the reason why Tom Robinson felt compelled to help Mayella Ewell when it was common knowledge across the town that this family was trouble. I thought he should have known better, especially on that particular day when he noticed the house was deserted and felt that something was not quite right. Back then those negative images eclipsed all the good elements, which I now consider strengths in Harper Lee's writing. As an adult, I can now understand the emotional desperation of a young woman isolated and abused being attracted to anyone regardless of race to show affection to a man who showed her kindness and in turn for Tom to forgo social restraints to feel pity for such a girl. 
 I had to read the book again as a freshman in high school, and even though only the themes of childhood innocence and racial oppression and opposition in a small town were addressed, I began to develop a new respect for the novel and made a mental note to revisit it again. As this year marked the 50th anniversary of its publication and since TCM aired the film a couple times in the past month, I thought now would be a good time for a reread. 
 Harper Lee is a visual writer, her words paint strong images in your mind's eye--the only other author that I've come across with the same ability is Truman Capote. My favorite part of the novel is Harper's depiction of the collective mindset of a mob. The mob is not a group of individuals, but an anonymous collective sharing one goal in mind. Showing the simple fact of a child naming one person in the collective could immediately dissolve that mob mentality and turn the collective back into individuals was a depiction masterfully done. Love it! When Scout calls out, "Hey, Mr. Cunningham." it's like a celestial ray of light piercing through the dark cloud of mob rule and helping Mr. Cunningham and the others find their individual conscience. 
 I also like the ambiguity of the ending: Was it really murder or was it just an accident... did Bob Ewell really just trip and fall on his own knife after being pushed away by Boo Radley? Though personally, I prefer the latter version.

Am almost embarrassed to admit I had never read this until about 10 years ago ...and fell in love with it. Powerful, well-written, heart-breakingly realistic in some ways and not afraid to have an unhappy ending ... I believe this will be one of those books you need to read once a decade as your life changes. 
 On an alternative note ... Now I understand people's desire to name their children Scout and Jem ... and why so many of my friends have dogs named Atticus.
I read this book a few years back, but I still remember key elements with great details. This book is very well written, and one of those books you have to read before you die.

I wouldn't have read it if it hadn't been for school. Though I have to say, I wasn't as disappointed with it like some of my other class readings. 
 Not a fan, though. Not gonna get a rave review from me.
There are some books that you shouldn't read just because everybody loves them. There are others that everybody should read. Everybody should read this book.

This was a re-read of a book which I haven't read since I was about 15, when it was a set text at my school. In light of the upcoming prequel release and the oncoming end of my law degree, I decided it was about time to revisit it. As an almost-graduate of a law degree, I feel like I got a lot more out of this book this time around than I did the first time, although I loved it on both readings. The book looks at privilege and discrimination in a singularly non-preachy way, made possible by the use of a child as narrator. I think this will remain a life-long favourite that I return to regularly throughout my life.
I enjoyed this book quite a bit, though it was different than what I thought it would be. I am usually not a reader of modern (or any) American literature, but I think that will change now.

I honestly thoroughly enjoyed this novel. And I am completely surprised with that fact considering I read this book with low expectations, it was for Grade 9 English. It was ... amazing. This response is coming from a girl who commonly loves romantic-comedy or science fiction novel ONLY! I try to read different genres but it will come as a surprise to my friends that I enjoyed "To Kill A Mockingbird". 
 There was no epic love story or killer aliens or even an invasion and battle scene. Nay, this book was simple and focused on the fictional town of Maycomb and it's citizens, issues and pressures. Sounds boring - correct? You would be surprised. I am baffled that Harper Lee could create such a wonderful work of literature and create so well that people still read it today. I loved the descriptions in this book, it made it all seem so real. I fell in love with the characters and felt that they were developed perfectly. I especially liked the foreshadowing in this book, it made me have those moments of "Oh, I remember that!". My friend Chris and I were in our English class and suddenly we both screamed simutaneously, "That was in the beginning of the book!" Our excitement shows this is a great book. I am in Grade 9, I scream over sales and the occasional cute boy. Catch me screaming about a book written in the 1900s? Loved it! 
 I won't reveal but the ending made me squeil with delight! I loved it, a perfect ending to a perfect book. It felt ... right. Have you ever read something so beautiful that when it comes to end, you have that moment of complete appreciation for the author and book? When you just have to sit and reread the last part again, while a smile dances on your face? This is what "To Kill a Mockingbird" did to me. 
 I think this goes to show that our teachers and the people who create our curriculum don't assign books to us because they are sadistic and enjoy to see us get bored to death. They choose books because they want us to appreciate and fall in love with the same novel they did. 
 Go read "To Kill a Mockingbird". Even though I have to write an essay for it, nonetheless it has made one of my favourites. 
 P.S By the way, this book does not have anything to do with the actual killing of a mockingbird but when you find those references to the tile, it'll be worth it.

This was mandatory reading for 10th grade English at my school. I should probably re-read it one day. I remember liking it, but I'm sure I'd get something different out of it now that I'm a bit more grown up. ;)

Scout and her older brother Jem learn about justice in a southern town. A powerful story regarding race and discrimination, choosing the right actions, and growing up. 
 I've always liked this book and have read and re-read it many times. It never loses its impact. Atticus is an odd, but endearing father figure and the relationship between Scout and Jem depicts typical siblings. There's a lot of humor mixed in with the serious topics, too, like when they make the mud-snowman, or when Scout has to dress up like a ham. The writing ties so much together seamlessly, and offers much to think about. 
 Good Read.
