** spoiler alert ** 
 THIS BOOK IS AMAZING 
 This book man, this book. This is surprisingly one of my new favorites. I say this because, well its a classic for a reason. This book covers so many topics from prejudice; civil rights; racism; defining bravery; maturity; feminine vs. masculine; gender roles; effects of the mob mentality; perception; inconsistency of humanity; integrity to the love inside a family home. 
 Starting off I thought this was going to be about killing an actual Mockingbird as I assume most do when they pick up this novel. But to my unexpected delight it starts off with Jean Louise "Scout" Finch. Who is about to turn 6. The story goes through her life in Maycomb Alabama in 1933. Her family includes her father who she calls by his first name Atticus, her older brother Jem and their cook but mother-like-figure Calpurnia. 
 The story begins with Scout, Jem, and their neighbor Dill who become obsessed with their mysterious neighbor, "Boo" Radley. They take up their time daring each other to run up and touch the side of the house or knock on the window while trying to go unnoticed. But the story takes a quick turn when it changes from innocent kids messing with their neighbor to prejudice, people getting hurt, and people dying because of it. 
 Right off the bat you realize the maturity of scout and her education being much higher than any of her classmates. So that made the book so much better for me at the start. I have never read a book about the impertinent behavior of adult towards children. Especially since shes so mature to recognize that her father would never ask much of her so when shes asked to do something she does it. 
 I loved the rest of the Finch family as well. Of course Atticus is my favorite and is if not the best, then a very good role model for parents everywhere. As always I'm going to show how meaningful this book was to me through quotes so starting it off with Scout: 
 "You gonna give me a chance to tell you? I don't mean to sass you, I'm just tryin' to tell you." Uncle Jack sat down on the bed. His eyebrows came together and he peered up at me from under them. "Proceed," he said. I took a deep breath. "Well, in the first place you never stopped to gimme a chance to tell you my side of it-you just lit right into me. When Jem an' I fuss Atticus doesn't ever just listen to Jem's side of it, he hears mine too,..." Page 97. This quote is as glorious for Jean Louise as it is for Atticus. Not only did a 6 year old girl have more maturity than most adults but it shows what a great father Atticus is. Treating both of his children fairly and knowing how to handle a difficult situation. 
 "Aunt Alexandra looked across the room at me and smiled. She looked at a tray of cookies on the table and nodded at them. I carefully picked up the tray and watched myself walk to Mrs. Merriweather. With my very best company manners, I asked her if she would have some. After all, if Aunty could be a lady at a time like this, so could I." Page 271. YEAH! YOU GO SCOUT! 
 Lets move on to Atticus: 
 "Scout," said Atticus, "nigger-lover is just one of those terms that don't mean anything--like snot-nose. It's hard to explain--ignorant, trashy people use it when they think somebody's favoring Negroes over and above themselves. It's slipped into usage with some people like ourselves, when they want a common, ugly term to label somebody." 
 "You aren't really a nigger-lover, then, are you?" 
 "I certainly am. I do my best to love everybody... I'm hard put, sometimes--baby, it's never an insult to be called what somebody thinks is a bad name. It just shows you how poor that person is, it doesn't hurt you." 
 Okay side note: In chapter 12 when Calpurnia takes them to church and they shut them in I just feel like they would never do that now. Like people would sue and freak out. Even if it was for a good cause. This scene is just so bizarre to me and unbelievable but amazing because even though they're basically blackmailing these people in the church its for a good cause. 
 It's so sad that Calpurnia cant remember how old she is or when her birthday is so she just has it on Christmas cause its easier to remember. 
 Sweet, sweet little innocent Dill: 
 "It was just him I couldn't stand," Dill said. [...] "That old Mr. Gilmer doin' him thataway, talking so hateful to him--[...] It was the way he said it made me sick, plain sick. [...] The way that man called him 'boy' all the time an' sneered at him, an' looked around at the jury every time he answered-[...] It ain't right, somehow it ain't right to do 'em that way. Hasn't anybody got any business talkin' like that--it just makes me sick." 
 "Jack! When a child asks you something, answer him, for goodness' sake. But don't make a production of it. Children are children, but they can spot an evasion quicker than adults, and evasion simply muddles 'em. No," my father mused, "you had the right answer this afternoon, but the wrong reasons. Bad language is a stage all children go through, and it dies with time when they learn they're not attracting attention with it. Hotheadedness isn't. Scout's got to learn to keep her head..." Page 99. I think adults underestimate children. They think kids can't possibly understand the "adult world" well I think if they're asking, they deserve an answer.

Oh and heres another: Sulky dark person. Speaking like they're a pest, that is so awful. "just ruins your day" sickening.

The beauty of this book lies in its straightforwardness. There's not much to analyze, really. I think it deserves every bit of the appreciation it has received because of its simplicity. I feel like half of the people don't read good literature because they find the symbolism and stuff to be too much. Perhaps they find having to analyze all that too much work. This book, however, touches on some important themes, and does it without using anything that has to be analyzed to find out what it really is. There's something to be said about a book that is made up of just its story, nothing more. I don't mind analyzing a good book. In fact, I love it. But sometimes it's wonderful to just simply read a book, and love it for its sheer beauty.
I'll never get to know Jem's reaction to Scout seeing Boo. Anyways, amazing book, amazing characters. I've got nothing to say about it.

I read it. 
 I devoured it. 
 I LOVED IT. 
 I now feel the urge to peruse other classics.

Earlier this year I decided to revisit a favourite classic of mine. It's taken me so long to write a review (about 2-3 months) because it is just such a hard book to write about. It's one of those books where not much happens big so much happens at the same time, if that makes sense. The majority of the book is made up of scenes of the characters playing and doing things insignificant but at the same time, so many themes of prejudice and injustice are brought up. I hold this author in very high regards. 
 To Kill a Mockingbird (although you probably already know) is set in the southern states of the US and focuses around a young girl called Scout. The author, Harper Lee, explores adult issues of race and class during the thirties through the ideas of Scout and her brother Jem. Atticus, the children's father, try to teach them morals and attitudes whilst defending a case in which he knows he won't win, a black man charged with raping a white girl. 
 The one thing that most people don't expect when it comes to this book is the humour. It is hilarious! There is so much humour woven into the story which brings a lightness to a rather heavy subject matter. I caught myself laughing a loud many times which totally breaks the stereotype of all classics being overly boring and overrated. 
 Another aspect that the author wrote really well is the relatability of the characters. Living in Australia, I have no idea about the cultural context of this story. Its embarrassing to admit that I know little to none about the civil law and everything that followed. Despite this, I was able to relate and connect to each one of these characters even if I had no idea the significance of what they were going to. I was able to see someone I know or even parts of myself in each of these very easily recognisable characters. I really loved this. 
 As I mentioned before, the context of the book is so foreign to me and yet despite that I can say that the message really hits home. Messages of equality, justice and the criticism of prejudice are so strong in this book and I can compare them to what the world is going through right now. The anti-judgement in this book is so compassionate and beautiful and relates to everyday life. Do. Not. Judge. It's as simple as that and nobody can express the message as eloquently and beautifully as Harper Lee. 
 This is definitely a book that everyone should read at least once in their lifetime.

This was an enchanting and profound look at life in the 1930's deep south, told with an innocent childhood perspective! I don't know how I made it through middle and high school without this being assigned reading in our public school system. What a travesty. I'm ever so grateful to have finally read this novel.

4.0 Stars 
 "Atticus, he was real nice." 
 "Most people are, Scout, when you finally see them." 
 To Kill a Mockingbird takes place in a small country town in America during the Great Depression. It tells the story of Atticus Finch, a lawyer and single father to Jem and Scout (the narrator.) The story unfolds over two years and covers a number of themes - injustice, compassion, racism and loss of innocence to name a few. 
 This is a great classic. The writing was wonderful. It is told from the perspective of a child, Scout, who brings a lot of charm and honesty to the story without it being overly childish. You really feel like you are growing up with the kids as the story progresses. I had a few minor issues with it though - one being that the timeline seemed a bit off in certain parts and the first and second half seemed rather disconnected from each other. I also would have loved to have known more about Boo Radley. 
 I was taken aback by the racism that is a constant theme through out the book. I couldn't imagine people being treated as if they were not human beings because of their color. I would say it is a decent portrayal of the prejudices against African Americans at the time, but i'm sure in reality it was far worse 
 Overall I really enjoyed it and would recommend it to anyone.

One of the best books I've ever read. 
 Update: (one month later and after rereading) Possibly my favorite book of all time..
Amazing piece of work. A must read for everyone. Opens your mind to different dimensions of life. No doubt that it is considered to be a classic and is used as a literature.

To Kill a Mockingbird changed who I was then, who I am today, who I will be always. It opened the parts of me that were Atticus, and that would become Atticus. It vitalised the parts of me that were Scout, and that continue to be Scout. 
 Thank you, Ms. Lee. 
 Rest in Peace in my heart.

I really don't see why people consider this book a masterpiece. Apart from the issues concerning racial discrimination and growing up, there's nothing very impressive about it. Even though the narrative was a bit silly and naive, I could never truly imagine the story being told from a child's point of view. In general, I think this was written by a person who doesn't know children at all. And not to mention how utterly boring and pointless some chapters were. 
 And just when it was just getting interesting, it ended. What a pity. 
 3 stars, only because of the ending. Otherwise I would barely give it 2.5.

One of the premier classics of American literature, this absolutely should be on the must-read list of, well, everyone.

I'm sorry, but this was a book I appreciated much more than I was affected by it. I don't know, I suspect if I had readit when I was in the mood for gentle, plotless slice-of-rural-1930s-Alabama-life piece, I would have liked it much more. Like, it's very good at what it does. It's excellent as children's fiction, teaching difficult truths to the reader without being didactic or too subtle. It's attentive to how class and gender function within the community (moreso than race, imo), and written with a great clarity and compassion. It definitely deserves it's praise! But, hmm, I wasn't extremely moved (although I really liked Scout as the narrator). I will come back to this later.

Finally read this book. I can't imagine how I've made it into my 30's without picking it up before. 
 This is a quiet southern story about a single father and his two kids. It's about growing up. Learning how the world works. Standing up for yourself, and your friends, and your neighbors. It's about believing in what's right, and not following the crowd.
I'm not sure how to rate this book...

MY. FAVORITE. BOOK. 
 This book was really good, no really good is an understatement. Let me retry, this book was AMAZING. I loved all the characters and the story and every aspect of this book. The author is obviously very talented and now I am sad she didn't write any more.
what can I say but that I loved this book from start to end so glad I finally read it.

I can't write a full review for this because there are no words that can praise this book high enough for it's amazing story. 
 I read this as part of a school project and I was engrossed from page one. As cliche as this sounds, this is my all time favourite book - the book I would choose if I could only read one book for the rest of my life.
Fantastic book. Really brings to life the depression era/Jim Crow South of 1930s America.

Quite simply, if I had to choose a single book as my all time favourite (which Heaven Forbid! haha) this would be it. I have read - and re-read - it many times and every time I am utterly delighted. 
 May I give it SIX stars? :)

4.5 
 This is an absolute must-read for everyone who is interested in US literature! Moreover, it's a very beautiful story that made me teary several times! I cannot believe I hadn't read this earlier! One of my favorite modern classics ever!
This was a good book, but reading it for school made the enjoyment of the book hard to find for me.

This is one I missed in school, and having finished it for the first time I'm not sure what to say. 
 Except it was very good.

Despite the initial prejudice I felt towards reading this book, I liked it. Did I love it? Some aspects, but not entirely. There were parts in the book I found slow and even skimmed over. The plot itself didn't have any of the wow factors I was hoping to see in a "classic." However, I will admit I liked the voice of the book, Scout. I liked seeing the world through her eyes as she learned some important life lessons. In addition, I felt quite attached to some of the characters like Atticus and Jem and sympathized them. I do feel incomplete with the ending, so I'm probably still going to pick up the sequel.

This novel takes us through fascinating events that happen in the life of Scout Finch. It has two parts and two main sub-stories. 
 The two parts: 
 Part 1, Scout is small and not yet fully aware of appropriate social behavior; together with her brother Jem, they often get into trouble and/or do things which their father, a very well read, well educated lawyer would have disapproved of. 
 Part 2, People and context appear from a new perspective, because while only 2 years passed from the beginning of the novel, Scout and Jem grew "old" intellectually and learned valuable lessons for life. 
 The two main sub-stories: 
 Sub-story 1: To kill a mockingbird - Tom Robinson, a colored man who was accused to have raped a white woman, although he was clearly innocent (physical evidence and a compelling story) is nevertheless convicted and later on killed as he tempted scape. 
 Sub-story 2: Not to kill a mockingbird - Boo Radley, whom most of Maycomb's inhabitants believed was a insane and evil guy, was in the end recognized to be a nice guy who besides having given Scout and Jem gifts earlier in the novel, saved them from Ewell's murder attempt. 
 Besides showing social conditions of race, gender and social classes, this novel teaches us bravery, empathy and justice.

I am so glad I finally got around to read this book. That was one of the perks of joining the challenge, to read books I normally wouldn't and to discover new passions. This book definitely fits this category. 
 I immediately fell in love with the whole southern small town, where everybody knows everybody and the characteristic accent translating amazingly into the pages. The Finches are a captivating family and Scout and Jem's adventure's are a delight to follow. Scout and her childish innocence and her rebellious ways made everything even better, waving through themes like prejudice and justice easily and in a understable and relatable way. I think that if this book was not written from her POV, it wouldn't be half as interesting. It's no wonder it won a Pulitzer. 
 The ending got me in tears, not only because it was a happy ending (or the best ending possible), but also because it was adorable! It tied all the loose ends in a beautiful way. The last page left me wanting more, but I'm not reading "Go Set a Watchman", not only because of the whole issue with it being published against Haper Lee's wishes, but also because, according to the reviews, it will basically destroy everything I loved about "To Kill a Mockingbird", which was basically everything.

For the first time in possibly my entire life, I wish that I had less time to read this book. My English teacher decided it would be a good idea to make us read no more than 4 chapters at a time and discuss them, which was, in fact, not a good idea. We ended up discussing the same things over and over again with no fresh ideas. 
 Nonetheless, I read said 4 chapters the night before every single time the due date was creeping up. I wish I would have had a week to read this book, because it honestly took me about 10 minutes to read 30 pages of it. I could have had this finished in one night. But when you have my English teacher, you can't have your way. 
 ANYWAY. The point is, I looooove To Kill a Mockingbird. I don't usually read books like this. I'm not a fan of the classics or historical fiction or anything like that. I didn't even finish Great Expectations when I had to read it. I have read some books for history, but I didn't enjoy any as much as this one. 
 Because I actually loved it. 
 I loved the setting and the lessons and the characters and everything about this wonderful story. 
 Scout I obviously adored. Since she is retelling the story as a grown woman, she has the knowledge of a lady, but her younger self's account of the story still has the youthful view. Scout's tomboy nature, her adorable interactions with Atticus, and her cute relationship with Dill were so endearing that I couldn't help but fall in love with her right away. 
 "Until I feared I would lose it, I never loved to read. One does not love breathing." 
 Jem may have went through some phases where he was moody or mean, and he may think he is better than Scout sometimes, but in the end, he grew into someone Scout knew she could always look to. No matter how the siblings change individually, they will never grow apart from each other. As Scout becomes a lady and Jem becomes a man, they will grow together, and these changes may even bring them closer. 
 "Jem was becoming almost as good as Atticus at making you feel right when things went wrong." 
 "If there's just one kind of folks, why can't they get along with each other? If they're all alike, why do they go out of their way to despise each other? Scout, I think I'm beginning to understand something. I think I'm beginning to understand why Boo Radley's stayed shut up in the house all this time. It's because he wants to stay inside." 
 Jem's reaction to Tom Robinson's trial was really eye-opening since he recognized how unjust the verdict was. He knew that the case was primarily based on race, and he expressed how wrong he believed that was. 
 Atticus was the ultimate father figure. The lessons he taught Jem and Scout are lessons that even I could do to learn. He was not just a hero to his children but also to the entire black community of Maycomb county. He was a white man who defended Tom Robinson, and that was more than any whites had done for them before. (view spoiler)[Even though Tom lost the case, Atticus's willingness to defend him was a small victory for the community. When he walked out of the courtroom, the black community stood up out of respect for the man who had poured everything he had into defending a man who, according to social prejudices, he should have looked down upon. But he didn't. Atticus told his children that he does his best to love everybody. (hide spoiler)] He taught the entire courtroom a lesson in acceptance and gave his children lessons that they would carry with them through their lives. 
 "It was times like these when I thought my father, who hated guns and had never been to any wars, was the bravest man who ever lived." 
 "'Before I can live with other folks I've got to live with myself. The one thing that doesn't abide by majority rule is a person's conscience.'" 
 "'You never really understand a person until you consider things from his point of view. . . . Until you climb inside of his skin and walk around in it.'" 
 "Real courage is when you know you're licked before you begin, but you begin anyway and see it through no matter what." 
 Miss Maudie served as one of the mother figures to Jem and Scout. She baked cakes, gardened, and always looked on the bright side. She was the one who gave the children insight as to why Atticus was forced to do the "dirty work" of Maycomb County. She knew that Atticus being appointed to Tom Robinson's case was not a mistake on Judge Taylor's part: it was an effort to prove Tom Robinson's innocence. 
 "People in their right minds never take pride in their talents." 
 "Mockingbirds don't do one thing except make music for us to enjoy. They don't eat up people's gardens, don't nest in corn cribs, they don't do one thing but sing their hearts out for us. That's why it's a sin to kill a mockingbird." 
 I even loved Tom Robinson. I didn't see much of him, but at the times that I did, he came across as a very honest, kind man. There is no world in which I can see him committing the terrible crime he was accused of. This man had a wife, children, a job. As a black man, doing anything against a white would mean putting his entire livelihood on the line, and with the life he was blessed with, there was no way Tom would risk it. His fate was a terrible one, but his experiences go to show the utterly horrible racism present in America back then, and people who read of Tom will hopefully realize their own prejudices. 
 I thought that Dill would be a bigger character than he ended up being, but in a way, he was one of the biggest characters. According to Jem, he was the one who started the journey toward Jem's "accident." He was the one who introduced the idea of getting Boo Radley to come out, and this led to more. 
 Everything affects everything. 
 The Ewells . . . Those jerks. They are one of the reasons To Kill a Mockingbird is such a controversial book. Mayella Ewell accuses Tom Robinson of one of the worst crimes possible, and the fact that he is innocent of the crime but is still found guilty is what makes this so awful. Bob Ewell is a disgusting human being. (view spoiler)[Bob is too cowardly to go after Atticus after the trial, so he decides to target Atticus's young children in a place where they feel safe: near their home. They were vulnerable, and he attacked them. Thank God Scout had on her chicken costume and Boo came out and served as the real MVP or there would have been some serious consequences. (hide spoiler)] 
 Boo. Radley. Boo Radley. BOO RADLEY. BOOOOO RADLEEEYYYYY!!!!! I actually cried when we finally met Boo Radley. (view spoiler)[The entire book built up to Boo Radley's reveal. It was Scout's reaction to seeing Boo that finally drove me to tears. When she realizes who he is, she tears up. After the years of anticipation, she finally meets the very bane of her existence as a child. She was no longer afraid of the man who had been the fuel of her nightmares when she was young. She quickly accepted Boo Radley as a friend, led him through her house, and even made it look like he was leading her somewhere so that he would seem to be a gentleman. Scout's views of Boo Radley are one of the main guidelines as to how she grew up. When she realizes that Boo Radley is no longer a fear of hers, this is because her new fears are much more present. She is terrified of Bob Ewell hurting her father now, and Boo Radley does not seem as scary as he used to. Jem and Scout have been hardened by the events during and after the trial, and Boo Radley has become nothing more than an object of fascination. BUT when he saves Jem, he becomes a fast friend. (hide spoiler)] 
 He helps Scout learn one of the most valuble lessons of the whole novel: you can't understand a person until you stand in their shoes. She takes a lot of time to see the neighborhood from Boo Radley's perspective and she learns that that is the only way to know a person's intentions and emotions. 
 AH I JUST LOVE BOO RADLEY. 
 Plus he's played by Robert Duvall in the movie, and who doesn't love a little RobDu? 
 Oh, Aunt Alexandra. I've got to say, I really hated you at first. When you first came to Finch house, you tried to take over, and I thought Atticus was doing just fine. She really did want the best for Jem and Scout, but she went about getting that for them in the wrong ways. Buuuutttt in the end, like a lot of characters, I developed a soft spot for you and decided I liked you a little bit. A lot. I liked you a lot. 
 And Calpurnia. Who could forget Calpurnia? Yet another one of the mother figures for Jem and Scout, she always seemed to favor Jem, but she definitely loved both of the children. Calpurnia looked out for the Finch kids like they were her own. 
 Other characters, such as the Cunninghams, Cecil Jacobs, Link Deas, Mr Underwood, Helen Robinson, Judge Taylor, and Reverend Sykes should be mentioned but to be honest, I just don't feel like writing any longer. 
 So basically everyone in the world should read this book and gain a ton of knowledge from it. The lessons taught in To Kill a Mockingbird should be learned and remembered by all. I know this book has been banned many times and is extremely controversial, but I think that despite the dispute surrounding it, To Kill a Mockingbird accurately depicts one of the terrors of US history. Just because we are ashamed of our past does not mean it shouldn't be known, and this novel is one of the best ways to learn. It is told through the eyes of a child uncovering the secrets of her town and those who reside within it. If you don't read this book, you are missing out on a vital part of life. We learn from our history, even the parts that are horrific. 
 If you have ever been interested in reading this book, do it. If you don't, I assure you that you will regret it. You can probably finish it in less than 2 days. 
 You can definitely finish it in less than 2 days. Because you'll really love it. I promise. 
 SCOUT: "'Atticus, he was real nice.'" 
 ATTICUS: "'Most people are, Scout, when you finally see them.'"

I'd asked around about what the book was about and I was told it's about a black man convicted of raping a white girl. I foresaw court scenes and societal conflicts and turmoil, little did I gather that it would be put across in the way that it was. The book tells a tale of people and their part in the society, about understanding the dynamics of any given society, about deceptions and truths, and most of all, about how much children truly understand.
Rereading before Go Set A Watchman and this is still one of my favourites. I'm not sure I want to read Watchman now, I don't want all these characters ruined.

Strangely one of the things I took away from this book was a desire to be a better housewife. I do not want to insult or belittle any of the important issues in the book. I was just so struck by the simplicity of the men and women in the book. I felt myself longing to live there and be like them. 
 Rather than analyse such a classic book I just want to talk about some of my favourite things. 
 I have to applaud an author who is able to write a book in which an eight year old narrates a story that heavily involves a court case in which a black man is accused of rape. Her youth and her lack of a mother possibly make her the least informed person in the entire town. I can see how using this child really allows the author absolute control over the release of information. It is clear that the crime and the trial are the subject of endless town gossip, but as a reader we are kept in the dark until the author is ready to share the information, due to the narrator simply not being privvy to the gossip of town. 
 I like the fallibility of the father. Mr Finch really is the hero of the book. The narrator is telling us the story of her father. It seems rare to give the main character subtle character flaws (make them big or not at all). It is a small thing but I appreciate how naive he is to the danger he faces from both the mob of men (prior to the trial) and Mr Ewell (after the trial).

I read this book in grade 9 for my English class, and I definitely loved it. Told from the point of view of a young girl, the book discusses racism in such an interesting way. A classic and a must-read.

The story takes place in 1930's Alabama. The narrator is a young girl called Scout. She lives with her older brother Jem, & their father Atticus. 
 The first half of the book is mainly about Scout & Jem & just their general life around town & the adventures they get up to. I went into this book thinking that it was mostly about Atticus & the trial he was involved with - as this is what's spoken about the most when people mention this book. 
 It's very well written & gives the reader a wonderful, yet troubling insight into American life in the 1930's. I can understand why this book is taught in school's - it deals with class, rape & racial injustice. 
 Atticus Finch is known throughout the literary world as being a hero, and I agree with this statement. However I wished the author could have gone into more detail after the trial in relation to Atticus & his thoughts/feelings. I know this may not have been possible given the narration, & because of this he comes across as very one-dimensional. 
 In my opinion, Atticus wasn't that great of a father. He seemed dismissive of his kids, hardly spent any time with them & pretty much just let them do whatever they wanted. I felt no connection between him & the children, & aside from a few 'pearls of wisdom' he really didn't say that much to them. Perhaps this was just the way it was in the 1930's. 
 I completely understand why this book won a Pulitzer Prize, however in the end, I really just didn't connect with the story or any of the characters in the book.

This was my second reading of To Kill A Mockingbird. I had read it years ago when i was maybe fifteen and i only remembered it in bits and pieces. So when I saw a readalong on Goodreads and with the sad passing away of the author i was only too eager to read it again. There is a world of a difference when you read a book at fifteen and at twenty-five. As a teenager i remember that i liked the book, identified with the simply and innocently portrayed children's games and their motivations for their torment of Boo Radley. I understood the theme of the book, the fight for justice and the desmystification of Arthur (Boo) Radley. But i did not understand the finer nuances of the writing. I did not appreciate the genius of a story so simply and effectively told, which dealt with a very complex and age-old problem of racism in Southern America. 
 Recently i read the Bregden Chronicles by Virginia Gaffney. It is an eight book series, focussed on the Civil War and the life and struggles of a plantation owners only daughter, Carrie Cromwell who fights against racism in the Southern state of Virginia, at a time when blacks were simply considered to be sub-human. I really loved the series, but coming back to the point, reading it gave me a deeper insight into the racial issues in America at that time. To Kill A mockingbird is set about a century later but the conditions for blacks show slight improvement. Scout and Jem Finch are the exceptions to the rule in the small fictional town of Maycomb. Exceptions because they have been taught to follow their conscience by their father Atticus Finch. He is man with absolutely no prejudice and great courage. He knows that by following his conscience his and his family's very life could be in danger. Yet he knows he cannot teach his children anything if he does not himself set and example for what is right. In every area of life, he has been an upstanding and respectable but more importantly conscientious citizen of Maycomb. He has taught his children respect and equality and always told them the truth about any matter. If the world had more people like Atticus Finch, it would be a better place. 
 The story is told in the voice of the young Scout Finch, who is courageous curious and hilarious. In the innocent narration of a child's voice it is much easier to understand simple truths and observations of the world around them. Scout takes things matter of factly and through her we can understand her neighbors, father, Aunt, Jem and Dill in a few sentences. Scout adores and respects her father above all others and her puzzlement at his defense of a black man when the whole town shows that children are but impressionable. It's what you teach your child by setting an example, not mere words that shapes their characters. The book has many layers, racial prejudice of a town set in its ways, where everyone has typical manners and families are identified by particular 'streaks.' The courage of one man against his friends and neighbors. The moral struggle of town faced with a dilemma. The vice like grip of small town prejudices. The importance of being conscientious rather than religious. The ever present struggle for changing mindsets and giving everyone a chance. Tom Robinson is convicted inspite of his innocence being proved in court because he is black. Arthur Radley is made into an evil monster and not even given a chance to lead a normal life. To Kill A Mockingbird is a timeless classic, that needs to be read by everyone who hasn't read it irrespective of age, gender and location. It is a lesson in morality and goodness. Though the main theme is racial prejudice it also teaches us humanity and conscientiousness for all situations in life. I'm sharing some of my favourite quotes from the book. I'll forgo the famous 'its a sin to kill a Mockingbird' for fear of being archetypal, but share some of my other favorites. 
 But sometimes a Bible in the hand of one man is worse than a whiskey bottle in the hand of another.. 
 There are just some kind of men who're so busy worrying about the next world they've never learned to live in this one. 
 I never understood her preoccupation with heredity. Somewhere, I had received the impression that Fine Folks were people who did the best they could with the sense they had, but aunt Alexandra was of the opinion, obliquely expressed, that the longer a family had been squatting one patch of land the finer it was. 
 I'm no idealist to believe firmly in the integrity of ur courts and in the jury system - that is no ideal to me, it is a living, working reality. Gentlemen, a court is no better than each man of you sitting before me on this jury. a court is only as sound as its jury and the jury is only as sound as the men who make it up. 
 These are just a few of the many effective and thought provoking statements in the book. Harper Lee has written a lesson in moral living in a witty, ironic, humourous and gripping tale of humanity and justice. 
 Needless to say the book gets 5/5 and a shelved under a Must Read for everyone.

I love this book. 
 I enjoy the heavy-handed illustrations of prejudice; that was the theme that hooked me the first time. Now on the reread, I was able to look at it beyond that. I could focus more on the small-town dynamics which is a concept Go Set a Watchman delves into. Whereas on my first read, I took to Scout, now I found myself appreciating Jem's role more fully. 
 One of the quotes I latched onto this time was one that I didn't understand at first. I reread the section several times but I still couldn't place the tone or implication well enough until I looked it up. This quote takes place during one of Aunt Alexandra's gatherings, as the ladies are discussing the trial: "His food doesn't stick going down does it" I couldn't tell who "he" was at first, but after realizing it was Atticus, I loved the witty defense of the Finch family by Miss Maudie. It became yet another example of how Maycombe residents are all linked to one another below the surface; Mrs. Merriweather does not comprehend how hypocritical her disapproval of Atticus' involvement in the trial is, while she is a guest at his house. No matter how different the town's families are, nobody exists in complete isolation. People and ideas have influence beyond those directly involved. 
 I realize that I just read Watchman within the last 2 years, but now I feel the need to go back and read it again. I tried to see this book through the eyes of adult Scout and more cynical Atticus, but I think it needed to be more recent to make direct comparisons.

Most people know To Kill a Mockingbird is about racism and class in the fictional Southern small town of Maycomb, Alabama, during the Depression Era, and is told by young Jean Louise "Scout" Finch as her father, Atticus Finch, defends a black man charged with raping a white girl. 
 Look close enough though, beneath the lessons of racism and prejudice, and the development of conscience, and Harper Lee's first and only novel is essentially Scout's reflection on just who or what started the series of events that led to her brother Jem breaking his arm. The phrase 'long story short' need not apply here. 
 The famous court case is the natural centerpiece, full of drama and intensity, but I appreciated every scene for what it brought to the overall message. The case is just as significant to the loss of childhood innocence as the death of a cantankerous neighbor, hypocrisy from a teacher, humanization of a shadowy figure, or revelation of a parent's hidden skills. 
 In this way, summer friend Dill's blatant lies about his family structure are as bad as the conviction of a guiltless man. Childish name-calling as ignorant as senseless killing. Each incident, whether juvenile or adult, is leveled by Scout's youthfully curious gaze. 
 It is easy to be swept up in Scout's day-to-day existence in Maycomb, Gothic elements, deft, spooky suspense, and taut courtroom interrogation heightening some moments above the rest. 
 The parts that stick out to me are those that moved me most: Atticus in the middle of the road, forsaking his glasses to the ground for the rifle in his expert hands; Jem and Scout walking home on Halloween and the aftermath that follows; cement in a healthy tree; Atticus' final appeal to the jury; Scout standing in someone else's shoes. 
 I marveled at the bravery in Atticus' imperfections, his steely commitment to do what was right--in the court of law as in his household--even if it was a lost cause. I found myself very envious of Scout for both her patient, honest father and protective brother, if not also her tomboy gumption that often dissipates in girls along with childhood. 
 The only thing I disliked about To Kill a Mockingbird was that Scout ever ceased her narration. The best stories always have more life in them than the author reveals on the page. Of course the novel needed to end where it did, for the story had come full circle. Once Jem's arm broke at the elbow, it's up to the reader to decide for themselves just who or what started it all.

... I think I like this book... 
 It's just a lot to take in and think about. 
 I need to read it again.

Very interesting. I'm not sure I got the deeper meaning, because it felt like I was missing something. I don't know though. Maybe it just wasn't quite as deep as I expected, for an English class book. My only comment is that you can reasd this book as choppy as you want, but as soon as you get to the trial, don't read anymore until you can sit down in a quiet place to read the trial straight through. You can't have previous testimonies already fading in your memory, because you miss the fine contradictions and logistics of the case. Read the trial straight through, as cohesively as possible. It helps -a lot.

** spoiler alert ** 
 I really expected this book to be an austere piece of work.Instead I found a book full of humor and sweetness.I liked so much little Scout,her innocent questions and her remarkable assumptions.Through the eyes of a child the author succeeded to make me see clearer the world with all it's prejudices and absurdities.I was really moved when the juries found Robinson guilty(something like that can make you mad at the world)and I was really shocked when I found out that Boo was the one who saved the kids.I really loved this book!

Still one of my favorite books. The best thing about "To Kill a Mockingbird" is the narrator. Scout is a naive, fierce, innocent young girl who loves her family and friends but can't quite understand all the awful things going on around her. As a result, the reader has to piece together some of the things going on. (view spoiler)[For example, the first time I read TKAM in middle school, I don't think I understood that Boo Radley probably killed Bob Ewell -because Scout didn't understand. (hide spoiler)] 
 If the book were written today, it would probably be a very different book. There would probably be stronger black characters - Tom Robinson and Calpurnia, though important in the book, are still minor characters. But for its time (1961), this book was really revolutionary, declaring through Atticus that "all men are created equal." During a period when black men could still be executed for raping white women, when black men still lived in fear of being lynched, when the Civil Rights movement was beginning to be underway, this was a startling book for a white woman to write. And it still resonates today. 
 There are many undercurrents in the book - Jem's sense of justice, Atticus's nobility, Tom Robinson's courage in the face of a certain verdict. The child's perspective shows us the toll that racism and injustice can have, and why people must fight for what is right. 
 Next book - on to Go Set a Watchman!

I haven't read this since high school and I forgot how compelling it is. Such a good novel with important themes on race, morality and humanity. 
 Favorite quote: 
 "Scout, I think I'm beginning to understand something. I think I'm beginning to understand why Boo Radley's stayed shut up in the house all this time. It's because he wants to stay inside."

I read this book in school and had forgotten all but the basic story line (somehow I forgot all about Dill, and most of the townsfolk, and their Aunt). I was listening to the section following the trial when Atticus is talking to Jem and getting frustrated in how little somethings seem to have changed. 
 I could go all into the things I'm sure I wrote English papers on but I still find this to be an important read, and I'm glad that I could get reacquainted with it.

The book has been described as a southern gothic novel which gave the book a certain appeal to me and was one of the main reasons I decided to read this book. What I found left me a little disappointed. To begin with, I found the book didn't start to get interesting till chapter 11. I know the back story was needed, it was a different time, but I didn't much care for the childhood of Jean Louise, Jem or even Boo. To me it felt like it dragged on and could have used some cutting down, but some people like to hear about life in the 1930's. When I did eventually get to chapter 11, I did start to enjoy the book a lot more and finally at chapter 17 we started to get into the real story of To Kill A Mockingbird; The Court Case. 
 Atticus was the only truly enjoyable character for me. He was a wise and fair man, though he never wanted to take Tom Robinson case he did his upmost to make sure he was treated fairly and got the best representation possible. Atticus was the shining light throughout this book; he was a scholar and gentlemen through thick and thin. Once the court case was over and Atticus no longer had to deal with Tim Robinson the book again went back to its original slow pace and eventually fizzled out. 
 The book wasn't all bad, it was well written and tackled some important topics, including racial injustice, class and even sexuality. I can see why this is a classic book and I think Harper Lee did a fantastic job at shedding light on some important social issues, the story just felt to slow for my liking, but I can understand why so many people enjoy this book.

There probably isn't a whole lot I can say about To Kill a Mockingbird that hasn't already been said. Of all the mostly shitty things I had to read for school, why couldn't my curriculum have included some of the good ones like this?

I am ashamed that at age 50+ I had never read this before. I finally got to it, via an audiobook read by Sissy Spacek, and am bowled over by it. Harriet the Spy used to be my girl-child-idol. Now it's Scout. 
 Highly recommended. Read and you will enjoy.
A well-deserved classic, certainly, but one that especially sticks in my mind for its eerie sense of neighborhood legend and undercurrents of unease.

A cliche favorite, but that's because it deserves to be someone's favorite. I love this book so much that I hesitate to read the new book in case it changes the way I read this one. But I just think this will always be a great book that will be relevant for generations to come.

I somehow missed reading this in high school. I decided to pick it up when all the buzz started going about Harper Lee's second book. I was both saddened and surprised by how relevant this book written in 1960 felt today. Choosing to use Scout (Jean Louise) the youngest character in the book to tell a story about this small town and its very ugly racism and her coming to grips with what it means to be racist was a compelling approach and I think it dissected feeling and thoughts I've had about racism in my life. I liked Scout sometimes, know-it-all characters are seldom my cup of tea, especially when they don't know, but watching her learn what she thought she knew was enthralling. Atticus was too perfect a human being to the point where I really just said, "Come on." But I believe the character is more of a symbol that a real person. Yes in the book he was Scout's father, but to me he represented what we all strive or should strive to be when we interact with fellow humans, but very often fail to do. The state the country is in now and has always been is a chaos of White vs Black, Rich vs Poor, etc, etc. This idea of respect and compassion is a message that everyone seems to be missing. We all think we are the fair minded ones and that everyone else is crazy or misinformed and we never stop to wonder why they feel the way they do. Why they disagree to vehemently with us. We argue for our perspective and seldom hear the other side. I though this book was fantastic and I'm sorry I only read it for the first time now, but I'm glad I did. 
 After finishing this book I read a synopsis of the new one and I have concluded that the book was very clearly a first draft and does plenty to tarnish everything "To Kill a Mockingbird" established. I have no need or desire to read it.

It's a shame I didn't finish this one faster. A really good book. In the beginning I wasn't sure I understand where all this is going - why should I care about these kids, their childish adventures? The storytelling manner was also quite childish. That's understandable, of course, because it's told from the point of view of a 6-7 year old kiddo. 
 Closer to the middle of the story I finally started getting where all this is going and what's it all about. I think it's a very rare combination when a story narrated by a child is actually a story for grown-ups discussing such serious problems as discrimination by race and general injustice, violence, rape. 
 But I actually enjoyed the second theme of the story even more. To Kill a Mockingbird shows us that children are, unfortunately, mostly the only ones in the world who can really tell the difference between good and bad, who are capable of empathy and real emotions. This is what makes this story popular nowadays - people grow up and become indifferent to all that is sad, evil and horrible out there. They build a wall around themselves and spend their lives convincing themselves that they don't care. Children never do it. I think every single person should bring these traits with them into their adult life. And I don't understand why it doesn't happen. 
 Another thing. Atticus is one of the best father figures in literature for me now. Honestly, he's the embodiment of a perfect father: strict, but caring, he is able to balance these traits. He's wise, he has high moral standards and rules, which he follows and therefore sets an example for his children. I am very very fond of him. 
 All in all, it's unquestionable why this book is a world classic and still being read in the 21st century. People will read and relate to it until they learn to be... to be better than they are, I guess. :-)

I loved this book because it's told through the eyes of Scout Finch. She is so innocent and yet so wise, like most children in my opinion. It's one of the only classics that deals with such pertinent issues to society but through the eyes of a child. I think this is a really effective tactic because we see how things really are, instead of how they appear through the biased opinions of adults. This is such a great classic because it also teaches people how to be tolerant of those who differ from us. If Scout can be kind to those who are unlike herself, than why can't we all? A great book to be read again and again, To Kill a Mockingbird is a great story of tolerance, truth and friendship. <3

I'm not quite sure where to go with this. The previous rating (4 stars) was accurate as to my having read it many years ago. I still would continue to rate it as that. But maybe a slightly "different" 4 stars. This was when I set it at 4 stars, to be a "not quite 5 stars" and this now is a "more than 3 stars"... 
 I had started reading this a while ago. I had been having a lot of trouble reading it. I got about 1/3 of the way through over a period of about 3 weeks of trying to read it. I wasn't feeling up to re-reading that part after having picked it up again a couple of months after having put it down (taken it back to the library). So I tried to remember where I had read to. 
 This time I started reading about chapter 10 of the book, which as best I can tell was where I had read to. And I immediately felt that I was reading a good book, that was going places that I really was hoping it was going. 
 Having read it a long time ago, I had remembered good parts of the plot. And even good parts of how the characters developed. The thing about this is... I read it now, being able to remember those things, but still enjoying it. 
 Other books I have tried to re-read only to find I just couldn't stand re-reading them. Pretty much all the "redeeming" characteristics of those books were really basic elements. The "basic" story. And on re-reading, even *that* really made me wonder how I managed to get through the series the first time. 
 Maybe when I was reading months ago, I was feeling a little bit of that. I think like many books, it had flaws, which *largely* fell around the beginning and end of the book. The "let's introduce what's going on" and the "let's make sure we wrap this up nice and neat" that I find often end up being very difficult for me to get through. 
 The *end* tends to be a little less difficult, because I am more into "let's actually just finish this". I may not feel compelled to read it on the basis of the writing, or the plot or really anything about what is going on with the book itself, but having got to the point where they are "wrapping it all up" I just feel... "might as well get this done as quickly as I can even though I'm finding this kind of boring". 
 Ah, it was indeed a good book, and indeed worth reading again. Still, it is interesting how books change over readings.

This book was outstanding! I can't believe it took me this long to actually find the time to pick it up and read it. I loved the tone of the book and the message the book delivered. The book really painted a picture of how things were in a small town in the Southern United States from the perspective a young girl who's a tomboy at heart. I was shocked how the trial against Tom Robinson turned out, even though I maybe shouldn't have been...that was a different time period than we live in now. The entire book, start to finish, was great. I felt the book was tied up well and I'm really glad that (view spoiler)[Scout finally got to "catch a glimpse" of Arthur "Boo" Radley before she died. =) (hide spoiler)]

3.5 STARS 
 So you can't go very far in life saying that you love books without people asking you what classics you've read. I don't read classics too often, having tried to pick up Pride and Prejudice and only gotten about 50 pages in. Now, my mom didn't grow up in America, so she never had to read all the American classics my dad did. So, knowing that I was planning to read To Kill A Mockingbird over the summer, she picked it up from the library and read it in July. Or, at least tried to. Because after about 100 pages, she deserted it, claiming that nothing was happening. And that was the end of that. 
 My father, on the other hand, did read this book because he was forced to in class. He remembered hating it, although when I tried to talk to him about the book, he didn't remember any of the actual details to the story. 
 Basically, my family really prefers their YA fantasy and dystopians over classics. 
 For the first part of the book, I was with my parents. Although the writing was good, the storyline was going nowhere, Scout was insufferable and all the characters felt very one dimensional. I'd give the first part of the book two stars. 
 The second part of the book was amazing, though. It was gripping most of the way through, layered with metaphors and philosophy and made me feel towards the characters. The second part is really what most people think of when TKAM is mentioned because that's where the main part of the story occurs. That part alone is probably somewhere between 4.5 and 5 stars. 
 Now, my problem with this book is that a lot of the first part just feels very irrelevant to the story, and that's what makes it so dry in the beginning. Although the book is actually about Scout and Jem growing up in Maycomb, there are some details that honestly have no purpose in the story. It would've been nice if Lee had cut out some of the parts that didn't pertain to the main two stories: the court case and Boo Radley. 
 The only other real problem I had with this book was that the characters all felt very one dimensional. Scout was the innocent smart child, Jem was the annoying but wiser older brother, Atticus was the wise, politically correct father, Cal was the sweet maid, Alexandra was the typical Southern belle, Dill was just an annoying kid, Boo was the kind town recluse, Tom was an innocent hardworking man, and Bob Ewell was just the town drunk trying to make some money. 
 In the first part of TKAM, the main story is about Scout, Jem and Dill trying to catch a glimpse of the town recluse, Boo Radley. They have multiple schemes about trying to get him to come out mixed in with their everyday escapades. Again, this part is very slow, and not a lot happens, so I can't say I enjoyed it too much. 
 If you haven't read this book, I will warn you, there is racism present. If that is something that makes you uncomfortable and you try to stay away from it, I would advise you not read this book. The court case in the story is that Scout and Jem's father, Atticus, is defending a black man named Tom Robinson who was accused of raping a white girl. Lee handles this topic with grace, and even gives Scout lines where she points out the double standard about discrimination throughout the world. I did find the court case very interesting, not only in how Atticus handled everything, but in how well he was able to sense what really happened. 
 During the first half of the first part, I really liked Scout. She was smart and didn't mix her opinion in with things she saw. That's really why Lee chose Scout as the narrator, because she told everything exactly how she saw it, without trying to mix what she thought up with what actually happened. When dealing with such sensitive topics, the narrator should only be saying the facts. I didn't really understand her whole thing with Dill, how she actually thought that they were going to get married. I wanted to slap her every time she talked about her 'fiance'. "...Summer was the swiftness with which Dill would reach up and kiss me when Jem was not looking, the longings we sometimes felt each other feel. With him, life was routine; without him, life was unbearable." Please *eye roll*. She got better as the book went on, but I didn't feel a ton of character development with her. Scout became less violent for sure, and a bit more ladylike, but that's not really development. Her character felt very dry and needed more substance to her. 
 I'm not going to do my usual character analysis with spoilers just because I feel like there wasn't enough substance to the characters or character development to do it. 
 So this book was good, but it wasn't as good as it was hyped up to be. The characters were flat and the first part seemed to drag on forever. But the writing style was still very good with a lot of interesting twists in the story in the second part. Read it, and please tell me if you agreed with my thoughts or if you felt differently. 
 Thanks for reading, 
 Caramel

The perfect novel. Simple, elegant, and touching. This is the type of story that makes you nostalgic for your childhood, even if your childhood is nothing like that of the kids in the book.

It started incomprehensible, but then it got more interesting. I love the title "To Kill a Mockingbird". It's a beautiful title and I like how it was connected to the story (Tom Robinson etc). 
 I loved all the parts with mr. Arthur Radley - Boo. 
 My favorite part was when Scout was talking to mr. Cunningham near Tom's prison. She was so innocent and didn't understand what was going on in the first place. 
 I liked Jean Louise Finch's nickname in my Estonian book - nirksilm (Scout). 
 1. "You never really understand a person until you consider things from his point of view... Until you climb inside of his skin and walk around in it." 
 2. "Until I feared I would lose it, I never loved to read. One does not love breathing."

 In Estonian: "Laske siniraage niipalju kui te tahate ja tabate, aga pidage meeles, et tappa laulurastast on patt."

How can you possibly describe the novel that has molded you into the person you are today? Are there even enough words in the English language to even attempt it? 
 The typical synopsis of "To Kill a Mockingbird" states that it takes place in Maycomb, Alabama in the 1930s. Told from the point of view of Jean Louise "Scout" Finch as an adult, it follows the story of Scout, her older brother Jem, and their father Atticus. Atticus is a defense attorney, and is assigned to the case of Tom Robinson, who has been falsely accused of raping a white woman. 
 This story, however, is so much more than that. It has so many important themes: particularly racism, socioeconomic prejudice, and, perhaps most importantly, childhood and the subsequent loss of childhood. "To Kill a Mockingbird" is truly the story of Jem: a young boy who grows up in an area full of racism, whose childhood beliefs about the goodness of his town and its residents are demolished by a 'simple' court decision. What makes this character development interestingly spectacular and heart-wrenching is the fact that the novel isn't even told from Jem's point of view, but rather from his younger sister's. 
 I could literally write papers and essays about how life-changing and thought-provoking this novel is (and I have done just that); however, no words could truthfully capture my love for "To Kill a Mockingbird." It's simply perfection.

My Review 
 Simple and complex in the same breath. Whenever you wonder what it takes to be human, turn to this. 
 P.S. Given that the name Harper is making a comeback, Calpurnia, Jem, Dill & Atticus should also be given some serious consideration. 
 Favorite Quotes 
 Summer was on the way; Jem and I awaited it with impatience. Summer was our best season; it was sleeping on the back screened porch in cots, or trying to sleep in the treehouse; summer was everything good to eat; it was a thousand colors in a parched landscape; but most of all, summer was Dill. 
 Naw, Jem, I think there's just one kind of folks. Folks. 
 [Atticus' closing remarks to the jury. Bawl.] 
 He put on his hat. "Now I may be wrong, of course, but I think he's very alive. Shows all the symptoms of it. Go have a look at him, and when I come back we'll get together and decide.

This book wasn't a part of my required reading in high school and I can't believe I waited this long to read it! It's absolutely beautiful and an obvious classic. The story still resonates 50 years after it was first published. Especially in today's political and social climate, I think it would serve us well to imagine what it's like to walk around in someone else's skin. EVERYONE should read this! No wonder it's part of most high school curricula! I just love the language and the way the characters speak to one another. My goal is to speak to my future children the way Atticus speaks to Jem and Scout. LOVE LOVE LOVE! 
 P.S. If you enjoy audiobooks, I HIGHLY recommend the recording narrated by Sissy Spacek.

Originally read in 2006 for a grade 10 English class, I suppose this was the first piece of 'literature' I read. Sure, I'd been through those 500 page Star Wars & Forgotten Realms books before, among other things, but this was literature. I didn't enjoy it for the first third or so, but then I felt in the groove, & by the end, of course, Atticus had changed my life forevermore. A friend drunkenly shoplifted me the book a couple of years later, & I've been intending to re-read it ever since, so I'm almost sad it's taken this long. After reading the 'sequel' earlier this year, however, I knew it was high time. I am so happy that circumstance finally led to this. 
 Re-reading this book made me realize a few things. For instance: I love it, & it means more to me than most books. I connect with it. Hemingway may be a kingly author, & The Sun Also Rises may be a better book (&, indeed, is one of my favourites), but I think I like this better. My favourite books are often crazy philosophical trips, with meta-leanings. Those are my favourites. & also, there are books I like greatly due to personality - Kerouac (in fact, all the Beats), Bukowski, HST, etc... but then, there is 'plain' literature. It surprises me to find, upon digging within myself, that I think my favourite books of 'plain' literature are Grapes of Wrath, Mockingbird, & Salinger's works. They trump the Great Gatsbys & the Sun Also Rises(es) to me. (Interesting also, I guess, that Mockingbird & Grapes both fit fairly snugly into a humble kind of realm, while Salinger - though being anti-intellectual in his own way - often radiates a self-aware intellectualism, differentiating his works rather dramatically.) 
 Anyway, recollections & realizations aside, this book is just great. It has everything. It has one of the greatest characters in literature, just about an archetype of morality & justice. It has suspense, sentimentality, humour, wit, charm, development, religion, sadness, friendship, family, history, & everything else. Scout's perspective is just so wonderful - it does any adult well to learn from children, but Scout makes it so easy & enjoyable. 
 Honestly, besides rather enjoying it, I remember little about Go Set A Watchman. I remember thinking it may have been possible for Atticus to become that person, but knowing I had to re-read Mockingbird to be sure. Reading this now, I just want to re-read Watchman, as I feel like I remember none of it - as if it was all too new, & that I would understand it more with this adult reading of Mockingbird in my mind. I think I will re-read Watchmen in the next two months, after I finally watch the classic Gregory Peck film. 
 Well, this drags on, but I plan on re-reading this every year or two for the foreseeable future, so will update it as thoughts come to me.

I have always heard so much about this book - mostly rather bad things since almost every kid in an english speaking country is forced to read it in school. So I decided I wanted to see for myself what the fuss was all about and let me tell you, I fell in love. 
 To Kill a Mockingbird starts rather innocent, narrated by a little girl, Scout, with a sophisticated father and a smart brother. She herself of course is witty and educated, but still way too young to understand the dark and confusing things that are going on in the little town called Maycomb, that of course become very obvious to the reader. It is a rather interesting concept to have the protagonist understand much less of the situation than the reader itself, but I think Harper Lee had this well thought through because it gave her the opportunity to write about very difficult and sometimes taboo topics without commenting on them herself or seeming biased, since Scout herself doesn't really have an opinion on these things. 
 I think Harper Lee did a brilliant job creating, nurturing and growing these characters. That is why the beginning of the book may seem a little long and boring, since nothing really happens but the kids playing and enjoying summer, going to school and fighting. I liked this part a lot since it seems Harper Lee took her time to let the characters and their personas sink into the readers brain and create an image of them and their surroundings that lasted. 
 The author deals with a very delicate subject that is still relevant today: racism and discrimination towards certain groups of people. It is all the more interesting that she does it from the view of a little girl, since she lets her ask questions that may seem silly to us but are so on point that they leave us sitting in confusion asking ourselves: "Yes, why is that so? Why do we do this? Just because it has 'always' been done?" 
 It reminded me of the story with the naked emperor that gets called out by a little boy and makes everyone realise how silly and irrational they have been behaving and leaving them thinking: "Why don't we questions daily rituals just because they 'have always been done that way'?" 
 I also very much enjoyed the way Harper Lee writes her "villains". I can't even quite call them villains because not even she does. Every character in her book has a good and a bad side. There is no black and white distinction. Literally. She introduces us to a character that infuriates us in his/her ways but then throws reasons at us as to why this character has been behaving the way he/she has and leaves us with a slight feeling of guilt since we hastily started to despise the character without thinking twice about the reasons behind his/her ways. 
 I do absolutely understand what all the fuss is about and I absolutely recommend everyone to read this book, whether it is to enlighten oneself or strengthen his beliefs and views. Her writing style is quirky and funny, but never leaves out the important and serious topics and issues. I am truly amazed by this book. 
 Thank you, Harper Lee. 
 Ps.: As always, excuse my english, it's not my mother tongue, so I apologize for any confusing sentences or words I may have used. I am still learning. Thank you for reading.

The only thing I can say is "Thank God Harper Lee's releasing a sequel!" 
 All the characters just felt so ... real. I have to admit that I cried during Atticus' speeches because they are just awesome. And I love Scout and Jim and Dill. (view spoiler)[If Dill and Scout are actually married in the sequel that would actually be so sweet. Just sayin'. (hide spoiler)] They just come off the page in a way that is so rare. 
 So ... go read this book. Please.

This was one of the few "assigned" books that I actually read in school, and I've read it at least a half dozen more times since high school. If you haven't read To Kill a Mockingbird, you are missing out!

This was a very realistic telling of a story narrated from a child's perspective. The time-frame and facts were accurate and the characters were well developed and believable. It was interesting to read that the author was inspired by events in her own hometown. This makes the story all that much better- and sadder. 
 I enjoyed the morals taught by lovable and decent father Atticus, as well as the lessons learned by Jem and Scout. Invaluable knowledge could be gleaned from such a wise and morally decent man. 
 I found it of particular interest, the way that the character, Boo Radley, was cleverly woven into the story. The end left of the book admittedly left me feeling a little bit, "eh," that being said, the journey to get there was a good one. 
 The story was most definitely painful at times... but filled with hope. The hope that, there are some good people, such as Atticus, who will be strong enough to do right, when not many others are willing, even if they recognize it to be the decent thing to do. However, the story also showed the true colors and darkness of some... such as Mr. Ewell. Overall, a very good story about the hard realities of life.
2nd time reading, once again for English class. Still a bit dull for me, but I understood and appreciated it much more than last read.

I read this book first as a teenager. It came up as the selection for my moms club book group this month, and I thought I'd like to re-read it. I recall enjoying the book as an adolescent, but I think at that time I was reading more for meaning than the pleasure of reading (especially since I read it as a school assignment). Now as an adult, a mother, a more mature reader, and as someone who spent a fair chunk of her adult life in the American South, I have a new appreciation for the depth of Lee's genius in this work. 
 The writing is melodious. I luxuriated in the construction of her sentences, which hold layers of intricate meaning. The characters are human; they have complex motivations and make embarrassing gaffes like the rest of us do. Reading this book, I have clear images of Maycomb and its inhabitants. This for me is one of the tests of a "good book." I want to feel part of the cast of characters, and I absolutely feel a part of this town. 
 A scene that I had forgotten as a teen but which moved me nearly to tears reading it as an adult was when Scout approaches the crowd outside the jail. With relatively few words, Lee conveys fear, embarrassment, relief, pride, love, anger, and, for me, a sense of the ability of humans to redeem themselves simply by acting human.

Poor Tom Ronbinson's struggles on the other hand is the stuff of nightmares for many adults. I had this whole set of quotes on Word, right? But I forgot to save them >.< This book also has so much new words I came across, I even had a huge list of them (which also disappeared along with the quotes). I'm pretty sure that Scout had no problem passing her SAT's :P It is refreshing to see something new, though. (Impedimenta - sounds like something from Harry Potter, right? XD) 
 The ending: it was the best part of the book the first time I read it, it still is <3 :') And then the part where she says she never sees Boo Radley again... 
 This book is something that anyone can relate to, whether you're reading it right now, or fifty years from now. It's more than just black vs white - Maycomb is like a mini version world: It's where people will always look down on others, it's where some people will take advantage of others, it's where the bad guys seem louder than the good guys. And then there are a small minority who always make you appreciate human beings (especially kids). 
 People are people - despite what they do, they're still human beings that end up being your neighbors, your friends, the people you grew up with. They do what they do, you might not like what they do, but you still care about them.

To Kill a Mockingbird is like taking a look back at time so simple and elegant. It is not easy for me to like a book from the first few chapters but that is what it was like reading it. I think what I admired the most is how Atticus treats his two children, the way he deals with the mishappenings and wrongdoings, the way he approaches their problems and questions. He simply gave them their freedom to explore and experience without resistance to what they do or pressure to be or do something they do not want. He gave them the freedom of thought. His ideas about parenthood are pure gold. 
 "When a child asks you something, answer him, for goodness' sake. But don't make a production of it. Children are children, but they can spot an evasion quicker than adults, and evasion simply muddles 'em." 
 Unfortunately, the book was too boring for me. I could not get past the first half of the book, although it addresses major issues of that time, the main theme being racism. I think I will get around to reading it again one day. I guess now is not the right time for me to read it.
I'm ashamed to say I skimmed this both times I was assigned it, in middle school and high school. After hearing so many of my peers rave about it, I hope to come back to it someday.
