What can I say about this book that hasn't already been said? I loved it. It's certain that people have said those same words. I'm happy to join them. 
 Harper Lee introduces us to Scout, the young, precocious narrator of her novel who is probably one of the best characters written. Through Scout's eyes, alongside her brother Jem and cohort Dill, we gain a picture of growing up in a small town in 1930's Alabama. At the heart of the book is the trial of a black man accused of raping a white girl. The whole of the book reveals the weight these children face as adults divide themselves along lines of color, class and status. Thanks belong to a child's resilient nature and to their father Atticus, who quietly by example teaches them, and the reader, to see through eyes without prejudice. And I can't forget one Boo Radley. 
 Scout made me laugh throughout the entire book. Lee wrote her heroine's character with a child's innocence, an off-the-wall humor, and wisdom beyond her years. I thought the story was solid from beginning to end. Sometimes I could predict the outcome, but that took nothing away from my feelings for the story at the end. 
 I don't know if Harper Lee wrote the perfect book. I do believe that she tackled subjects that need to be read. Although the face of things may have changed over time, racism and prejudice still exist. If there's one thing people can do to change this, it is to write a story like Lee did. The book may be fiction, but there is so much truth inside its covers. 
 I've heard that Go Set a Watchman changes the way we see Atticus. I'm just happy that I'll at least get to read another book by Harper Lee. I'm sure if she had continued to write, all her books would have been compared to her first, but I wish there were more out there.

It was slow going and although I was very close to giving up, I am glad I persevered until the end. I enjoyed the 'loss of innocence' themes but did find the cultural/geographical setting hard to relate to. Readable but not one I would want to own/re-read.

I hadn't read this since 1995, and I figured it was time for a reread. It was so much better than I remembered. I recommend everyone take another look at it before Go Set a Watchman releases. I must admit it was hard to reread a book when there are so many new things I want to read. But it felt good to hang out with Atticus and Scout again. They are magical, the best characters of all time. There were so many moments my adult brain needed to redigest.

"I wanted you to see what real courage is, instead of getting the idea that courage is a man with a gun in his hand. It's when you know you're licked before you begin, but you begin anyway and see it through no matter what." 
 What is this book about? 
 The story takes place in a sleepy Southern Town in the 1930's during the Great Depression. People were poor and social equality was still a long way off. We follow Scout, her brother Jem and father Atticus through a court case that changes the lives of everyone living in Maycomb. During this case we tackle racism, religion, the coming-of-age of Scout, parenthood, love, death and every other aspect of life you can think off. 
 Why is it boring? 
 I guess it is kind of a legal drama... Not that those are boring and not that To Kill a Mockingbird is boring, but it's about the only fault I can come up with. This book would do well on job interviews. It's only fault is that it might just be a little bit too perfect. 
 Who would you recommend it to? 
 Everyone. This book is amazing at giving you perspective, at considering things from other people's point of view and imagining other people complexly. I completely understand that this book is required reading in most American schools and I don't understand why I haven't been told to read this by my own teachers. To Kill a Mockingbird will teach children and adults alike to think about someone else's circumstances and to not be prejudiced. The book is one long life lesson. If everyone would live according to the 'rules' set in this book, the world would be a much better place. 
 Why should I read it if it's boring?! 
 The prose is amazing, the story is so tight and just insanely emotionally resonating. All the characters in the book are perfect, but flawed in their own way, making them exceptionally human. I love Scout, the young girl who loves to read books and brawl with boys. Her brother Jem is amazing at being an older brother and when he cries about the injustice in the world, all you can do is just cry with him. And then we have Atticus. The most amazing man you will ever read about. I have not read The Road yet, so to me Atticus Finch is hands down the most amazing father in literature. God, there is so much gushing over this book, but it is completely well deserved. Go take a look at the Goodreads page and see how well loved this novel is. Just reading that you can feel how much love there is for the story Harper Lee wrote. What I love most about this book besides the characters, is how Harper Lee never gets preachy. She espouses all of this wisdom and creates near perfect characters that should be perfectly annoying. But she gives every character their own little flaw or strength, making them perfectly human instead. Also, when you finish this book, immediately go back to page 1 and read the first lines. You will be amazed at how well Harper Lee is at telling you a story. 
 Rating: 5/5

I never had to read this book in high school. We read Huckleberry Finn instead. But I decided to read it because an acquaintance of mine said it was his favorite book. Well, I have to say Harper Lee, you are truly remarkable, because it's a great great story. So sad, yet so understandable, so suspenseful, child-like but filled with incredible depth. 
 I also love Harper Lee and Truman Capote's relationship. It's really quite intriguing to think of writers in that way. Although that relationship doesn't really have anything to do with the book. I still find it fun to think about.

Not so much of a review... 
 This is not what you're used to see on this blog. I never review nor rate classic for a simple reason and it's they've been discussed and rated by so many people that my say in all that is irrelevant. But I've made a mistake and put this book into one of my challenges, and I hate leaving things unfinished, so I had to write a review. Make no mistake this is not a review as I won't talk much about this book but I'll talk about my lit classes instead. 
 In case that you don't know I'm a student at faculty (something similar to college) of Philology at English language and literature department. Even though after finishing the studies we more or less become English teachers (as hopefully I will one day) or translators that doesn't stop us from enjoying lit classes. At least it doesn't stop me. I love them for a simple reason and it's that they make me read books that I would never pick my myself nor would I even finish them. But then after discussing them I see the real beauty in them. The same happened with To Kill a Mockingbird. Let's face it, this is by far the most mentioned book in history of American lit and I've tried to read it few years ago and to see what's that all fuss about. I've never finished it as I couldn't understand lots of things. Things, of course, changed after I learnt about American history and discovered everything that happened during that period so now I could easily go through the book. Of course non of that would be possible without my teachers who always try to make them more interesting to us and help us to see real picture. And for that I'm really grateful. 
 Did I enjoy/love/hate this book would be hard to say, but I do see the reason why this is called a classic and why it's so important and that I know how to appreciate.

It took me a little while to get into this book. I didn't really understand what all the fuss was about. I kept waiting for the story to start, but the first couple of chapters is really just setting the scene, the characters, the town, the atmosphere. So I was feeling a little bit frustrated, like the story wasn't going anywhere. And then slowly, the plot started to take shape. 
 And now that the book is finished, I can say I thoroughly enjoyed it, and did get very attached to the characters.
Brilliant book! Loved eveything about it, characters, story, setting, pacing! Dialog...

Intense, vivid, funny, and poignant at times, there is definitely something about this book. Nevertheless, I was somewhat confused, the fault is most likely mine, and will probably read it again later.

Frankly speaking, this book is the pinnacle of literary pursuits. Harper Lee, a rarest of rare lady, has materialized the infinity that is childhood and growing up in the form of this amazing work of art. You feel you are an inherent part of the Finch family right from the first page and see your childhood trammels and tribulations, confusions and playfulness reflected in the everyday activities of the gang of children - Scout, Jem and Dill. 
 Atticus Finch, the lawyer and the father, is one of the greatest heroes I have encountered in English literature and if I personally turn out to be at least half as good as him, I will assume I have turned out to be a fine human being. His words, his lessons to his children and his behavior towards the world - everything is so endearing that you feel like reaching out to him and extend your gratitude for everything. 
 This book clearly has found its place right on the the top part of my All Time Favorites. Strongly, very strongly recommended!

5/5 - Scout Finch and her brother, Jem, live in a small town in 1930's Alabama with their father, Atticus, and housekeeper, Calpurnia. A neighbor, Dill, joins them in the summers and the trio spend their time outdoors, thinking up ways to lure the mysterious Boo Radley outside. One day, Scout and Jem learn that Atticus, a lawyer, will be representing Tom Robinson, a black man accused of raping and assaulting a white woman. Scout and Jem are harassed at school because of this, and their aunt eventually comes to live with them to help keep tomboy Scout out of trouble. Continued under spoilers... (view spoiler)[ The trial comes and goes (in an emotional scene that had me cheering for Atticus and furious at everyone else in the courtroom) and Tom, even though Atticus proves his innocence, is convicted of the crime. 
 Later on, Tom tries to escape jail but is shot and killed. Scout, Jem, and Dill are affected in various ways by the trial and learn important lessons. Slowly, life in Maycomb is returning to normal. However, Bob Ewell, the accuser's father and the one who actually assaulted her, is still furious with Atticus for publicly shaming him. He attacks Scout and Jem on their way home from a Halloween play. Boo Radley rescues the children, though Jem gets a broken arm, and kills Bob Ewell. Scout walks Boo back home after the Sheriff says, "There's black boy dead for no reason, and the man responsible for it's dead. Let the dead bury the dead this time, Mr. Finch." Atticus reads a book to Scout until she falls asleep and spends the night watching over Jem. (hide spoiler)] 
 I appreciated the simplicity of the language. It felt like I was reading a story in the hot, humid South. The story flowed perfectly with Lee's writing style; it was straightforward and charming yet never boring. I think the simplicity is what made the message so powerful. 
 I'm just going to assume that people who don't like this book (if you can believe that) were probably forced to read it. I know some also think the characters were a little one-dimensional. I understand that argument, but don't completely buy it. Sure, Atticus was a perfect, can-do-no-wrong father figure, but I don't think it made him unbelievable. He had the weight of the world - or at least Alabama - on his shoulders. He had to hold himself at a high standard, especially for his children. 
 Scout was my favorite, with her tomboy tendencies and polite back-talking. I loved that I could read from the perspective of a child and not want to skim over her thoughts. Once, she referred to waiting as "two eternities later," or something similar, and I laughed out loud. One character I wanted to see more of was Tom. His main appearance was in the courtroom and Atticus' speech on Tom's behalf there broke my heart, so naturally I wasn't satisfied. But because it was Scout's story and she was so young, Tom was only there to be an innocent - a mockingbird. 
 The following are a couple of quotes I most appreciated: 
 "People generally see what they look for, and hear what they listen for." 
 "Shoot all the Bluejays you want, if you can hit 'em. But remember it's a sin to kill a Mockingbird."
This book was absolutely fantastic. I really enjoyed it, and couldn't put it down.
the INJUSTICE of it all!

Definitely one of the best books i've read! It's a pity tom robinson was killed. I doubted Atticus was able to save him, but nonetheless, it's the little steps that counts. And Scout finally met Boo, nice scene!
I have read this book several times. A great book.

Finished this during Dewey's 24 hour Readathon 
 *Read for the 2016 reading challenge: A classic from the 20th century*
First time I read this was in school but I really enjoyed the story. It's a great classic.

This book is so idyllic and the protagonist so naive it is almost painful. 
 But we shouldn't forget that the book is written from a child's perspective over the course of several (I'm not sure if it was three or four) years. Scout was not older than 9 years old at the time the events happened, so I don't think it is fair to say that she is naive. She is a child. 
 This is also a part of my 2016 Classics Challenge 
 WHEN I Discovered This Classic 
 I first heard about this book last year in the London Underground where the billboards where advertising Harper Lee's second book - Go Set a Watchman. They had both of her books in one binding and so I became interested in it. Being German I seriously hadn't heard about it before. 
 WHY I Chose to Read It 
 I chose to read it because I was interested in the racial conflicts in the 1960s. Because this book is set in the 1960s (and I knew it contained a serious amount of racism) I was reluctant to read it at first, but then I discovered I would jump right into it, regardless of what the author had to say about the issue. 
 WHAT Makes It A Classic 
 Just like The Adventures of Huckleberry Finn and Tom Sawyer, this book is written from a child's perspective. I am of the opinion that children do often have a different view on things than adults and I was very interested in what a little girl had to say. It is also a classic because this book does not judge. Atticus Finch sees to that. 
 WHAT I Thought of This Classic 
 I loved it. I loved the characters, I loved the way the children were portrayed, the trial itself was very interesting and the fact that Atticus Finch is one of the deepest characters that I have ever read made it so fantastic. 
 WILL It Stay A Classic 
 Yes, indeed. Because of Atticus Finch's personality and morals. 
 WHO I'd Recommend It To 
 Everyone having dealt with racism and those who are not (yet) educated about the racial system in the United States in the 1960s and before that. Shoutout to my fellow Europeans!
Needs a re-read.

This is the one novel I didn't mind reading in my boring English class in high school. Scout and Jem Finch explore the racism of the South in the 1930s as their father handles the defense of a black man accused of raping a white woman. The story is timeless and the Gregory Peck movies is worth watching as well.
For a novel we had to read for school, it wasn't bad. It brought up a lot of strong points and did make you think a bit. For me, it was too detailed in things I don't find interest in.

To Kill a Mockingbird has been on my list for ever so long. I re-watched the Gregory Peck movie and that decided me; I had to get a copy. 
 Touching, poignant, deeply telling of a flawed system in a divided South. I mention the symbolism, allegory and foreshadowing of Atticus killing the dog and I'm wondering if To Kill a Mockingbird needs to be retaught. Such hatred still exists and not all of it's online.
Such an amazing book. I wish I read it when I was younger.

To my surprise I enjoyed To Kill A Mockingbird, despite the fact that it wasn't the usual type of novel that I tend to read. I also watched the 1962 movie too, starring Gregory Peck, to enhance my understanding of the points the story was making: it covered most of the major plot elements contained in the book, albeit in a slightly different order, emphasising certain aspects of the novel for dramatic effect and leaving others out; it was an interesting comparison. In this brief review I'm not going to run through the plot, rather I'm going to touch on the various themes which I noticed: 
 Good versus Evil 
 "Mockingbirds don't do one thing but . . . sing their hearts out for us. That's why it's a sin to kill a mockingbird." 
 The exploration of what it means to be good or evil is covered extensively. Mockingbirds (such as Tom Robinson, Boo Radley and possibly even Atticus) are almost entirely good but the characters exhibit and deal with this goodness in different ways, for example Boo hides from evil and Atticus fights it head on. However with Atticus he also understands that good people are weak enough to support an evil cause, for example Mrs. Dubose. Atticus also recognises that we all have a basic level of human dignity which requires respect and an attempt to understand individual points of view, he says: 
 "You never really understand a person until you consider things from his point of view--until you climb into his skin and walk around in it." 
 The novel suggests that failure to "stand in the other persons shoes", leads to intolerance and fear which then leads to prejudice and injustice. Once you take the time to understand why a person is behaving in a certain way then tolerance and sympathy will follow which will then ultimately remove prejudice. 
 This lesson in morality suggests that you can live with dignity without becoming overly pessimistic at how others conduct themselves. Scout grasps this when later in the novel she acknowledges Boo for who he is not who she thinks he is; he becomes fully human to Scout, illustrating that she has developed into a sympathetic and understanding individual. Despite the pain Boo has suffered, the purity of his heart guides his dealings with the children; he saves Jem and Scout from Bob Ewell and is the greatest symbol of what it is to be good. 
 Interestingly, the novel doesn't provide clear guidance on how to approach those people who are integrally evil and who are indifferent to reason. That is left up to the reader to consider alone. 
 Groups versus Individuals 
 I mentioned the effect that the irrational grouping of people has in my review of Cats Cradle; while Atticus considers the individual others in the book use religion, race, class, gender or the expected behavioural patterns of society to group people together, set certain standards and norms, create stereotypes and then demand conformity to these; this is sometimes called "prejudice" (see above). 
 Perhaps the most powerful example is how most people in the book perceive black people: they are either stupid or evil, both assumptions are skilfully dismissed by the author. For example, even though the black characters are of a lower class than the white Ewells they are more law abiding, accommodating and hard working. 
 Growing Up 
 The children in the book question what doesn't make sense to them, for example the pervasive prejudice and as the novel progresses the children age and slowly lose their innocence: at the start they equate good to mean Atticus and the citizens of Maycomb and evil is personified in the mysterious Boo. As the book concludes their outlook becomes more realistic and they begin to understand the complex nature of morality: everyone is good or evil to a greater or lesser extent. 
 To Kill a Mockingbird also condemns standardized school education: memorisation of facts and figures and the hypocrisy shown when it comes to the discussions about the Nazi party and democracy all highlight how schools create conformist children as opposed to critical thinkers who foster shared understanding across the artificial boundaries mentioned earlier. 
 Courage 
 The theme of courage was perhaps the most powerful for me. Atticus defines courage are follows: 
 "It's when you know you're licked before you begin but you begin anyway and you see it through no matter what. You rarely win, but sometimes you do." 
 Courage therefore is not the same as power or might, it's about doing what you know is the right thing regardless of what others think (here's an example of this). 
 As: 
 "The one thing that doesn't abide by majority rule is a person's conscience." 
 In conclusion, the skill that has gone into writing this novel is really only understood when you have completed it and thought about the entire story. One the one hand it is a simple morality tale but on the other it really is one of the books that every adult should read before they die.

To Kill a Mockingbird is a great, important book, of course, but I'm not sure it's always so great on literary merit alone. Everything's a little too heavy handed, from its morality to its symbolism to its characterization. Don't get me wrong: this overtness was necessary at a time where many largely white literary readers needed an object lesson in humanity, but the book clearly makes some aesthetic sacrifices to suit its rhetorical purposes. Also, white savior narratives are always problematic, even if this benevolent white savior does ultimately fail. I acknowledge this is a modern view of a classic work, but, I'm only discussing aesthetics here. The dramatic structure's a little wonky too, with chapters serving as their own mini-narrative parables, and the primary conflict not even making itself known until about halfway through the book. A better title might be a Twainesque The Adventures of Scout Finch, providing a clear signal that there's not always much unity among these multiple plots. 
 Still, even beyond TKAM's admirable politics, much of the book does work well. Scout is great narrator, witty and wry and nostalgic about her childhood yet reflective. I think people forget how funny this book is (I certainly did in the years between reading it as a high school student and teaching it as a high school English teacher). Think of the films The Sandlot or A Christmas Story and that's very much the tone here, with an occasional Southern Gothic twist. Also, the author manages a clever narrative device throughout the book where Scout's age sometimes renders her an unreliable narrator in intriguing ways. Not a dishonest narrator but one who, despite how precocious she is, isn't always privy to the world of adults and interprets what's happening around her through the euphemism and evasion of adults in her life. It leads her to moments where she misinterprets situations yet manages to, for example, save her father's life and stop a murderous lynch mob with some "aw shucks, golly gee whizz" preciousness. It's fairly similar to those early Harry Potter books/films where those three wizard kids stumble around on investigations based on faulty premises only to inadvertently save their school and its negligent adult educators. 
 All in all, TKAM is a deserving classic even if some its devices feel a bit outdated. I've met people black and white who consider it their favorite book of all time. I'm glad about that; people could do much worse. Its heart is in the right place, and its message about the ethical responsibilities of individuals within unethical societies still matters today. It also reminds us that our conventional wisdom and first impressions of others--not just people of other races but also mysterious recluse neighbors and mean spirited old ladies--are often revealed to be flawed once we have a little more information. As Atticus says during one of his Yoda meets Dumbledore meets Aslan moments, "You never really understand a person until you consider things from his point of view [...] until you climb into his skin and walk around in it." If the book can still teach this, it's still worth reading today.

To Kill a Mockingbird--written during the peak of the civil rights movement, when hatred and fear penetrated the hearts of those who feared change and what that change meant (equality among the races, leading to the loss of white's current position of "superiority") often leading to riots and violent attacks--came at a much needed moment in American history and is well deserving of the Pulitzer prize awarded to it. 
 Harper Lee crafts a novel that conveys ideas of compassion, equality for all, and the injustices of racial discrimination, while not becoming too preachy. She accomplishes this by telling the story from the eyes of an innocent young girl, unaware of the racial tensions around her. In fact, the first part of the story does not deal with Tom Robinson's case or racial issues at all, rather it's about a couple of kids playing together during the summer time, absorbed in the mystery of what has become of Boo Radley. Beginning the story this way allows the reader to become emotionally involved with Scout, and her uncorrupted view of mankind, before leaping into the crux of the novel.The African Americans in To Kill a Mockingbird have been criticized as lacking dimension and I don't disagree with this, however, Scout--being an unreliable narrator and a young white girl--would not have the perspective or the familiarity with black people to give them depth, so I believe Harper Lee could not have rendered them any other way. 
 This book is more than a novel about race; Lee explores the evil in humanity (the use of religion as a way to spew hatred, the hypocrisy of people, peoples tendency to judge others on superficial terms, the failures of the education system), yet at the same time the book is full of love, compassion, and hope. To Kill a Mockingbird is a book about growing up and the lessons that come with it, that should be read by all children coming of age.

Though one of the major plot point concerns an unfair conviction of an African American man, there is more in this book than a simple criticism of racism: it's also about the absurdity and destructive effect of class, gender and racial discrimination in a stagnate yet slowly changing community, about faith and hope, and about a child's coming of age in an oppressive world.

Clearly, Scout Finch is no ordinary five-year-old girl--and not only because she amuses herself by reading the financial columns of the Mobile Register, but because her nine-year-old brother Jem allows her to tag along when he and Dill Harris try to make Boo Radley come out. 
 Boo is the Radley son who has not shown his face outside the creaky old family house for 30 years and more, probably because he has "shy ways," but possibly --an explanation the children much prefer--because his relatives have chained him to his bed. Dill has the notion that Boo might be lured out if a trail of lemon drops were made to lead away from his doorstep. Scout and Jem try a midnight invasion instead, and this stirs up so much commotion that Jem loses his pants skittering back under the fence. 
 Scout and her brother live in Maycomb, Alabama, where every family that amounts to anything has a streak--a peculiar streak, or a morbid streak, or one involving a little ladylike tippling at Lydia Pinkham bottles filled with gin. The Finch family streak is a good deal more serious --it is an overpowering disposition toward sanity. This is the flaw that makes Jem interrupt the boasting of a lineage-proud dowager to ask "Is this the Cousin Joshua who was locked up for so long?" And it is what compels Lawyer Atticus Finch, the children's father, to defend a Negro who is charged with raping a white woman. The rape trial, Jem's helling, and even Boo Radley are deeply involved in the irregular and very effective education of Scout Finch. By the time she ends her first-person account at the age of nine, she has learned that people must be judged, but only slowly and thoughtfully. 
 Author Lee, 34, an Alabaman, has written her first novel with all of the tactile brilliance and none of the preciosity generally supposed to be standard swamp-warfare issue for Southern writers. The novel is an account of an awakening to good and evil, and a faint catechistic flavor may have been inevitable. But it is faint indeed; Novelist Lee's prose has an edge that cuts through cant, and she teaches the reader an astonishing number of useful truths about little girls and about Southern life.
Sweet, nostalgic. Surely one of the classics.

I'm glad I finally had the opportunity to read this classic. Somehow, I never had. I can see why it is an enduring novel. There's a lot that happens over the course of the book, but the themes in here are long-lasting. 
 I was surprised to find that the novel was not entirely about the trial of Tom Robinson, but more about Scout and Jem growing up, evolving into different people. Over the course of the novel the children grow and change, coming to the harsh realization that life in their little town is far from perfect. The two are faced with evils that they did not know existed, and must learn how to actually deal with them. 
 The book is a very entertaining and charming read in itself, and the audiobook read by Sissy Spacek is awesome.

 Classic.

 I'm not going to review it. You'd have to be a fool.

What's not to love about this book? How can one not love the three Finches? Scout embodies the youthful innocence perfectly; Jem shows signs of a well-known child growing into puberty; Atticus is this solemn, just father whom his children call "Sir". 
 I first read this story a little under two years ago. Back then, I did not grasp the full extent of the content Ms Lee developed under the reader's very eyes. Rural Alabama, in the 1930s, populated by a still ever so racist population, one who does not deign to use the words Negro and nigger to describe black people. Rural Alabama, in the 1930s, wherein two white kids witness the stirring of a tranquil town when their lawyer father defends a black man unjustly accused of raping a white young lady. 
 Now, I can at last grasp the meaning of Harper Lee's book, and I wish I could rate this six stars.

a touching, heartbreaking and funny look at childhood and race relations, this book has sadly been ruined for many people by being a forced text in schools.

Probably my 20th re-read of this wonderful book.
I can certainly see why this is required reading in many US schools.

I have always wanted to read this book, but I don't think I ever understood how much I'd like it. It was so beautifully written and I found so many lines that I kept reading over and over because they made so much sense and were constructed in a beautiful way. 
 I loved the characters, and the story. It is so sad when you think of that this used to be, and still is in some places, a reality. That people judged each other based on skin color, and decided to treat people horribly because they weren't white. 
 It's heartbreaking and makes you sick, because it's so stupid and sad and yet few people spoke up to try and change it. 
 Well, in the book Atticus did speak up, but everyone turned against him except for the few who secretly agreed with him. 
 Atticus is probably one of my favorite characters, I loved him because of the good he saw in people and because he tried to raise his children in a world that so desperately tried to teach them how to be superior because of the color of their skin. Atticus never let them believe that, instead he taught them about Mockingbirds, and how it's a sin to ever kill one.

Best. Book. Ever. 
 (This was a re-read.)

I expected the book to be completely boring. However, I was pleasantly surprised by how much I enjoyed it. I normally just read YA books and the "classics" usually bore me, but this book was an exception. I would say that it's popular for a reason. Great read!
One of the best books I've ever read.

I approached this with a kind of wariness that came with the fact that I'll never have the same emotional reaction to this book as people for whom it is formative. Regardless, it was honestly compelling and quite moving. While it is simplistic in its depiction of some societal inequities, I got no sense that it was trying to flatter the status quo out of some misguided sense of nostalgia. The setting held a lot of warmth and love but there was also a lot of ugliness, and that came through in the story as well.

Originally posted on www.yearningtoread.blogspot.com 
 Jean Louise (Scout) Finch is the feistiest girl in Maycomb, Alabama in the 1930's. She's six years old and doesn't care to be a lady. She wants to wear pants all her life and mess around with her older brother Jem and their friend, Dill, who visits every summer. To Kill a Mockingbird spans over a couple years of Scout's life, during which she becomes engaged to Dill, attempts to befriend a reclusive neighbor - and, most importantly, witnesses a trial during which a young black man is accused of raping a poor young white girl. These events are seen from the young, questioning eyes of a little girl who wants to understand. It is heart-breaking, eye-opening, and a book that everyone should take the time to devour. 
 _______________________________________________ 
 My thoughts - 
 This is my first time reading To Kill a Mockingbird (people have looked at me, shocked, for saying that), and not only can I say that I've read it, but I can also say that I loved it. 
 I was quite moved by this story. Moved to laughter, moved to sorrow, moved to anger, moved to love. I was inspired by this little girl Jean Louise who saw the world so innocently. I wanted to be like her. I want to be like her. She was precious to read about. 
 Character notes - 
 Scout Finch has a sarcasm that's hard to miss. It adds life to the story and made me laugh. She's one smart little seven-year-old. She understands most things - and when she doesn't she asks questions. Questions that made me think. Questions that seven-year-olds now would never think to ask. Scout is also a deep thinker, pondering the world in that innocent light that she views everything. 
 She loves her family. She has a heart for her brother...wants to do everything to be like him. When he starts to grow up, she doesn't understand it, but she tries her hardest. Because she loves him. 
 And she loves her father, too. Oh boy, their relationship tugged at my heart more than anything else in this story. Atticus Finch is older, has no wife, and would be lonely but for his lovely children. Scout and Jem mean everything him, and he means everything to them, even when they would like to say otherwise. Atticus very easily became my favorite character - for his bravery, his selflessness, his humility, and his desire to do what is right...at all costs. 
 Story notes - 
 This story is well told from the first word to the last. It weaves in family troubles, characters being built, the culture in the south in that time of history, the town's trials and triumphs, strange neighbors, unlikely friends... All of this is seen through the eyes of an observant six/seven/eight year old, and I can't imagine it any other way. It was the perfect touch for the story's progression. 
 Speaking of the progression...it was slow. But not in an "I'm bored, please get me out of here" way, but in a languid, beautiful, floating way. It was a current, slow and constant, and it pulled me along until we reached the shore, where I sat, watching the tide drifting away, knowing that I would never forget that experience. 
 When I first started reading this book, I expected it to be mainly about the rape trial. While I was at first confused that it wasn't, I couldn't stay confused for long. The depth and intense character development in the rest of the story led up to the trial and its outcome - and even events after the trial. 
 One word I'd use to sum up this novel (final thoughts) - 
 Eager. Because while the whole town is languid, underneath the surface a passion is stirring - and it is seen in Atticus and his bravery; Miss Maudie and her garden; Jem and his desire to be like his father; Tom Robinson and his innocent friendship with the poor white girl; and little Scout, who cannot get enough of her world, and who won't let it fly by without having a word or two with it. This really is one exceptional story.

Gooooooooood book. A look at some of the injustice of the world through the eyes of an innocent child. A tale told in a manner charming and thought-provoking, and very easy to forget oneself in. Requires a little bit of patience to get through, but still, it is too well-written to be boring.
I thought Scout's voice was a delight to read.

Burn me at the stake if you want, I just didn't like this book. Maybe because I've read it in the 2010's, not the 1960's. I know a girl named Scout-possibly after this book-and several others with names like Hunter and Tyler. I can't recall reading a book where the protagonist actually wants to be a lady. I live in a world where it's perfectly normal for girls to play basketball and football, so Scout's tomboyish nature isn't surprising. 
 She doesn't do anything. She's the narrator, but Atticus is the real protagonist. Scout is an innocent bystander. 
 And then there's the structure. The first half is simply "I live in a small Alabama town where it doesn't snow so we can't make a decent snowman." Then suddenly, BAM, racism. I can see why so many people reread this. It has that cozy storybook feel to it, like The Hobbit. And a lot of old books now that I think of it. That's how they stay in print. You curl up on the couch on a rainy day and read it for the millionth time. Nostalgia by nature. 
 I don't think it would get published today. The literature world is used to stories that start when the book does, none of this insert lengthy family history stuff. Too slow. 
 I know Harper Lee is an important woman who shaped history. I just can't appreciate it.

It's hard to say anything original about such a literary classic when everything has been said before. So I won't, roll on the cliches... 
 Possibly the single best written book I've read to date. Harper Lee's mastery of the English language is nothing short of magical. For at least the first half of the book the story and plot are very secondary and background characters. Instead what we get is a masterclass in scene setting and charactisation. 
 The second half of the book sees all the real action and Harper Lee expertly hammering home the main themes of the book. 
 To walk a mile in another man's shoes.

I just adore this book and have read it several times, though it's been quite a long while since my last reading. 
 Every time I read To Kill a Mockingbird I find something new to love. I've always been drawn to Scout and Atticus and Boo, and this go-around was no different. What was new this time around was that I found myself really appreciating and loving Miss Maudie and Jem in a whole new way.

This was so good! Surprisingly good, even. I went into such a well-known 'classic' with a lot of skepticism, but... wow. That was really good. 
 I think it was because of the characters. Unlike most writers of 'classic' novels, Harper Lee seems to understand the importance of likable, interesting characters. If Atticus, Jem, and Scout had been less interesting, I probably would have been bored out of my mind; but because those three main characters had such life and conflict, it was fascinating to read about them. 
 One classic that's definitely worth reading - if not for the messages, then just for the spectacular characterization.
It was beautiful, there's so much childhood here it got me nostalgic.

This was literally the only time where I saw a movie before reading the book. I loved the movie, but there were some serious plotholes I figured would be in the book, so I was so excited to read it. It might be the first time I've ever said this, EVER, but I really think the movie was better than the book. 
 There are a few reasons for this. Kathy, the narrator, often becomes annoying. I think the this author is fantastic because I feel like EVERYTHING that was said or done had a true purpose or motivation, but it really just wasn't my cup of tea I guess. Kathy was telling the story as an adult, but was often recalling her childhood or young adulthood. Everything she said had a justification behind it, and it got taxing. She would say something like, "This happened, but I never knew it would lead to this...but this is why I did it." I think that this was important when the author posed the idea of whether or not these clones, these men and women who are basically nothing but spare parts, have souls. Kathy does get very deep and seems to have a great understanding of her actions and their consequences, but she does not seem to really be an adult. It was interesting, and I see the purpose for it, but I just didn't like it much. 
 Secondly, the book seems much more emotionally shallow than the movie. When Ruth admits that she knows it should have been Tommy and Kathy together all this time...if I wouldn't have seen the movie, I would have been like, "Well, why would you think that? They show no real preference to one another in a romantic way." Kathy even seems mildly verbally abusive to Tommy. The whole time they are out looking for Kathy's tape in the shops, she calls him an idiot every chance she gets. And then when they do get together, it's so one dimentional. Kathy talks about sex all throughout the novel in a very fleeting way, which is all part of their lifestyle since they cannot have children or marry or have families. I don't know why, but this irked me to no end. I was expecting her to talk about sleeping with Tommy and having it be like nothing she'd ever experienced...but it was like it didn't matter, even with him. 
 Lastly, the climax of the story, I think, should be Tommy getting out of the car after their visit with Madame and Miss Emily and throwing the first fit he'd had in years. In the movie, this was a phenomenal scene and I really just...felt it and understood how devastating it would be...but in the book, that scene barely even registered. 
 So, I guess all I have to wrap it up was that I liked the movie better...and that never happens. It was well written, and I think that had I read it first, I may have viewed the film in an entirely differently light. The movie made the characters more likable (even Ruth) which made me more invested. Oh well.

This book is heavy with the theme of what makes people 'good' and 'bad'. The rigid social divisions don't define it, the racial divisions don't, age divisions, gender, etc. I like how this book shows us how Scout essentially grows up, how she learns and develops her own morality with the events of the summer weighing in heavily. 
 The implications of our society and the racial struggles we are still faced with is depressing. We like to think we've come so far in the past 80 years, but have we really? The symbolism of the mockingbird was beautiful, and I like how it came full circle in the end.

Set during Civil War, this main theme of these story is about racism. The story was about childhood in Maycomb town. 
 The story was nice, with great plot and writing style.

I read it once in high school, and liked it. Recently I went to a live production which was great, so I picked up the book again. I appreciate Atticus much more now, and I find Scout funnier. It's a classic and it's worth being read far more than once.
Had no clue what to expect when reading this book -- but now that I have, I rather enjoyed it. It wasn't as sad as I pictured. But realistic with a plot twist at the end.

To be honest, I read this several years back, so this isn't a review of a book I read recently. I'm reviewing from memory, so this will be short. 
 I liked this book a lot. I read it when I was pretty young, so I probably didn't get everything out of it that I would if I read it now (which I really should, by the way ... if I do, I'll review it more thoroughly). 
 I think this is another book like Gone with the Wind ... a one-time triumph from an author that can never be repeated (which is the reason I'm delaying reading Go Set a Watchman). Atticus Finch is my hero. Scout inspired the main character in one of my novels more than any other character in fiction, just as Jem somewhat inspired another character of mine. The plot is very touching, at times slightly humorous, and overall inspiring. 
 Well, that's all I have to say for now since I've put my two-bits in, even if they're identical to what everyone else has said. :) 
 ~Kellyn Roth

Man.... I am (nearly) 32 and last read this book when I was a freshman in high school. I don't think I could appreciate the beautiful complexity at that age. I'm certain I didn't because I'm sure it would have stuck with me through my 20s. 
 This is probably one of the greatest moral books of our time. A gentle fable that gently leads the reader to confront prejudice in the world, and more importantly, in ourself. We are all Scout, Jen, Boo, Eula May, Bob, Miss Stephanie and Atticus. We all have streaks of mean seated curiosity, strength, oddness, meanness, gossip, and wisdom. 
 What a pleasure to read this book in a time that feels so uncertain. But... It's not time to worry just yet.

I thought it was a good book. There was a lot of views into the lives of the characters and althought it was something I wouldn't usually read, it was a good book. It is something that I would not mind reading again if I had the chance.

4.5 stars. An impressive story about how racism and prejudice are learnt behaviours. Parts of the book, particularly in the first half, were slow going, but they did manage to emanate a particular atmosphere that made me more involved in the rest of the story.

Although I did find the daily life of Scout and Jem to be interesting, I didn't start getting really into this book until Tom Robinson's trial. I unfortunately was never assigned to read this book in high school. I think it would definitely have made me question the culture I grew up in more and the values it (but not necessarily I) held. I can see how this book would have been very controversial when it was originally published in 1960. It made people look at a part of themselves they would rather have ignored. I think some people still need to read it in today's society!

Like everyone else, I read this in school, and do not recall having strong feelings about it. This year I decided to re-read it, alongside Go Set a Watchman, for the sake of having an informed opinion about both. This is such a well-known book that there's no need for another review of it; what follows are some thoughts from this time around. There may be spoilers. 
 What struck me right away is Lee's craft: her writing and storytelling (not the same thing) are both excellent. I have a habit of reading the openings of books when I first bring them home, and sometimes several more times before actually starting to read them, just to whet my appetite. I tried that with this book and didn't stop for more than 50 pages. The story is compelling, every scene comes vividly to life, and yet there's an impressive economy of language - at some point I realized I was moving through the book more slowly than expected, not because it's difficult to read (it isn't) but because every word is important. It is simply a pleasure to read. 
 And yet, I did not fall in love with the characters the way many readers have. I am not generally a fan of stories told through the eyes of young children (even though Scout is recounting events from an adult vantage point, and I enjoyed her voice), and Scout, unsurprisingly for a 6- to 8-year-old, feels a little unformed, at the margins of the real story. At times it felt I was reading a father-son story from the wrong perspective. It was distancing. 
 Whatever else this may be, it does not read like a YA book; novels written before that marketing category existed generally don't. Scout is too young for teen fiction, and the book isn't really about her. One never loses sight of the fact that the other characters in it all have lives that don't revolve around her; that is a sign of good writing, of course. The book does have a tendency to provide explicit moral lessons, generally through Atticus, but I took these scenes less as moralizing at the reader than as a portrayal of a harried single father looking for teachable moments in difficult situations. And the book doesn't make everything explicit: did I realize as a kid that Mayella was sexually abused by her father, that Tom Robinson definitely wasn't climbing a fence, that the sheriff's true concern for Boo isn't an excess of cakes? 
 Of course, some of the book's biggest moral lessons have to do with race, and on that subject there are ways the book has aged very well and ways that it hasn't. Make no mistake: this book is all about white people. The central conflict is between educated, fair-minded white people, who are nonetheless paternalistic in their attitudes, and the rest of the white community, who, as Atticus observes, lose their heads over race. Black people are almost incidental to this conflict - the only semi-developed black character is the housekeeper, Calpurnia, and it's a white man, Atticus Finch, who's positioned as Tom Robinson's savior. 
 With the publication of Go Set a Watchman, there has been talk about Atticus's (and Lee's) views on segregation. It is interesting that this book, published in 1960 and known as a seminal book about race in America, barely addresses what was the great moral and political issue of the day. It is also interesting that, in the early draft (that being Go Set a Watchman), she did - that early version was set in the 1950s, but by Mockingbird it had become historical fiction, taking place in the 30s. That could be viewed as a cop-out: it's always easier to be on the right side of history when you're writing about the past. And yet, the funny thing is that while the great issue of Harper Lee's day has been resolved - no more legally enforced segregation - the issues she reached back into the past to write about - inequality in the criminal justice system; black men being shot by white officials under suspicious circumstances - are still absolutely timely in 2015. 
 Then too, readers would be mistaken to think that Lee could only see the most egregious forms of injustice; there are subtler observations, too. Scout notices, for instance, that white people driving back from the dump use black residents' yards to turn around in. And Calpurnia and her son work menial jobs despite their evident intelligence (she taught him to read using Blackstone's Commentaries on the Laws of England). When Lee does address segregation, it's in the context of white people crossing the color line, never the other way around - but it's evident where she stands. And in that context, I don't believe Atticus, as the moral center of the novel, is a segregationist in his final incarnation. 
 I won't be reading about Atticus's earlier incarnations, though, because in reading this novel, I realized that Watchman is superfluous. We already have Lee's final product, the excellent novel that was the only book she ever meant to publish. I am satisfied to have enjoyed it as Harper Lee intended, and I'll leave it at that.
I'm still reeling a bit from this book. All I can say is that I see why it is a classic. May this be a highschool reading book for years to come.

I cried at the end! I really loved the way the author aproached the probem of racism and I thought the main character was so well-made! Loved the character of Bau Radley all throughout the book and I didn't doubt he was a good person! :d

I have read so many things about this book - mainly raving, fangirly reviews about ATTICUS and SCOUT and JEM and the GENERAL AWESOMENESS, and how you haven't lived until you read this book. 
 Frankly, I didn't believe any of it. I was tired of hearing about the book, I didn't think it really could be that good, and I didn't have any plans to read this book in the near future. 
 But then my sister got it out of the library and loved it, and since I was by that time finished with my schoolwork for the year, I thought, well, why not? And so - I read it. AND I COULDN'T PUT IT DOWN. 
 Of course I don't subscribe to the view that you're a horrible person if you don't like this book, but I agree with just about everything else. This book is the GOODS, people. I found myself really connecting with Atticus, since he's an INTJ just like me, and I loved Scout and Jem and Dill and Boo Radley and Miss Maudie and everyone . . . I could go on forever about what I liked, because I liked the WHOLE DANG THING. 
 Read the book, people-with-my-former-views. You won't regret it.
I remember reading this in school and it it such a classic and I recommend that people read this book at least once.

Told through the eyes of Atticus Finch's children, To Kill a Mockingbird is a story set in a small Alabama town in the 1930s. Atticus is a lawyer defending a black man charged with the rape of a white woman. The book explores the themes of prejudice, class, and that life is often unfair. 
 There are also humorous and tender elements in the book since Scout is an outspoken tomboy and Jem is changing from a boy to an aware young man. Atticus is a caring, wise man that showed his children how to live by his good example. This book deserves its place as a well-loved classic.
One of my absolute favorite books

For me, this book started out slowly. If it weren't o highly acclaimed, I probably would not have persevered. I am very glad that I did continue to read. There were a lot of things about this book that held my interest. I was particularly surprised by the ending, and liked the twist. 
 It was interesting to read this book in my present state of mind, where there have been so many police killings of black men, and the justice system is still not serving them. At the same time, reading the story as a woman, ,and it being about rape and believing a woman about whether or not that rape happened. I felt very conflicted, because of all that I brought to the book as I read it.

I never read this book in high school. I think it gave me a different perspective reading it when I was older. Some things in life never really change like world views of people. It will always be there.

I started this book with some trepidation, as it had been talked-up by almost everyone I know that had read it. I'm so glad that it didn't disappoint. 
 The characters really are loveable, especially Scout and her innocent perspective as she processes and recounts such shocking events, which creates such a contrast in the narrative.... truly wonderful stuff. The plot was exciting and the book as a whole such a captivating read. 
 The author presents the sensitive moral issues of the text without being at all preachy. Atticus Finch is the father we all needed growing up. What a guy.

Actual Rating 3.5 stars 
 "Until I feared I would lose it, I never loved to read. One does not love breathing." 
 This has been on my TBR list since I started my account and got into reading, I just didn't have the opportunity to read it until recently. And with over 3 million reads and 4.25 rating, I really think that there is something wrong with me. 
 Before going further into this review, I need to make a confession: I was in a kind of reading slump and that may have slightly effected my rating and review. 
 Now, I seriously considered NOT finishing this book, the start was so slow and the interesting parts only came later, I was saying that there is something that everybody can see in this book except for me, all my GR friends gave this book 4 or 5 stars and that was driving me crazy, I have only not-finished a book till now and I didn't want to add this book to that list so I decided it is only fair to give it a chance. 
 What I like 
 Fortunately, I ended up liking some parts of the story, the story only caught my attention from the trial onward. I like that it has been written in 1960 and the vibe to it certainly felt good. I can't say that it was nostalgic - I am not that old- but reading a book in that period of time is excellent for a change, and I ended up learning that many things are not as modern as I think they are. 
 Mr.Atticus Finch Character was intriguing and we need many Finches nowadays, that would make the world a better place. I just would have loved if he stood up for himself a little more. 
 The central message of the story is a 5 stars message and I assure you, had I read the book in the 60s (If I was born then), this would have been also a 5 stars book. 
 "I think there's just one kind of folks. Folks." 
 What I don't like 
 The slow pacing of the story and the overuse of description were excruciating. I also don't like Scout personality, she was annoying and many times I would confuse her for a boy, her brother Jem, was going through puberty and most children that age are annoying -which means actually that he had a well written character- 
 Also sometimes I would be confused of how did they end up discussing a certain subject, and finally there was a lot of use of the N world -Not in a bad way though- that made me kind of uncomfortable. 
 So I ended up liking some parts and hating others, and I can see why many people like this. Now I finally feel free. 
 In conclusion, I think this book is not as bad as I thought it is, I can actually recommend this to certain readers (I have a target audience for it in my mind), I think the story ends here for me and I am quite sure I am not going to read the second book. My mission finally ends here!

Harper Lee's acclaimed novel, To Kill A Mockingbird has long been considered one of the top books in American literature. I still remember reading the novel during my freshmen year of high school. While some of the themes may have gone over my head, I was immediately attracted to the style of Lee's writing and have always held the book in high regard. The famously reclusive author was recently thrust back into the spotlight when it was announced that her long lost manuscript, Go Set A Watchman, would be published. There continues to be quite a bit of confusion and controversy surrounding the discovery and release of this fifty-year-old story, but I knew that I would be reading it. With this new work, I decided to revisit To Kill A Mockingbird as well. 
 Immediately, Lee's prose transports readers to a simpler time. Through her juvenile protagonist, Scout, Lee documents a coming of age story that dares to tackle racism, ignorance, and justice. Mockingbird is set in Maycomb, Alabama, a picturesque little town, during the 1930's. Scout spends her summer days playing with her older brother Jem and their friend Dill. The trio has a particular interest in their mysteriously reclusive neighbor Boo Radley. Maycomb lore tells cautionary tales against disturbing Boo, but Scout and her gang are determined to sneak up to his house and catch a glimpse of him. 
 Amongst the vignettes of Scout's childhood games and experiences emerges a larger narrative thread that involves her father Atticus. Atticus Finch stands as a shining literary example of what a father is and should aspire to be. His wife died during childbirth, so he has taken to raising his children on his own. As a father and the local town lawyer, Atticus becomes the moral compass for his family and the local justice system. When Tom Robinson, an African-American man, is accused of raping a local woman, Atticus volunteers to defend him. A riveting trial ensues, and Scout begins to witness the ways in which her family and town react to the racially charged proceedings. 
 It is almost impossible to write an objective review of this classic. Harper Lee and To Kill A Mockingbird were placed upon a literary pedestal long before I cracked the spine of this novel. But there is something to be said for the profound effect that this story has on those who read it. Through a lyrically southern voice that instantly captivates your imagination, Lee provides an idyllic tale of innocence that is both nostalgic and equally timely. She writes of the values and integrity that we all aspire to achieve. Justice, understanding, acceptance, faith, perseverance, all are explored through the plainspoken words of a child. Whatever your opinion of the recently released manuscript, the simplicity and beauty of this original novel makes for a deeply moving experience and a quintessential work of American literature.

Harper Lee's writing is very easy to read. Despite being set in the 1930's America To Kill a Mockingbird feels timeless and universal in its depiction of childhood, small town life and gender and racial discrimination. 
 Adding this to my favorites.

Who knows how many times I've read this book? At least three, maybe more. In my mind it's always mixed together with the film, which I've probably seen more than three times. It's a core story of American life, a brilliantly written portrait of childhood, and the central character, Scout, is one of the absolute best ever. This is a book you can read when you're 12 or 13 and then again at 20, and again, and again. Each time I'm surprised all over again by the rich characterizations of both white and black people, children and adults. 
 If you love this book, be sure to watch the film Capote, with Philip Seymour Hoffman as Truman Capote and Catherine Keener as his best friend, author Harper Lee.

Read: paperback 
 One of my favorite classic novels.

"Sometimes the Bible in the hand of one man is worse than a whisky bottle in the hand of (another)... There are just some kind of men who - who're so busy worrying about the next world they've never learned to live in this one, and you can look down the street and see the results.(Miss Maudie)" 
 -- Harper Lee (To Kill a Mockingbird)

I don't know why I hated this book as much as I did. Maybe it was the fact that the characters were boring cardboard cutouts, or that the setting was just horrible to me. 
 Or maybe it was b/c I had to read this stupid thing for class during my Sophmore year. Trust me that english class was just a stab to my brain. Anyways, I only read about 10 chapters out of this whole book, and yet I still got the jist of the story. That's bad...if I can get what's going on with just 10 chapters...then that means nothing happened within the other chapters. That's my idea. 
 Honestly this book dragged on and on, and I would give it nothing if I could. Sadly this book doesn't exist on my shelf anymore, and was given to my sister, who has to read it soon for school. I pitty her, and hey I love reading, but this book made me hate books for the longest time. 
 Sorry to all those who loved this book. Maybe it's just me, and that my brain just didn't want to cope with this book at all. Or maybe it's the lack of magic, dragons, and battles....I don't know. But I felt that this book lacked a lot of something, and it just didn't give out a complete story to me.
It didn't live up to its hype.
I. Love. This. Book.

This has to be one of my favorite classics so far! I smiled every time Atticus talked; I loved him so much! Jem was the perfect brother to Scout, and Arthur was also pretty lovable, although he's going to die early. In a way, too, it was sad at the end, but not too sad.

Okay, you guys have had to deal with my classic reviews before, right? 
 LORD OF THE FLIES: THE END OF MY HAPPINESS. ARMAGEDDON OF BOOKS!! 
 ANIMAL FARM: I'll never look at farms the same way again. 
 OF MICE AND MEN: This was . . . this was . . . THIS WAS . . . not so bad, actually. (Was it because it was so short??) 
 ALICE IN WONDERLAND: URRRRGH! This is a children's story?? 
 And then there was the worst one of all . . . 
 ROMEO AND JULIET: (Chucked out the window with a passionate scream.) 
 When I've just about had it with classics . . . I meet this. 
 This . . . this . . . this story of ADORABLENESS. 
 It's ADORABLE. AH-DORABLE. Not just because the narrator is a 6 year old girl, but just because everything that has happened in this book is actually INTERESTING and adorable. 
 So yeah. When my (used to be, because she's quitting her job at my school. WHICH IS WEIRD, because she was on maternity leave for first quarter, and then she didn't even stay for the whole second quarter because she's moving and trying to find another job. But she was such an awesome teacher. BUT WHY IS SHE LEAVING SO SOON, SHE DIDN'T EVEN STAY FOR A WHOLE QUARTER, NOOOOOOOOOOO! So now she's getting a new job...and we're getting a new teacher.) English teacher gave this book to us, she said 
 "This is my most favorite book in the whole wide world, so children . . . I'm making you read this." 
 Kind of like how last year, my teacher made us read Watership Down because it was HER favorite book. 
 But I did not dislike this book! I did not dislike this book SO MUCH . . . that I feel really bad that I didn't finish it. 
 I KNOW. Come and yell at me! 
 Come and smack me back and forth and back and forth and left and right ACROSS MY FACE! 
 But no. I didn't finish this book. 
 AND IT WAS HORRIBLE ON MY GRADE. 
 We had this test on the first 10 chapters. When we took that test, I was proudly sitting there with my book marked at Chapter 11. 
 When we had the test on chapter 11-20, I WAS STILL ON CHAPTER 11!! 
 And when we finally took the test on the WHOLE BOOK, I only got to Chapter 17! 
 I just procrastinated. This is a good book, don't get me wrong. I just . . . didn't finish it. 
 Maybe it was because it was homework. Anything that's homework, I'm not going to want to do! 
 If the teacher told me to get out of my house and just walk across the street for homework, I'd probably procrastinate to the last minute. Because there's just this thing in my head that tells me . . . that TEACHERS CAN'T TELL ME WHAT TO DO!! 
 Or maybe it's because I'm just lazy. 
 OR MAYBE it's because it was the week before winter break. I mean, I was procrastinating A LOT. I didn't study for my AP World History test on Chapter 13--on Christians and churches and HISTORY (No offense to religious people--I mean, I'm religious, too. BUT WHY IS HISTORY SO BORING?!?!?!?!). 
 My grades aren't straight A's anymore. IT'S AWFUL!!! 
 So, yeah. Yeah. I didn't finish this book. 
 So I can't properly review this book. I didn't properly read the end. AND THE TEST SPOILED IT FOR ME!!! Are you serious?! 
 (view spoiler)[Question 17: Who killed Tom Robinson? 
 And I was sitting there with my mouth open, saying . . . 
 "TOM ROBINSON GETS KILLED?!?!?!" (hide spoiler)] 
 So yeah. The ending is already ruined for me and you guys know how I hate being spoiled. 
 And . . . I don't know the book well enough to review it! (Or maybe I'm just lazy.) 
 BUT THIS WAS A GOOD CLASSIC. It will keep you interested if you give it a chance. It's a good book for a classic. 
 I mean, ANYTHING is better than Romeo and Juliet, you know. 
 So yeah. Sorry this is a pretty short review. T^T

"Atticus said to Jem one day, "I'd rather you shot at tin cans in the backyard, but I know you'll go after birds. Shoot all the blue jays you want, if you can hit 'em, but remember it's a sin to kill a mockingbird." That was the only time I ever heard Atticus say it was a sin to do something, and I asked Miss Maudie about it. "Your father's right," she said. "Mockingbirds don't do one thing except make music for us to enjoy. They don't eat up people's gardens, don't nest in corn cribs, they don't do one thing but sing their hearts out for us. That's why it's a sin to kill a mockingbird." 
 -- Harper Lee (To Kill a Mockingbird)

I've wanted to read this book since forever but never really got to it. A friend of mine borrowed me her copy during the summer. The book was all I imagined it to be, and it comes with a great lesson.

How can you not love TKAM? I'm pretty sure that's not allowed. 
 This book has the distinction of being the very first book on my Book List. I don't remember every book I read before that one, but I remember the ones since then because I wrote every single one of them down in a red spiral notebook until I started using Goodreads. My Goodreads account creation day was truly the end of an era. 
 1st reading: finished 10/2/2002 
 2nd reading: finished 3/20/2009

One of my favorite all-time books. It's a story about a black man accused of murder and the lawyer, Atticus Finch, who defends him. I read this book many years ago, while in high school, and I would like to definitely read it again soon. The movie is also excellent.
I now understand why this book is considered a classic and why it's constantly making "book everyone should read in there life time" lists. It a favourite of mine now.

I think the first time I read the book as a kid, I had already heard so much about it that I had really high expectations. The problem with my expectations, is that I have a pretty vivid imagination as to how good a book can be. So, I think the book fell a bit short of the hype, however that said I really did truly enjoy it, and shared the feelings of the characters. I always like a book if it makes me feel.

I didn't think I was going to enjoy this book at first, but once I got into it, I really liked it. It was interesting to think about the values expressed, considering the time period it was written in. Some of her observations about race and classes unfortunately still hold true today.

This is so good! I loved every part of it and how endearing these characters are. The way that it discussed prejudice, racial discrimination and just plainly what it means to be a decent human being was something that I feel will really stay with me.

I'm not sure what to say about this book that hasn't been said 61,500 times before. Seriously, that's how many reviews To Kill A Mockingbird has on Goodreads. This is going to be a short review because I literally have nothing to add to the conversation. 
 Even if you've never read To Kill A Mockingbird you probably know what it's about. The story is set in 1930s Alabama and told from the point-of-view of eight-year-old Scout. Scout's father is a defense attorney who causes a controversy after he defends a black man in a rape case. This book shows Scout's struggle to make sense of an unjust world. 
 I read this book for the first time when I was thirteen. Thirteen-year-old me was an avid reader of classics, but I mostly stuck to the sci-fi/fantasy/horror classics. I couldn't get into the realistic ones. This book helped me realize that realistic classics didn't have to be about stuffy British people who attend a lot of dinner parties. Many of the characters in this book are children, and the author perfectly captures the humor, mysteries, and confusion of growing up in a small town. Even though thirteen-year-old me had never been to Alabama, I remember the vivid rural setting of the novel pulling me in. It was a setting that I could (and still can) relate to. 
 When I first read this book, I was young enough that it had an impact on how I saw the world. To Kill A Mockingbird is about looking past a person's outward appearance and reputation. It's about trying your hardest to be fair to others. It taught me that I have to stand up for what I believe, even if it's hard or unpopular, but I still need to respect people who believe differently than me. It has always impressed me that a book could teach me so much without being preachy. 
 "I wanted you to see what real courage is, instead of getting the idea that courage is a man with a gun in his hand. It's when you know you're licked before you begin, but you begin anyway and see it through no matter what." 
 "People generally see what they look for, and hear what they listen for." 
 "They're certainly entitled to think that, and they're entitled to full respect for their opinions . . . but before I can live with other folks I've got to live with myself. The one thing that doesn't abide by majority rule is a person's conscience." 
 I'm glad I got a chance to reread this book.
Review soon! Such a great book.

This is one of my favorite books. I read it in high school for english class and liked it so much, I decided I wanted to keep my copy and 'forgot' to turn it back in. Ive read a couple more times over the years. Still love it.

I first time I read this was for assigned summer reading for my AP English class in the 9th grade. I sort of always disliked books I was forced to read as a teen, and To Kill a Mockingbird really suffered. I got so much more out of the re-reading of this one. Maybe more so than any other re-reading I have done. 
 Note - I am trying to read this list in 2012. :) 
 http://www.flickr.com/photos/fireleaf...

Awesome book. Excellent. Something that when you close, finished, and let it down, you sigh with wonder. It's that kind of a book. I loved it. I still love it. It's a must read. 
 In the perspective of Scout, you get to experience the full courage it actually took to support blacks when they were looked down upon. This book is classic and I will forever respect Harper Lee for writing it. 
 Just read it. People who haven't read it yet are missing really good stuff. Do not hesitate. Take it up.

Wow. Who knew it was going to be all about Atticus? 
 I grew up with the Robert Mulligan movie and always perceived it as a somewhat autobiography of Harper Lee and definitely related more to the subject of being fancy free as a child and learning from the world around rather than completely absorbing the stark, important message of prejudice and justice that collides with the issue of racism in the story. But this is really about the importance of Atticus, because he is the driving force of Scout's subjectiveness and the axis of her moral values; the last few words of the book are of Scout reflecting the love her father has for her and her brother described through an action: Sitting at Jem's bedside all night till he wakes. 
 I've been a fan of the movie for years--and there's not denying Gregory Peck's fantastic performance--but there's no doubt that the book is far better. The only reasons I have for saying so is that the movie is pretty much just a cinematic version of the book give or take several scenes and declarations of Scout and her point of view. But, like most on-screen versions of popular novels, the 1962 film gives perfect faces to the characters. Can you imagine if Cary Grant or Peter O'Toole played the role of Atticus? They would live up to their reputations as actors, but would lack character traits and behaviors (O'Toole would be too soft in appearance and voice, and Grant would lack the natural tranquility of Atticus' character). The roles of the children are spot on in the movie as well--especially Mary Badham as Scout. I suppose performance is all that matters in the film anyway because the original story is primarily lead with character development and realization as opposed to plot. 
 For me, and many others, Atticus is really what made this book. I was more interested in Atticus than Scout and Jem and wished that there was a whole book dedicated to Atticus from his point of view as a prequel telling how he met Jem and Scout's mom, his years in law school, and that involve flashbacks of his childhood with his family (there must be a fan fiction out there somewhere...) God, I can't even describe how much I personally admire Atticus. It's an ongoing, but true, joke in my family that Atticus Finch is the Optimus Prime of American Lit. Both characters are on par with each other on all characteristic levels: Both are respected and loved by those they raise/lead, both hold firm to their moral values--including justice--even if it may cost them their lives, both have a tender authority that attracts others around, you want both to be your father, I could go on. Yep, Atticus Finch hits my top favorite characters in Lit. next to Siever Genarr (Asimov's Nemesis) and Nick Carraway (Fitzgerald's The Great Gatsby). 
 This was such a great book, and my excuse for knocking off a star is probably the most cliche but true factoid among ALL readers: It just didn't hit me hard enough to stay completely interested. Every time I put it down I was more like "...eh" instead of needing to stay up all night till I reach the last page. Lame, I know, but my opinion deserves a star too despite this novel's excellence. Great read, highly recommend it for anyone who wants a good, warm read about facing the world's issues through the eyes of a child.

The book is simply genius. 
 The book takes a child's point of view and does so brilliantly. Like any good story, it explores its theme with out explicitly lecturing about it. That is probably why not all of us are able to understand it. 
 The title itself is fine example. There are no mocking bird - dead or alive, in the story but the title is metaphor for acts that destroy a child's innocence and trough the story, you find characters whose innocence gets destroyed. 
 The story explores how children go through various stages with regard to their views on morality. Also, it is pointed out, beautifully, that you can't understand a person unless you see life in his/her way.Another important theme is gender differences. That is even if you leave behind other more common theme like racism and pride. 
 Initially, i thought it is famous only because it is all literature. Also it was based american urban life and as such, I won't like it but, the book is like a poem of humanity and equally enjoyable to all. 
 .... and what is above all it explores those themes with a good humor.

Lee hits you over the head with her moral messages, but you forgive her because they're messages that need to be repeated. Atticus remains one of my most favorite characters. You wonder how different the world would be if there were more fathers like him. Definitely my favorite book to teach to freshmen; they still connect with it and gasp with outrage in all the right places.

As many of us do, I have deep connections to this book that is so much more than a book. I read it for the first time in college (1990), deciding to pick it up on my own because I was the only person I knew that didn't read it in high school. Of course, I loved it, but that's about as far as it went. When I began teaching sophomore English, probably around 1994, I read the entire book aloud to each of my classes. With each reading, each day, each year, my love for the book grew as did my talent for reading it aloud (I'm pretty BA with my voices, if I do say so myself). Eventually, I began co-teaching English II with my best friend, my sister, who also loves TKAM. We taught the shit out of this book. We LOVED teaching this book together, reading it aloud together. And because we loved it with such an obvious and visible passion, our students loved it, too (I still have former students come up to me and share their Mockingbird memories). TKAM made such an impression on my sister, she named my nephew William Atticus, after one of its most beloved characters (Go Set a Watchman doesn't count!!!).
