 Flash forward years later. I've been a librarian for 9 years, so it's been that long since I've had the opportunity to return to Maycomb. It's February 19, 2016. My sister and I are in the hallway outside the hospital room where our mom is dying. We are devastated and lost. We're skimming our phones when we see Harper Lee has died. We are moved and know Mom won't be far behind. She wasn't. 
 Flash forward two months. It's April and my son is failing English (I know, right???). His class is finishing the year with Mockingbird. Students are expected to read the book 100% on their own. I know my son. I know he will not read this book. I refuse to let that happen. Yes, part of the reason is that I don't want him to fail, but a bigger reason is because this book is so important to my sister and me and his sister, too. And because I know I can make him love it, I convince him to let us read the book together (and by together I mean let me read it aloud to him). He agrees. And that experience is now one of my all-time favorite parenting memories. I savored every night I got to read this book aloud again. All my voices came right back to me, my cadence, the questions I would stop and ask, all of it. Jake was an attentive audience, he laughed and was outraged in all the right places. He made excellent predictions. He answered all the questions correctly. He made wise connections and observations. He made intelligent jokes. My favorite was when he texted me to say that he read in class that day, not waiting for me to read to him that night, and he already knew that Tom came back to life and Boo Radley was a Ninja. How excited he was when we got to the end and it turned out that Boo really was a Ninja - well, kinda. 
 I always cried in certain parts of the book while reading aloud to my classes ("Miss Jean Louise, stand up. Your father's passin'," and, "Hey, Boo," just to name two), but reading aloud to my son just two months after my mom's death was an exponentially more emotional experience. Aside from my near hysterics reading the last few chapters (poor Jake), the chapter that made me cry the most (that didn't even used to choke me up) was Chapter 11 - the chapter on courage, the chapter about Mrs. Dubose. As I read the last page when Atticus is telling Jem about Mrs. Dubose's death and how she was the bravest woman he ever knew, I was overcome. Jake let me cry for several minutes, then he cleared his throat and read the rest of the chapter aloud to me. 
 What a blessing to me that Jake's teacher chose not to read Mockingbird aloud to her classes (thank you, Jenni George for pointing that out to me). If she would have, I would have missed out on sharing it with Jake. I would have missed out on revisiting Maycomb and the story and the characters and the memories that mean so, so much to me.

Wow. I haven't read this book since 1999. What a powerful and engaging and totally engrossing reread. I think I need to read this book every few years. 
 Things that struck me about it this time through: 
 - the dialogue. Just damn! She nailed it. I was sucked into the story within 10 pages because of her natural and believable dialogue, which also helped make the world of Maycomb that much more real. 
 - Maycomb as a character. At a writing conference last year, one of the speakers said, "If you can pick up your story and characters and move them to another city or place and still be able to tell the same story, then your setting isn't working hard enough." Well TKAM wouldn't work in ANY other setting, and Maycomb played as much a vital role to the outcome of the story as any one person did. 
 - The story takes on this creepy vibe at certain parts, so there's this underlying sense of terror without it ever being a horror novel. She's able to create this unsettling tone in many places, and the horror becomes a real sense of horror - like how could those people do that to that man? or how could anyone want to hurt children? - yet the book never loses its sense of childhood innocence during those moments. 
 - having an adult narrator tell a story from her childhood's point of view is tricky and well done. how she managed to find a balance between the sensitivities and understanding of the adult and the innocence and naivite and curiosity of the child was kind of mind blowing at times.
Read for school. It's a classic for a reason.

I basically started this book so I would have a background before I read the newly released sequel. This is one of those books which are socially relevant and so don't get relegated back to the dusty shelves where they belong. It's considered to be an indictment against racism in American society, but I did not find it all that powerful. 
 For one thing, we look at the entire issue of racism from a white point of view, which basically just skims over the daily humiliations and trials of being a black person in the segregated and racist society of the American South. The Finch family is the primary focus of the book, especially the two children (Scout and Jem), who have no knowledge of these issues, right till the end of the book. The legal case only takes up a small part of the book and while it makes a point about inherent racism in the courts, it really does not dig deep into the issue. 
 The story-telling is rather lacking with paper-thin characters and no actual focus. The book is divided into two parts and the first part is almost entirely Scout and Jem and their daily lives, which I found pretty pointless. They go on endlessly about their silly games and there is far too much attention given to some mysterious neighbour who doesn't really serve a purpose except to act as a deus-ex machina at the end. The second part is better structured but even here, it is still about the Finch family. 
 Child narrators almost always have a major problem with lack of understanding of the world around them, which does not work for me at all as a narrative. Looking at the story through the lens of an innocent white girl serves no purpose. She has no clue about the harshness of the lives of black people because she is sheltered, ignorant and innocent. If a child's viewpoint was even required, which I would definitely argue against, why not a black child who would have the right experience. Maybe even Tom Robinson's daughter? 
 There is not much done in terms of character development, except for Scout herself, and perhaps her brother. But these two should not be the focus of this story because they are really peripheral characters looking at the action taking place around them. Atticus Finch borders on a Gary Stu character. On a more personal level, I could not connect to the characters or to the story except in a few rare instances. 
 I did like a few scenes, especially the courtroom ones. I found Mayela Ewell the most interesting character in the book and would have enjoyed a bit more focus on her and how she felt about her life and her lies. Scout's development of a relationship with her aunt got me interested in spite of myself. But overall, I don't think this book even does its job properly. I found it hugely problematic that for an acclaimed novel against racism, the black characters aren't developed much or even exist for the most part in the narrative.

"Shoot all the blue jays you want, if you can hit 'em, but remember it's a sin to kill a mockingbird." 
 After a lot of procrastination, I finally picked up the book. Scout quickly became my favorite character. I found her witty and quite intriguing. I just loved her sense of humor. The way she tries to make excuses to avoid school had me laughing hard. 
 "Do you defend niggers, Atticus?" I asked him that evening. 
 "Of course I do. Don't say nigger, Scout. That's common." 
 "'s what everybody at school says." 
 "From now on it'll be everybody less one--" 
 "Well if you don't want me to grow up talkin' that way, why do you send me to school?" 
 Liked the way Harper Lee has written it. It was a smooth flow of words and the book doesn't bore you. 
 Atticus is shown as genuine person and not portrayed like a superhero. I was hooked to the book during the second half of the story i.e. when Tom Robinson trial began. 
 It has a powerful message and portrayed beautifully. 
 "Stand up for what you think is right, even if the whole world stands against you."
This was a very entertaining. This is outside my normal genre so I was particularly delighted by how much I enjoyed it.

Words can't portray the feeling I had, when I finished the book. I had to watch myself not to cry, because it was such an emotional turmoil towards the end. Very great book and I can recommend this to almost anyone. I couldn't imagine, who would not enjoy this book.

this was such a great read, i got bought this novel for my 13th birthday and when i read it i was quite engrossed. The title is very symbolic of the black man and how he is accused of raping a white woman. there is an underlying love and struggle in the family life that shows lots of affection. a really good read i should read again sometime!

One of those books everyone was supposed to read...evidently I was not ready to read it in high school, I watched the movie. 
 But as with so many other books, the book is far better than the movie, offering depth and insight. 
 The kids offer a rare, unvarnished opinion of life and growing up in that time. Boo and the court made me emotional at points. 
 Once I started reading, I couldn't put it down. Read with some historical perspective (it's not today after all), but do read. It's classic for a reason.

If a book is written from a child's point of view, I tend to skip it. That was the reason why I was putting this off, even though I was interested in the topic and liked the fact that it was set in the South in the 1930s. I also wanted to see why this is considered as one of the greatest American novels of all time. Well, I did see where people were coming from and why this is such a loved story, especially in the United States. It had this charming and nostalgic atmosphere, which made me want to go back in time when I was a carefree child. Had I read this during the summer, I would have had a glass of lemonade in my hand while sitting on the garden swing in a warm breeze of wind. 
 Lee knows how to evoke the sweet childhood alongside the serious undertone of the trial and racial issues. It soon becomes clear that the prejudice and mean-spiritedness towards certain groups of people is incomprehensible to children, which I personally think shows that it is completely unnecessary and ridiculous. In the story one of the teachers abhors Hitler's actions, but at the same time says that it was about time someone taught the Negroes a lesson because they didn't stay in their proper place anymore. What a load of crappy hypocrisy, Ms. Whatever-her-name-was. I would also say (based on the book and my own experiences) that racism is a completely learned behaviour. Children repeat what they hear at home, they don't even necessarily know the meaning of the words they're spitting out, let alone why it is wrong to say such things. 
 However, had I read this earlier in life it would have probably worked a lot better for me. I'd say that this would serve its purpose in schools' compulsory reading lists. Adolescents at a certain stage in their lives would take out a lot from this. I understand why people love this so much, but at the same time I can't consider it as nothing more than one of many canonical classics. Steinbeck's Grapes of Wrath for example is in my opinion many ways far superior, whereas Lee falls short in both her writing and characterizations (mostly with the children).

To Kill a Mocking Bird is one of those books. The kind that isn't full of drama, action, and dangerous situations, but you still can't put it down. And when you find a book like that, you know it is a good one! 
 I LOVED this book! Such a beautiful, simplistic story of 2 little children, only it is so much more! The characters were simply amazing! I love Scout (aka Jean Louise Finch). She is just the sweetest little spitfire ever! I love her attitude, her thirst for knowledge, and her love of reading. And every time she crawled up in Atticus's lap, my heart melted completely! <3 <3 <3 And Jem. The typical big brother. I love his imagination, his protectiveness towards Scout, and his tender heart. There were times I just wanted to wrap him in my arms and give him a hug! He reminds me so much of my own brothers, which is perhaps why I like him so much. Let's not forget Atticus. The Best. Character. Ever. I love how he was such an amazing man, yet the author still portrayed his flaws, making him realistic and relatable. I am having a hard time describing him, because he is just so darn awesome! And Boo Radley . . . yeah. We'll just leave it at that! <3 
 The writing style was quite unique in this book, and I have to say, as much as I liked pretty much everything else about this book, I wasn't really a fan of the writing style. It was somewhat confusing, and I found myself rereading sentences 2 or 3 times just to comprehend what she was trying to say. Otherwise, I loved this book! Definitely something I will read again and again! 
 CONTENT NOTE: (view spoiler)[There was a decent amount of language in this book. Nothing absolutely terrible, but definitely a bit more than mild, and more than I am comfortable with on a regular basis. I wouldn't recommend this book to anyone younger than 15 for that reason, and because one of the main themes involves a trial about rape. (hide spoiler)]

I loved this book! 
 Thought I'd give it a try since everyone seems to have read it but me, and I'm glad I did. Well-drawn characters who really had their own dimensions and personalities, and the town seems to have a personality of its own. So many quotable lines in the story; so much to learn, though not told in a preachy way. 
 My 16-yr-old son just read it for school and did not enjoy it, and I'm not sure I would have either when I was in high school, as it's told from a child's perspective, which is overwhelmingly evident at times, and written in a time and about a time that is probably unrelatable to the average teenager, for the most part. But as an adult, what a great story of a bygone time. 
 My intention is to watch the movie next. Hope it's just as good, though I've heard it is.

I had never read this book before, but am trying to make my way through "the classics" over time. This was such a powerful story conveying life in depression era Alabama, told through the eyes of a child, Jean Louise Finch (aka Scout). There's little I can write about this book that hasn't already been written in countless reviews and book reports over time. What is worth commenting on is the reading by Sissy Spacek, as I listened to this on audio. Of all the audio books I've listened to, this reading was the most engaging and seemingly perfect for the story and characters. Spacek's southern drawl came across with the humility and innocence of the story's voice, Scout. She did a fantastic job, and really brought the book to life for me.

I understand why this why this book was important. Reading it fifty years after publication though, and not being from the Southern US, or from anywhere in the USA, it's devoid of it's cultural context. When you lose that context, it's a simple story about how we should treat others as we would wish them to treat us. 
 That story has been written many, many times. Sometimes much better than this.
Loved this book! And Sissy Spacek did a phenomenal job narrating the audiobook.

I haven't read this since high school so it was time to pick it up again. 
 So. Very. Good. 
 It isn't often that you read a book where every sentence matters.

"You never really understand a person until you consider things from his point of view ... until you climb into his skin and walk around in it." 
 This was amazing... 
 I really don't know what I am supposed to write here about this unbelievably good, and well-written and important book, so I really don't think there is much point in me trying (Because words are hard and I tend to mess up when I get excited). But you shall not worry, I will try and you can laugh, if you want, when I fail. 
 I'm just going to start, by telling you to go and pick up this book if you haven't already done so. Drop everything, go pick up the book, read it, and then you can thank me. 
 "I think there is just one kind of folks. Folks." 
 This book has over 3 million ratings on Goodreads, over 70 000 reviews and a crap-ton of reviews elsewhere as well, so I know I am not first one to rave about how good this book was, nor will I be the last. 
 This book has great characters and a great plot. The fact that all the events taking place in this book, is told through the eyes of a child, made this book ten times more gripping and captivating. I think it made everything feel a little bit more real. 
 This book deals with racism, equality and inequality, and most importantly it portrays courage. 
 There is a lot to learn from this book, and that is partially why I would strongly advise you to read it. 
 I loved this book and it is now one of my favourite books of all time and I want to read it again already. However, I think this book is one of those you either love, or don't like at all. I can see where this book may not appeal to every reader out there, but I would still advise everybody to pick this up. 
 "It is never an insult to be called what somebody thinks is a bad name. It just shows you how poor that person is, it doesn't hurt you." 
 This book deserves all the stars and I can't stop raving about it, 'cause it was just that good. If you haven't picked up this book yet, please do, it is worth it, trust me. 100/10 would definitely, always recommend this book to anybody who asks. I think I'm finished now. 
 (You may now laugh if you want to)
Aside from a couple lulls, this book was perfect.

I loved it. Loved. Scout is one of the most genuine and honest characters I have ever read. And Atticus is an exemplary parent, the likes of which are rare. He, and by extension, Scout, defy convention in the most veritable way. An incredibly raw insight into the prejudices and mores of Jim Crow South.

book: To kill a mockingbird 
 written by: Harper Lee 
 genres: Adult, literature, classics 
 own / library / borrowed 
 pages: 309 
 rating: 5 stars! 
 the book: 
 US, Alabama, 1935. Scout and Jem are the two children of Atticus Finch, a lawyer. Atticus has to defend a black man, who is suspected of the rape of a white girl. He cannot deny the case, because that'd mean no job, which means no money. And that's why he has to defend the man, even tough he knows the case is already lost because of the difference between black and white people. Lots of terrible things will happen, because Atticus defends a black man. But when the thruth is revealed, will people set the man free, or won't they, because he's black? 
 review: 
 I have no idea how to review a book this good. To me this is an important piece of american history. The story is told from Scout, a nine-year-old girl, point of view, which makes is less difficult to read, which was great for me. I like to know what I'm reading :) I think that this story wouldn't have been as good as it is if it was told from e.g. Atticus's point of view, Scout really made the story funny with her childlike innocence. The author made me want to read literature, something I'd think I would not like. 
 This story is out of my comfort zone, but still I loved it, and I know I will read more literature. I hope all literature is as good as this book. Then English classes will be fun in the next 3 years :D (I'm in year 9 now) 
 The characters were very developed and thought-through, which made the book easier to read. You did not have to care about some very bad characters, and I fell in love with all of them. I kind of felt like I knew every family that lived in this village, and that I knew all about them. 
 I could relate to Scout in many ways. I was like she is, always being boy-ish. My parents also are like Atticus, teaching me to read before school started. 
 *I think I can go on rambling about this book forever* 
 Altogether, I think many newer stories were based on this one, and this book has been a source of inspiration for tons of books, writers and readers. Definitely worth the Pulitzer Prize it recieved!

(2015) 5 Stars 
 August was a horrible month for reading as it was busy with work, family and trying to get some writing in. If you can believe it - I read and listened to only twelve books and many were shorter novels. Despite not having too much time to read I did finish To Kill a Mockingbird before September and enjoyed every moment of it. 
 As I listened to Sissy Spacek narration of Harper Lee's novel I found myself almost reading this as if it was my first time. When I first read this novel as a preteen I understood the basic principle of the racial issues and of right and wrong and it frustrated me. I wanted good to prevail and have everyone have a group hug and ride off in the sunset. On my second reading, in my mid-twenties, I was more aware of the elements behind the issues and it angered me. I wanted blood from the bad, shame the bystanders, stand on my soapbox demanding idealism and justice. This time (turning 35 later this month) when I listened to the words written by the incomparable Lee I took in the pain, injustice and reality and I cried. I cried with Scout. I felt what she did but instead of applying myself into the novel I walked in the characters' s shoes. I am fortunate to have had this novel by my side as I grew into a more compassionate person. I still want to change...and rage against...the world but I want the peace that many of the heroes strived for. 
 Lee's editor was brilliant in zeroing in on Jean Louise's childhood and having her focus her novel around young Scout. Through this character Lee is able to give us the good and bad of Maycomb, circa the Great Depression. We see the innocence of morality, the awakening of consciencness and the ultimate compassion. This is not just a novel of a small town in Alabama that houses racists, bullies, small minds or lowbrow people that strikes it's readers for change. It is a novel that Lee wrote from her own experiences and childhood memeories but also a novel that asks you to look at the world from more than one point of view. 
 The fact that this novel is a banned book only makes me more proud to call this piece of literature one of my favourites of all time. Any book can allow me to be carried away to another place and time but it takes something special to take me to another place and time but give me a different perspective each time. I would recommend this novel to everyone - you may love it or hate it but you will feel something. 
 I apologize that this isn't quite a review as much as a reflection. I think for me this is one book that I can't be as objective as I wanted to be. This proves interesting as I will be reading Go Set a Watchman this month. Other than being excited to read more of Harper Lee's writing I am not sure how I feel going into the book. 
 k (My Novelesque Life) 
 http://mynovelesquelife.blogspot.ca/2... 
 (2004) 5 STARS 
 This novel takes place in the South in the 1960s. Told from a young girl's point-of-view we get the story of how a black man is accused of raping a white woman. Scout, the young girl, watches her father take this case and teach them that life is not fair but if you believe in something you do all you can. Scout and her older brother, Jem are teased by other children and looked down by the adults. 
 What a GREAT read - haunting, heartwarming, outrageous, heroic, etc. This is more than a coming to age story but a story of life lessons and what is right.

I last read this when I sat my GCSEs and I don't care to remember just how long ago that was. I remember taking the book home with homework to read the first chapter. I finished it. I remember loving the book then, but I had forgotten how the plot ended. 
 The book is written in third person from the perspective of Jean Louise Finch (who is called Scout). Her father is a well respected member of the state legislature, and is the defence attorney assigned the defence of Tom Robinson, a black man in 1930s Alabama, accused of the rape of a white 19 year old, Mayella Ewell. 
 Although the court case is almost a sub-plot in the novel, it is a vehicle to explore the Finch family's attitude to the world they live in as we follow Scout, who is 9 by the end of the novel, as she tries to figure out her place in Maycombe society. It's a fascinating snapshot of life and society attitudes in 1930s Alabama. 
 This novel is an interesting book. It works on many levels as a novel which makes you think, it's an enjoyable plot and has creatively drawn characters and has a number of sub-plots. 
 I'm really glad that I read it again, and I am now looking forward to reading Go Set a Watchman.

To Kill a Mockingbird is storytelling at its absolute best. I can't think of a more perfect book. Honest and poignant, yet warm and hopeful all at once. There's so much I want to say about this book, but I think Scout said it all, or rather, showed us. This is a book that will stay with you for a lifetime.

Best questions asked are from kids, the innocence they have as they see the world is so refreshing and at the same time a little too heartbreaking. Questions most adults don't ask themselves, things adults forgot to ask about how they run their life and reflect on it. I get annoyed at Scout in some moments but that is how kids are sometimes, same goes with Dilly and Jem. Thing is, Scout's POV is so refreshing I didn't mind the most parts where she was annoying. I love how the story progressed along the way, I love how her relationship to her father and to her brother was told, alongside her extended family, neighbors, and Calpurnia and the rest of the black society. 
 Prejudice is one of man's greatest flaw, to think that he is above everyone else. And this book has showed me how an act of prejudicism affected children, and how those children reacted to such action. This has been a very emotional read for me, and this will be one of my favorites that I will surely love to visit again and again. Deeply moving.

Absolutely the only assigned reading in middleschool/highschool that I enjoyed. Almost everyone I talk to says the same thing. I think this is partially because the novel can become truly dark, and it may be one of the first times that kids are really confronted by this unfortunate part of our nation's past. On top of that, it still resonates today. The prose is uncomplicated but still precise, the message is resounding, and the coming-of-age and moral dilemma are presented in a way that elevates a young adult's mind instead of stooping to it. A must read for all YA.

I never reread books - well here is the exception. THIS book was well worth a second reading. This is a book that CAN be read twice and I guess even more times. I loved the book when I read it a little short of 50 years ago, and I loved it this time too. For different reasons. Last time I read it when I was about 11 or 12, when everybody was reading it. This time it was refreshing to attack it from a completely different angle, without hearing all the fuss from others. There is a new book about TKAM and the the author, Harper Lee. It shows that much of this novel is autobiographical. That Dill could be based on Capote! I will have to read this book: !Scout, Atticus, and Boo: A Celebration of Fifty Years of To Kill a Mockingbird. I need to know more about Harper Lee!!! 
 Last time I read TKAM there was so much talk about racial issues, and I read it then, even as a child, with this as the main focus. It IS an excellent glimpse of the South in the mid-thirties. It so well depicts how life unfurled itself then and there. 
 This time around what struck me was the love between the different characters. Love in all its different aspects and ways. Love between a father and his children, love between brother and sister, love between a young "tomboy", Scout, and and her friend Dill. And there is more. Their is love and understanding between the people living in the small town of Alabama. Maybe one can not classify it as romantic love, but all of these "loves" are so beautiful to see and watch. Such love is down-to-earth and real and honest and without any pretense. The author says on the back of my splotched and ripped and yellowed copy that she saw this as a love story. I read this note at the end and understood it immediately. This time around, this is exactly what I got out of the book. 
 I adored the prose. the sentences that erupted from the characters' mouths, the dialogue, the ideas expressed. I personally fell in love with Atticus, the father of Scout. What a father. He had alot to teach me to, still even in my old age..... He and his children were continually reminding each other that "it is not yet time to worry." I love that statement b/c it does not deny that horrible things are going on but we are not yet at the point where we must fall apart and collapse. In all its honesty it calms you down. You can tell yourself to just cool it! This will be my new motto!!! And I love Scout and Jem and Dill........ and Boo! 
 Another thing - the title and how the story plays out are so very important. I will not talk about these things here b/c that would be a spoiler. You have to read the book first. Or you have to read it again, as I had to. After you have read the book, several of us at the Group Comfort Reads have discussed the book and what it meant to us. Here is a link to that thread: http://www.goodreads.com/topic/show/3... . Many of the things I want to talk about here are voiced there. I wrote a couple of rather lengthy bits. See meassages 82, 86 and 89 if you are curious. 
 REALLY DO READ THIS BOOK AGAIN, and for heavens sake if you have never read it, get it NOW! 
 P.S. It is so strange that I totally love this book - it is pure fiction. Or maybe I love it because I can feel that what the author says is based on true events. Probably I feel this b/c it is partially autobiographical.

If I write a great review here, I will be years late. Still, there is no way I can not write something here. 
 I heard about this book from many people, I had always wanted to read it, but I put it off. I'm glad I bought the book when I saw it through the glass in a book store a couple of days back. I wish I had done it earlier. 
 It's a beautiful story, written beautifully. It isn't for the reader who only looks for pace and twists in a book. It's for those who read a book and take away lessons from it. It's for those who would like to be carried away by two children to a place and time everyone wishes never existed. It's for those who look for hope in this world where it seems bleak. 
 It's for those who want to have a book they can always run back to so they can learn how to be right. These characters have a lot to teach each of us. I hope we do learn from them.

No wonder why this is such an acclaimed and awarded book. 
 It narrates the life of two kids in a time where racial discrimination was a serious thing, it specifically looks at the circumstances black people had when faced with the law even when they got the best lawyer in the county. 
 You see the whole story in the eyes of innocence, which means that society is the main reason of discrimination, we are not born racist. 
 It kind of reminded me of "The Help" scenario, it is nice to be able to see a different point of view of those years of turmoil.

"Shoot all the blue jays you want, if you can hit 'em, but remember it's a sin to kill a mockingbird." 
 Actual Rating: 3.5 stars 
 Going into this book, my expectations were probably too high because of how well-known and acknowledged it is. Or maybe it's because I don't usually read books similar to this. Nevertheless, I didn't enjoy this book as much as I would've liked to. 
 To Kill a Mockingbird by Harper Lee is a classic in American literature. It's about life in the South through the eyes of two children, Scout and Jem Finch, and the hardships they face when their father, Atticus, defends a black man accused of rape. 
 The Good: 
 To Kill a Mockingbird accurately depicts childhood and growing up. It reminded me of all the stupid things I would do as a kid and how much I missed having a carefree life (now mine is occupied with homework, projects, and studying). I loved seeing Scout and Jem mature and question and learn about the world around them even though it wasn't pleasant. I also loved seeing the emotions they go through: 
 "'That's what I thought, too,' he said at last, 'when I was your age. If there's just one kind of folks, why can't they get along with each other? If they're alike, why do they go out of their way to despise each other?'" 
 The most interesting character in this novel is Atticus. People like him are rare. He has a heart made of gold, and Scout and Jem are proud to look up to him. I learned a lot from him, and the things he said made me think about the person I am. He has good morals and teaches them to his children: 
 "You never really understand a person until you consider things from his point of view . . . Until you climb inside of his skin and walk around in it." 
 "I wanted you to see what real courage is, instead of getting the idea that courage is a man with a gun in his hand. It's when you know you're licked before you begin, but you begin anyway and see it through no matter what." 
 The ending was also amazing. I won't say much about it, but the ending saved the book for me. 
 The Bad: 
 This book took me much longer to read than most other books. It just didn't fully captivate my attention. Sometimes, I almost had to force myself to keep on reading. I would often zone out during the long descriptions and reread them to help me focus on the story. 
 Another thing I didn't like was how the main plot came much later in the story. The beginning of the book focused on various childhood events that only briefly mention the court case. The purpose of this was to develop the world and characters, but it was done too slowly. 
 Overall, I still enjoyed this book despite how boring it could get at times. I recommend it to anyone who enjoys a humorous, character-driven historical fiction novel.

4/5 stars 
 Review to come on www.kailynkausen.com

Centers around the life of Scout and the events surrounding a hefty portion of her childhood. Scenes of school, home life, and play are seen often. Her father is a lawyer who is given the task of defending an African-American in an accused rape trial. Though only a small portion of the book, these few chapters hold a lot of discussion possibilities about race, prejudice, and ethics. Strong character development throughout---many impressions of characters change over the course of the book as the readers learns more information about them. Artfully written and demands rereading. Much is implied or downplayed in its seriousness---the reader must look further at a passage than as one would with a hasty read.
One of the best novel I have read so far in school. Hard to read a lot at once.

My first classic, and I absolutely loved it. The writing and the story feels so natural and unforced. I can't remember when last I liked characters this much - I cried and laughed with them. I though Atticus the most honorable person in any book I've ever read. I especially liked his viewpoint that all individuals are good, but sometimes society can make them do bad things. I strongly recommend that you read this, it's perfect

After reading this timeless novel, I felt the urge to watch the movie adaptation which was more than outstanding. As for the book? Extraordinaire. The innocent and humorous narrative tone of the novel dealt with some serious social problems of the evil human nature and gave not only valuable life lessons but lessons in parenthood, as well. I can understand why Atticus Finch has become one of the most beloved characters in American literature.
I really enjoyed it. A young girl battling with the ideas of racism and sexism... still relevant today.

Maybe I didn't fall madly in love with this classic, but I did enjoy reading it during one of my high school English classes. Even after we had completed the unit on the book, we continued talking about it every now and then. It really had a profound impact on my classroom. I feel everyone should read To Kill A Mockingbird at least once in their life.

*spoiler? maybe?* 
 I cried when the bitchy old drug addict died. 
 Although I got really irritated when on one side of the fence it preached about loving people of every color, then on the other side of the fence it was like, women are so silly and pointless and of course they can't be on juries because they'd only ask a bunch of questions and nothing would get done, tee hee! It seemed like if anyone wanted to criticize the book for that, it could easily be said, well it was from a main character who was a little girl so she didn't know any better. (She was old enough to get generally that racism is a bad deal but hey, that's different, right?) 
 3.5 stars

This was my third reading of this book (I read it once in high school when assigned, and once in college when my youngest brother was assigned to read it) and my first time to read it as a "real" adult with children. It was even better than I remembered, and deserves all of the praise it gets.
This book is better than you think.

Normally, I can't bear classics. This is one of the few that I actually enjoy! 
 Amazing story of innocence and, in some ways bullying, and the economy. I am disappointed that Harper Lee got writers block after her first book. 
 I think she could have had a long and successful career. This is one of the most influential books ever written, and everybpdy should read it at least once in their life.

This is one more book which I read during a summer break. I actually had not read any classics by my own volition until I grabbed this one, so I will always cherish To Kill a Mockingbird as my first. At first, I didn't even know what the book was about, really. I just remember choosing this one because I had heard its title a bunch of times, plus it had a really beautiful cover (yes, I am one of those guys...). I remember thinking that it was bound to be, at least, average, otherwise it wouldn't have acquired such fame. And it was much more than that. To this day, few books have had the same general impact on me as a human being as this one. The powerful lessons expressed through every character, especially Atticus Finch, are unique and everlasting. 
 I could say that this book is nothing more than a coming of age story about day-to-day life in a small Alabama town during the Great Depression, but it is. To Kill a Mockingbird, in its simplicity, emanates waves of warmth through totally believable and relatable characters. Enduring characters like the Finches, Calpurnia and Boo Radley are rare, but when they come up they tend to stay with the readers for generations. Atticus Finch, by being such a beacon of righteousness to the kids, has done the same for me as well. The most admirable thing about him is his ability to influence the kids, constantly leading them to the right direction regarding moral and general behavior, while letting them interact with society and find out the workings of the world on their own. Also, the way Atticus talks to the kids is something that everyone should learn: to interact with children as if they are adults; by doing so, Atticus makes sure the children know their opinions are being taken seriously and that they are respected. I wish every parent was like that! God knows how disgusted I get whenever I see parents interacting with their kids as if they are some kind of injured puppy or something... Well, to wrap this all up, I wish I could have read To Kill a Mockingbird sooner so that I would have been inspired by its awesomeness from a younger age. 
 Regarding the narrative, I found it light and easy flowing; there is no excess of detail descriptions, no sudden unexplained events or anything poorly executed. Everything makes sense and fits the rhythm of the story perfectly. Still, it was only a third or so into the book that I began to understand why it is what it is. When I got there, the first part felt really less significant than I had thought. In fact, it only served to introduce all the characters - their relationships, personalities, motivations and moral standpoints. After that, though, the core of the story is slowly built until it comes to the famous courtroom scene - and I found it to be as remarkable as everyone had said it would. The events that come right after are equally shocking. Even though our society, unfortunately, still is not near being prejudice free, the lengths to which people of that time would go to ascertain that their prejudicial views were being hold by legal authorities left me astounded. 
 To Kill a Mockingbird was truly beyond its time and I find its messages very much relevant. That is what characterizes quality literature: the property of transcending time and having the same impact on several generations as it had on the first reader. All things considered, this is an incredible book that reminded me, once more, of how important it is to at least try to treat everyone with equal respect. Also, this book is extremely powerful in its discussion of racism, tolerance and human behavior. Considering that I come from a town where most people will look at you as if you are trash if you don't suit up to go to the mall to watch a movie, I can't possibly read too much about such lessons. I really do not ever want to turn into one of those people. 
 Interesting quotes that I didn't include in the review: 
 You never really understand a person until you consider things from his point of view... Until you climb inside of his skin and walk around in it. 
 People generally see what they look for, and hear what they listen for. 
 The one thing that doesn't abide by majority rule is a person's conscience. 
 People in their right minds never take pride in their talents.
I wish I had read the book instead of hearing it. The beginning at least. It was kind off difficult to focus on the book.

The first time I read this book, I was in seventh or eight grade. I remember enjoying it and being moved by the story, but I know I didn't appreciate just how profoundly good a book it is. Reading it at 34 is such a different experience than at 13 or 14. I haven't and don't plan to read Don't Set a Watchman (based both on reviews and on the questionable nature of the book's release), but I'm glad that it's publication spurred me to reread this classic. It's heartbreaking how relevant so many of the issues in the book still are today. I don't often agree with "must read" book lists, but this book has obviously earned its place on all of them.

This novel has been reviewed so many times, it would be impossible to note something which hasn't been assessed and analyzed thoroughly before. 
 The story of racism seen through the eyes of children and told in a manner understandable by them explains why this book has been on many high school curricula and makes for a very adequate introduction to racial equality to all young minds. 
 While most of the content is understandably already familiar to me, considering how much media coverage there is on the central theme of the novel, I found some of the standpoints of Atticus Finch, who serves as the main pillar of morality for the children, to be quite insightful. That is not to say that Atticus' concepts of equality are what caught my attention, but the manner in which he brings up his two children, Scout and Jem, makes for a brilliant environment to raise children in, and fully allows them to explore their own moral terrain and gives room to corrective behavior which most children are capable of before they are socially polarized to have opinions on some social issues. 
 A brilliant read and I highly recommend it, not for the central theme, but to understand the concept of social polarization, the dangers of it, and to remind oneself that people already know the answer to questions on human dignity.

Homer Simpson: I'll have to read Marge's book. And I swore never to read again after 'To Kill a Mockingbird' gave me no useful advice on killing mockingbirds. It did teach me not to judge a man based on the color of his skin, but what good does that do me?

This review was originally posted to Jen in Bookland 
 4.5 stars 
 To Kill A Mockingbird was my book club book for this month. I had never read it before and I see now why it is such a classic. It was a great read. It is simple and easy to follow, but written in such a way that it entertained me from the first word until the last. Just a really great story. 
 I was surprised that the story was not as much about black vs white as I had thought going into it. Before reading it I had heard of it of course, but didn't really know the story. I knew there was some talk about race, but I thought that would be most of the story and I didn't think it was. I felt like it was more about people in general and how we treat each other based on various different things, one of them being the color of your skin. Really there is all of the hierarchy of people that everyone is in within their groups. Like Scout couldn't befriend Walter Cunningham because her aunt wouldn't let her. Why? Because he is a Cunningham and Cunningham's are beneath them. They are trash. It was really interesting how it was more about how we treat people in general. Yes, there is the black guy Tom and his trial and that whole racial tension part to it, but it is more than just that. I loved the story. 
 It was interesting as the one lady in book club felt like nothing really happened in the book, nothing really changed. I found that not to be true. This book was written at that time when the people are on the cusp of change. It shows how change happens slowly, it doesn't happen overnight. You keep fighting and you can change things. The jurors took hours to come back with a guilty conviction instead of minutes like it would have been. Sure it is not perfect yet, but it is setting up for the next time when maybe it won't be that they will convict just based on the color of the skin even if the person is obviously not guilty. Feelings are slowly changing and people are starting to think more about the way they are looking at things. Change doesn't happen overnight, but this showed how you can slowly start to influence people and their ways of doing things. 
 Atticus was of course the perfect moral compass. He was always level headed and kind to everyone. He didn't hold grudges and just wanted everyone to be treated equally. He didn't think less of the Cunninghams because they didn't have money, or the black people, or anyone really. He was just a great influence on everyone. He is just that all around good person in the story that if you needed to know if something was right or wrong you could look to him and what he thought. Not that he was really perfect, he did have some slight flaws that I don't even know were supposed to be there. Like his views on women are not 100% equal which I found interesting. Still for the most part he is the person to look to for right and wrong. 
 I am glad it was written in the point of view of a child. It was nice to see how she grew and was influenced by everyone around her. It was nice watching her try and figure out what is right and wrong, how to fit in someone else's skin and see it from their point of view. Really a great read and no wonder it is such a classic. Even though it was written some time ago it still feels relevant today. It is not one of those books where you just can't identify with what is happening and the people of the time because everything is so different. It still works today. Really loved this book and I am glad it was chosen for our book club read this month.

Descendent from Robert E. Lee, the Southern Civil War general, Harper Lee was born in Monroeville, Alabama. Her father was a former newspaper editor and proprietor, who had served as a state senator and practiced as a lawyer in Monroeville. Lee studied law at the University of Alabama from 1945 to 1949, and spent a year as an exchange student in Oxford University, 
 Wellington Square. Six months before finishing her studies, she went to New York to pursue a literary career. She worked as an Airline reservation clerk with Eastern Air Lines and British Overseas Airways during the 1950s. In 1959 Lee accompanied Truman Capote to Holcombe, Kansas, as a research assistant for Capote's classic 'non-fiction' novel In Cold Blood (1966). 
 To Kill a Mockingbird was Lee's first novel. 
 "Shoot all the bluejays you want, if you can hit 'em, but remember it's a sin to kill a mockingbird." 
 The story takes place during three years of the Great Depression in the fictional "tired old town" of Maycomb, Alabama. It focuses on six-year-old Scout Finch, who lives with her older brother Jem and their widowed father Atticus, a middle-aged lawyer. Jem and Scout befriend a boy named Dill who visits Maycomb to stay with his aunt each summer. The three children are terrified of, and fascinated by, their neighbor, the reclusive "Boo" Radley. The adults of Maycomb are hesitant to talk about Boo and, for many years, few have seen him. The children feed each other's imagination with rumors about his appearance and reasons for remaining hidden, and they fantasize about how to get him out of his house. Following two summers of friendship with Dill, Scout and Jem find that someone is leaving them small gifts in a tree outside the Radley place. Several times, the mysterious Boo makes gestures of affection to the children, but, to their disappointment, never appears in person. 
 Atticus is appointed by the court to defend Tom Robinson, a black man who has been accused of raping a young white woman, Mayella Ewell. Although many of Maycomb's citizens disapprove, Atticus agrees to defend Tom to the best of his ability. Other children taunt Jem and Scout for Atticus' actions, calling him a "nigger-lover". Scout is tempted to stand up for her father's honor by fighting, even though he has told her not to. For his part, Atticus faces a group of men intent on lynching Tom. 
 It was the first time I read this novel though of course I had heard about it on several occasions. I read some of the reviews before starting it and those gave me the idea the book was harsh and horrible, some even went as far as to say the book should be banned cause it was racist amongst other things. I think this books very well put down the idea of black people in that era. I think the book is very clear how unfair they have been treated on many occasions. I enjoyed very much the ideas the children came up with for their creepy neighbor, it reflected very well how children deal with things they cannot get their heads around. 
 I did enjoy the story of Tom Robinson too, it was clear he was innocent but did not stand a change. But it was good to see that not all people agreed with how things went. 
 What I did have a problem with was the use of language, I got the hang of it at some point but as a Dutch person reading in English it was difficult at first to get a grip on the Southern language used in the book. It did help though with setting the atmosphere. 
 I think the characters where described very well. They really came alive and it was easy to empathize with them. The description of the street and the houses what was where was very well too. You could imagine walking down a street, seeing children play and that one dark, abandoned looking house on the corner.

I first read this book as a high school student. At age 16, I was impressed by how much Scout learns about the world through the experiences of Tom Robinson's trial, "Boo" Radley's protection, and her interactions with Dill, the Ewells, her teachers, and of course her father Atticus. I learned about the power of empathy and about following one's conscience. 
 I re-read Mockingbird as a 32-year-old, this time from the perspective of a father. This time, I was enthralled by the way Atticus Finch parents his young children (who are close in age to my own two). He is honest, steady, and patient. He never loses his cool, but uses each of his children's mistakes (no matter how serious) as a teaching opportunity. He is the kind of teacher and father that I would like to be. 
 This time I was also more deeply impressed at Harper Lee's remarkable book than I was in high school. She really allows you to "crawl inside the skin" of each character -- even bad 'ol Mr. Ewell. There is just so much beauty, art, and feeling in this book... it brought a lump to my throat several times. Rooted in a time and place, Mockingbird's themes and characters are timeless.

After I finished it I decided that it is one of those books that I want to hug and in the same second I want to throw across the room and yell "IT'S NOT SUPPOSED TO END THIS WAY!" It seems as though everything was solved but I still feel like the story is unfinished.

Briefly, it's an excellent read about kids growing up & facing prejudice, along with other trials of life, morals, & death. While the movie with Gregory Peck was excellent, I still prefer the book. If you haven't read it, do so. It's one of the shorter, better classics & has aged superbly. 
 I first read this when I was in my teens (quite close to Jem's age) & loved it. Now I'm Atticus' age & have raised children of my own, which lends a different perspective. Knowing the story ahead of time meant I could relax & the details really popped. Scout is quite the character. Precocious, she's often a square peg in a round hole. Her experience with learning in school resonated quite deeply with me. 
 The combination of Scout's 8 year old POV & the small town background complimented each other & made the subtext come alive brilliantly. The huge problems of the racial divide, prejudice, & poverty during the Depression were obvious, but the way Scout tried to sort the good from the bad in people was fantastic. She had some definite ideas on how things should be & was quite bewildered by the reality of what was. Can't say as I blame her - I still don't understand people. Most of what should be black & white is gray, though it trends to paler shades in Atticus' opinion, one that she & I didn't always share. He's a far better, more understanding man than I. 
 The wording was captivating. For instance, the book starts off with: 
 When he was nearly thirteen, my brother Jem... 
 That tells us so much, so fast. Only a child would make such a fine distinction in age & we know the narrator holds Jem in high regard or else he'd just be 12.5. 
 Our introduction to Calpurnia made me chuckle. 
 Calpurnia was something else again. She was all angles and bones; she was nearsighted; she squinted; her hand was wide as a bed slat and twice as hard. Scout obviously doesn't place much importance on race as it is sometime before we get any clue as to Cal's race. Not until she speaks about old Mr. Radley & then we just know she's not white. That means she's different or has different rules to Scout only. 
 I remember operators fondly. As an only child with a busy mother & a perpetually absent father, I called them more than once for advice, so I got a real kick out this: 
 Eula May was Maycomb's leading telephone operator. She was entrusted with issuing public announcements, wedding invitations, setting off the fire siren, and giving first-aid instructions when Dr. Reynolds was away. 
 Or Scout's evaluation of her uncle's looks: 
 He and Aunty looked alike, but Uncle Jack made better use of his face: we were never wary of his sharp nose and chin. 
 Her comparison of one old biddy winding down like a pump-up organ: 
 I was reminded of the ancient little organ .... The last note would linger as long as there was air to sustain it. Mrs. Merriweather had run out of air, I judged, and was replenishing her supply while Mrs. Farrow composed herself to speak. 
 The characters were intriguing. Of course the focus was on discovering more about Boo & Atticus, but just what was Miss Maudie's story? She was some one I'd like to know more about. And the newspaperman, Mr. Underwood (perfect name) had a lot more bottom than showed most times. The sheriff & judge were good men, too. 
 Possibly my favorite scene was the one in front of the jailhouse. They did that well in the movie, too. You can find it here: 
 http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=oaVuVu... 
 Thanks to Florence for turning me on to it. 
 Anyway, great book, a must read, highly recommended & all that. If you haven't read it since you were forced to in school, by all means make some time now. I wish I hadn't waited so long. It's amazing how much more was there now than I remembered.
Interesting look into that time period.

This was the first adult book I read as a child. I read it again in college but it is my first impressions that are indelibly ingrained in my memory. I was drawn in by the childhood musings of Scout, Jeb and Dill but it was Atticus who became my adult model for decency and heroism. I knew little about the American South and even less about race relations before the civil rights movement took off in the early 1960's, and this wonderful book put it in perspective for me. Its influence helped to shape my development as a responsible adult.

This book has such wonderful characters & plot. I love Tom Robinson and Scout. I love how Lee gave so much character and attitude to Scout. It taught me a lot about the South in those days. Although I did hate all the racist comments the book had, I found it teaching me so much! 
 I picked this novel up in 5th grade, and got half way thtough with it, then lost it!!! I just found it over the summer and started over again, and I read it in about a week. This is definitely one of my favorite books! I recommened it to junior high kids, because it does talk about rape, and the court scenes can be confusing

There are some books that stay with you when you put them down, or (in my case) the recording finishes. Some books paint such a vivid picture in your mind that you'll continue to visualise scenes in your mind's eye for weeks, months, maybe even years to come because the author somehow managed to engage your sense of wonder. This is an art, certainly, and an art that I feel is critical to write great, as opposed to simply good, novels. Harper Lee is an artist. 
 Authors can craft these visual responses to words in different ways. Some do it through excellent use of prose (Mervyn Peake), atmosphere and setting (Susannah Clarke), or humour (Neil Gaiman, Douglas Adams). Lee falls somewhere within the second category, but what I feel is most remarkable about her approach is her command over nostalgia. She manages to create a believable and, above all, romantic and nostalgic atmosphere as she reflects upon the childhood of Gene Louise "Scout" Finch - all the while keeping everything perfectly realistic. To me she captures the very essence of childhood. 
 This powerful setting sets the atmosphere for Lee's bildungsroman and lures the reader into its grasp without one really noticing. That is not to say that this book is, as some have claimed, an easy read. I felt the first 100 pages were a slog to get through, mainly because the plot seemingly wasn't going anywhere and not much was happening, but perhaps this was necessary in order to fully realise the atmosphere. As with all stories this was a compromise between setting, plot, and characters, and luckily the eventual result of this compromise was a satisfying one. 
 To Kill a Mockingbird is worth the read for its atmosphere and nostalgic meditations on childhood alone, but there is one particular reason I believe absolutely everyone will benefit from reading this book. That reason is called Atticus Finch. 
 John Greene called him the "role model to end all role models", and I couldn't agree more.

I read this book because 'it's a classic'. I had to remind myself of this as I bored myself with the first half of the book. 
 To me, it read more like a collection of short stories with a huge cast of characters, and then some interception of these stories at the end. The second half of the book was a much more interesting end. 
 I assume this book has such high acclaim and used in schools to study racism - all the while being a sexist text in itself. 
 I promise there are far worse classics out there, and the book does get better the further you get into it.

I am so glad that I had to read this book for school. It was absolutely amazing. The lessons I learned from reading it will always stay with me. I don't even know what else to say. To Kill a Mockingbird was just beautiful.

I re-read this in 2012 because it was the book club choice for the club Dennis and I belong to. I also read it because I assigned it to him and wanted it to be fresh on my mind when we discussed it. I would say I loved it as much as when I read it in high school but that would be an understatement. I loved it even more. I think age and wisdom, in addition to the different world we now live in made me love it even more.
Read this for school.

WHEN I Discovered This Classic: Um...I don't even know. I mean, I always knew of it. Is there any American child who has not heard of this book? Especially with all the hoopla last year? Also, I'm pretty sure in one or two literature classes we watched part of the movie because I can't forget a Gregory Peck, but I was never in a class that actually read it, which is really actually kind of striking to me. I focused on the Southern Gothic for goodness sake! *hides* 
 WHY I Chose to Read It: Because I was really embarrassed about the fact that I never had! With all the controversy last year, I found myself nodding along a lot, and I felt really bad about it. Also, apparently I some intention to read this because I put myself on the library hold list for Go Set A Watchman and promptly forgot that I did so (a thing I do a lot because my library system is huge and it takes forever for popular books to come in). My hold came in at the beginning of January and my first thought was "Whoops, well, I probably should read To Kill A Mockingbird first." 
 WHAT Makes It A Classic: I find it interesting when you look at contemporary reviews of Mockingbird versus more modern reviews. It makes me think a lot about the life of literature and reception of a work can change over time. I think in the end what gave Mockingbird it's staying power is its portrayal of a specific time and place. It cuts into harsh issues of racism, classism, injustice, etc and does it through the eyes of a relatively privileged child. We see her (and especially her brother's) awaken to these problems and the (often problematic) mistakes she makes navigating them in a way that not many books allow. I think it's important to have a book in the "Classics" cannon that tells children, sometimes you're wrong and sometimes adults are too. 
 WHAT I Thought of This Classic: This is a masterpiece. Pure and simple. This is one of those situations where my five stars are less "I liked the story" and more "the writing is transformative." The story itself is brutal and harsh in many ways, even, (dare I use the Southern Gothic convention?) grotesque, but it is also imbued with a slim sense of hope. and childishness because of the narrators place in the world. I found the use of perspective and sense of place particularly interesting. This storyline could have been a -fascinating- multi-pov story, but the way Lee uses Scout as the sole voice we are struck hard with a very specific person's point of view. I have a lot of thoughts on that which I will come back to at some other time. 
 WILL It Stay A Classic: I don't know what else to say other than, "well, yeah." I think there are many ways that the themes in this book could be mined in literature classes that (as far as I know, as I stated above, none of my lit classes ever actually read it) it's currently not, and these discussions could open up a lot of new avenues. We are far from done with this book. 
 WHO I'd Recommend It To: People interested in Southern (especially Southern Gothic) literature, People who are interested in explore point-of-view, People who appreciate a strong sense of place in their fiction

The first 10 chapters or so kinda bored me, I understand why some people can't bring themselves to finish the book. It really gets better though. 
 Not really my type, but well written. To walk in a nine-year-old girl's shoes is a nice experience, too.

Set in the backdrop of The Great Depression, to Kill a Mocking Bird is an unpretentious tale of love, heartbreak and the loss of innocence, told through the eyes of a child....such that "even children can understand it". It is commentary on the human psyche and the social prejudices prevalent in those times, especially in the southern states. 
 Killing a Mocking Bird is a sin, it symbolic of killing something that is innocent and harmless and wonderful. This theme is expressed over and over in this book in various events. Told in a simple narrative, it paints a clear picture of society where racial discrimination and gender inequality were prevalent. But feminism was trying to make a headway, as in seen by Scout's deep resentment of social etiquette amongst women. The women's fashion of those times subtly points to the latter. 
 The three years this book spans, we see the two main protagonists grow, and through their eyes we see the true nature of their correspondents change till, one incident strips away their masks forever. This hypocrisy leaves a deep impression on their minds and above all, it is this this hypocrisy that attributes to the loss of this innocence. 
 A mocking bird has been killed and it is only the aftermath that shows us the gruesome picture of society bared to all. It is only one man that dares to stand against it. And that is why, Atticus is symbolic of courage and bravery. 
 His courage may not be about fighting a war, or firing a gun, but it is a bravery ingrained in his nature that trumps all and triumphs always....if not in saving a man, then in winning his children's respect forever.

This is one of those books that everyone else seemed to have to read in school except for me. And BECAUSE it was required reading for school, it put me off from wanting to read it on my own (i know, dumb of me). I've seen clips of the movie and have "seen" a play production of it from a high school (but i honestly just didn't want to pay attention, i was kind of forced to go) but I knew in the back of my mind I'd get around to reading it SOMEDAY. But knowing what becomes of a character in the "sequel" (if you can really call it that) has just put me off from ever reading this at all. 
 I wonder if the use of this book as a required-reading novel in school will continue now, knowing what becomes of the characters in the sequel. So much of what I hear my friends remembering learning from it is kind of tarnished from the sequel. I don't know. 
 (view spoiler)[From an outsiders perspective, Atticus Finch's racism in the 1950's south when Go Set A Watchmen takes place makes sense. And look, just because Atticus defended a black man in the first book does not mean he didn't believe in segregation. Historically speaking, his racism in the second book is logical... but at the end of the day... it's a book. And not many people like to have someone they "idolized" in a sense be brought down. I don't know. The entirety of GSAW's publication in the first place was shady enough, but I honestly wonder if Harper Lee held off from publishing it was because she knew her characters had changed when writing TKAM. (hide spoiler)]

I loved this book when I first read it in high school, and I love it even more now. When I first read it, I thought it was just about race relations. Now I realize it's about so much more than that. 
 It's about growing up in the South during the Great Depression. 
 It's about gender roles. 
 It's about the power of rumors. 
 It's about religious hypocrisy. 
 It's about friendship. 
 It's about family. 
 It's about the different ways receive education. 
 It's about different kinds of courage. 
 It's about stereotypes and prejudice - including but not limited to racism. 
 And finally, it's about the loss of innocence we all experience when we realize that the world won't always work out the way we want it to. 
 If you haven't read this classic, I would highly recommend it.

It's a wonderful book. Glad I didn't have to read this in school, otherwise I would've hated it. The characters are slightly one-dimensional cardboard cut-outs of some stereotypes, but it works for this story.

I was pleasantly surprised by how much I actually enjoyed this- I tend to find that books set for English Literature classes tend to be a little dry for my liking. The writing was easy to read and engaging though- the characters were all deliciously fleshed out. Things didn't settle too badly either; although some of the subject matter was a little trivial, the pace was good and kept up throughout the whole of the book; at the end I was reading it quickly, because things were coming to such a climax! 
 I think Atticus Finch is one oft he most awesome characters, profound but very homely and down to earth at the same time. I love how the world rests heavy on his shoulders, how he's both a strong figure but also one with wit and a light side. Scout is awesome, fiery and opinionated; Jem the same, but in a different way, which I appreciated. 
 It deals with so many different things and I haven't time to write properly about it, but this was lovely to read =)

Only because 5 stars is the limit... 
 I hadn't read this book since high school, and WOW - I am so glad that I did. Harper Lee is an amazing writer and Atticus Fitch is truly one of the best characters of all time. I have never highlighted a book before or searched for things on my iPad, and this is a story that I couldn't help but highlight and take notes on, solely because I was moved by the use of the English language. Harper Lee's writing is such that you are transported to the 1930s, to a time of racial divide and to a time of small towns, lack of education, and poverty that rampant. 
 Her work is truly a study of not only the time period, but of the characters. Her character development is so strong that you are pulled in and either love or despise them throughout the story. Ones that really struck a chord with me were: 
 Atticus - he is truly the father, the man, the role model that everyone wants in their life. He parents with EXTREME patience, with understanding, and with a deep conviction between right and wrong. His tolerance knows no bounds and I am awed with him. I have a wonderful, wonderful, father but would love to have had Atticus be in my life as well. 
 Scout - gotta love her. She is given the freedom to be who she wants to be, to play games and run with her brother, to be a free spirit. Yet, she is quick to go back home, listen to and share things with her father, and cuddle up in his lap. She embodies all that I want in children - that innocence, the spunk, and the firm beliefs in what is good. 
 My other favorite characters were Miss Maudie (how could you NOT love her - especially after her comment during the missionary lunch?) and Calpurnia. I even started to like Aunty a little towards the end. 
 I am just in awe of this book. ABSOLUTELY makes my favorites list. I am awaiting Netflix's copy of the movie tomorrow. I remember vaguely that Gregory Peck is amazing as Atticus. Right now, I'm just going to go for the "I've finished the most amazing book" afterglow and pause before deciding my next book to read.

I read this book in high school and hated it. Rereading it now as an adult has provided with me with some perspective, especially in how well the story is constructed. The characters are well developed and the story is well paced. The ending leaves a bit of a question mark, but all good books should leave the reader wanting more.

My grandfather bought me "To Kill a Mockingbird" when I was thirteen or fourteen because he was shocked I hadn't read it yet. Read it then and loved it. Read it now and still love it. It's one of those books where you dread the ending because it means you can't live in that community any more and you'll see no more of the neighbors or main characters and learn no more of their past or future. It's not that the ending is unsatisfying but that you want it to never end.

This is a really beautiful, very important book. I can see why it is considered a classic, I really can. I don't need to sit here and tell you why it's such an amazing, important book, that's been done a thousand times, a thousand different ways. I missed out reading this in high school, but I'm pretty sure a massive percentage of the Western population did read this in school, so most people should already have an idea about how amazing and important this book is. 
 Having spent most of my life hearing about this book but never having a clear idea as to what it was about, here are some things I wasn't expecting: 
 *The narrator is an 6-8 year old girl (it takes place over a couple of years) 
 *Very little of the court case actually features in the story 
 *Most of the meat of the story- the real essay-worthy stuff- happens as subtext 
 *The model of white trash that was happening... they live down near the black people and never work, so we (the locals) all have to act like they're worth more than the black people (because, after all, they're white) but none of us believe they are. There's a lot of complicated stuff happening there. 
 *I would die for Atticus Finch. He could ask me to do anything and I would do it. He is one of the most interesting characters I have ever encountered. I hear he gets a rough shake in the second one, and I'm really interested in reading it, because I don't see him as like... the American Ideal that I think he gets slotted in to. He's a man who is ahead of his time, but there is only so far one person can go when he still lives in that time. Also lots of interesting stuff going on with him. 
 *The willing sacrifice of one minority on the alter of another. 
 This is where the book lost a star, for me. The part when Jem was 'explaining' rape cases didn't really bother me, because it was actually an interesting look at how childishly we have seen these things in the past. "Basically if you're not beat to a pulp and, preferably, knocked unconscious, it wasn't rape." It's a very adolescent definition, and, horrifically, it's one we as a society have used. Even the case itself didn't bother me, all sides were humanized enough that I could see how no one could win. I mean, cool motive, still murder, but yeah, everything is awful. The part I wasn't expecting was the narrator's blatant distaste for her own gender. And you can see it being built up in her by the people surrounding her (her brother always saying "you're starting to act like a girl" to shame her, and so on) until it reaches a place where she says something like "They might drink, swear, gamble blah blah lists more sins, but men are still more comfortable than women." And I know she's only 8 years old, but she's SO uncomfortable in her own skin, as a girl, that groups of ladies makes her want to run away. This never gets dealt with, beyond a really passing sort of "hey, I think being a girl might be a lot of work and not about weakness after all" at one point. 
 And then there was the time when someone died (look at me trying to avoid spoilers) and the ladies go back to their missionary lunch, and Scout tries to behave her best because, "If Aunt Alexandra could be a lady at a time like this, then so could I." And on the one hand, it's one of the few times when Scout sees Auntie's behavior in a positive light; it might be the only time when femininity is seen as strength. But it's such a... I don't know, two-faced reaction? Why IS she being a lady at a time like this? The human thing to do would be to mourn, but they can't, because the one who died isn't white, so they go on with the facade, and this is the femininity we have to be proud of? I don't know. It doesn't sit right. I'm also INTENSELY worried about Mayella, and very angry that none of those missionary ladies thought to seek her out and help her. 
 Anyway, it was disappointing that a book that was working so hard to show all people are people would also, both blatantly and in subtext, trod on another minority. And things like Scout's internal misogyny being so clearly built up by other people kind of make me wonder if Lee wasn't doing something purposeful with that, like she was with the racism, but the resolution was never made clear. I do love Aunt Alexandra though. I love that she wasn't a straight-up baddie/terrible mother figure. And I did love that when the boys were being dicks, Scout went and hung out with Miss Maudie. There WERE some excellent women in there, doing excellent things. It's just that, while the narrative clearly presents racism as a problem, the sexism remains confused. It is really interesting to see that internal misogyny being built by a culture that is so intensely sexist, but while the internal racism is being challenged, I don't see the same thing happening with the sexism. I BELIEVE with all my soul that there was an underlying purpose to all those gender issues, but believe with the same intensity that it was unfinished. 
 That was a MASSIVE tangent, and it makes it seem like I thought less of the whole than I did. I wish I didn't need that tangent, but I still LOVED the book. And I am SO curious to read her sequel when it comes out in like... 2 days.

It's been ages since I read this. Hollywood Housewife is hosting a book club discussion on it this week, which was a good excuse to finally re-read it. It still holds up, though I do wonder how POC view it.

Clearly there's a good reason why To Kill a Mockingbird is such a classic. I've seen the movie a million times but never read the book until now. There's so much that the movie misses, and yet there are good reasons why certain characters are left out, like Aunt Alexandra. Of course, I love Boo Radley all the more now that the book helped me to understand him. However, I do admit that it was hard to read at times. I greatly dislike the "n" word and it made quite a lot of appearances in the book, but Ms. Lee was only staying true to what was common speech during the Great Depression in Alabama. 
 What makes this book so great was that it was published in 1960, a few years before the Civil Rights Movement really took off. I wonder just how controversial this book was back then? I can't imagine that it was universally appreciated then like it is now.
Reviw to come. Maybe. But it's good. You should definitely read it!

**4 Stars** 
 I really enjoyed this book. I never had to read it in high school, so I wasn't sure what to expect. 
 ****SPOILER ALERT**** 
 The book give you so much hope that Tom will win, then crushes you. It is hard to believe that stuff like this actually happened in our past. Even with everything that happened with Tom, I was really happy with the ending. The emergence of Boo was perfect and a great way to end the book.
